column6: utterance_text_gemini

Well see, my wife's been getting on me a lot lately about trying to improve my health habits, and I really don't see what the big problem is. I mean, I've been working real hard. Sometimes I can't come home for dinner, so I'm having to go out to eat at Applebee's or something like that, so-- but she seems to have a bigger problem, I really don't see what the big deal is.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit confused and maybe even a little frustrated that your wife is concerned about your eating habits, while you feel like everything is fine.  Is that a fair summary?
Yeah, I mean, I feel fine.  Work's tough, I work hard all day, and grabbing something quick at Applebee's is just…easier.  She doesn't get it.
So, the convenience of grabbing a quick bite after a long day is really important to you right now.  Tell me more about what a typical workday looks like for you.
Well, it's manual labor, mostly outside. Hot sun, you know. I'm on my feet all day.  I sweat a lot, so I figure I'm burning off whatever I eat.

That sounds physically demanding.  It makes sense that you’d want something quick and easy after a long day like that.  So, you mentioned sweating a lot – how do you think that impacts your overall health and well-being?
Well, I mean, I feel okay.  A little tired sometimes, but nothing major.  I figure sweating's good, right? Gets rid of the bad stuff.
It sounds like you’re pretty in tune with your body. You mentioned feeling tired sometimes – is that a regular thing, or just occasionally?
Eh, sometimes.  Especially towards the end of the week.
Okay.  And you mentioned you had a physical last year.  Everything was good then, right?
Yeah, the doctor said I was fine.
That’s good to hear.  So, if you’re feeling okay, and your doctor gave you a clean bill of health last year, what do you think might be driving your wife’s concern?
I don't know. She says I need to eat healthier, maybe cook more at home.  But honestly, I don't have the time or energy for that after work.  And like I said, I feel fine.

It sounds like you value the convenience of eating out after a long day, and that cooking at home feels like a significant challenge given your work schedule.  It also sounds like you trust your own assessment of your health.  Is that right?
Yeah, pretty much.

Okay. So, just to make sure I understand, you’re not particularly concerned about your health right now, you feel your current eating habits work for you given your work schedule, and you’re a little puzzled by your wife’s concerns. Is there anything else I should know?
No, I think that covers it.

Okay. Thanks for sharing all of that with me.  It sounds like you've given this some thought.  What are your thoughts on exploring this a little further, maybe looking at the connection between diet, energy levels, and long-term health?  No pressure at all, just an option.
I guess… I mean, if it’s quick. I don’t have a lot of time.
Absolutely. We can keep it brief and focus on what’s relevant to you. How about we start by talking a little bit more about what 'healthy eating' means to you?
Hi, Emily. It's good to see you again.
Hi. Yeah, it's been a little while.
I notice something new!  You've got a lip piercing.  Looks interesting. How long have you had it?
Oh, thanks! About a month now.
Cool. So, what prompted you to get it?
Um, I don't know, really. Just felt like a change, I guess.  A bit bored with the usual, and it's kind of fun to stand out a little.
I get that.  A little something different can be refreshing.  So, what's been your experience with it so far?
Pretty good!  It's still new, so mostly just getting used to it.  I like how it looks.
It does look good.  As your dentist, though, I do have a few things I usually discuss with patients who have oral piercings. Have you thought much about how it might affect your teeth or gums?
Not really, to be honest. I mean, I figured it might, you know, rub against them a bit, but I haven't really looked into it. My teeth are pretty good, so I haven't been too worried.

You do have great teeth, and I always enjoy seeing how well you take care of them.  That's why I want to make sure we're on the same page about this.  Sometimes, these piercings can cause some gum recession, particularly right where the jewelry sits.
Oh, really? I didn't know that.
It's something to be aware of.  And we also see chipped teeth occasionally, from the jewelry bumping against them.
Oh wow. I definitely don't want to mess up my teeth.  You've mentioned my gums being a little lower before, and how important flossing is. I know I'm not the best at that...

Flossing is definitely key, and we can always talk more about that too.  It sounds like you're already thinking about the potential impact on your oral health.  What would make you consider taking the piercing out?
I guess if I started seeing actual problems, like the gum thing you mentioned, or if I chipped a tooth. But right now, it's fine.
So, you're thinking a "wait and see" approach, keeping an eye on things?
Yeah, pretty much.  It's only been a month, and like I said, I like it.  But my teeth are important, so…
Absolutely.  It sounds like you're weighing the aesthetic appeal against the potential risks, which is a smart approach. So, monitoring it closely and being aware of any changes is your plan for now?
Exactly.  I mean, the piercing might not be forever, but I'd like my teeth
Hi, Sal. Thanks for coming in today. I know it’s not always easy to make time for these appointments, so I really appreciate you being here.
No problem.
So, Sal, what brings you in to see me today?
Well, my doctor suggested I come talk to someone.  She mentioned something about needing to make some changes…
Okay. And what’s your understanding of those suggested changes?
Honestly, it feels like I’m being asked to change everything all at once.  It’s a bit overwhelming.
It sounds like you’re feeling quite a bit of pressure to make these changes.
Definitely.  There’s the asthma, which has been acting up lately, and then there’s… well, everything else.
Can you tell me a little more about this “everything else”?
It’s the dog, for one.  The doctor thinks Oscar is making my asthma worse, which is ridiculous.  He’s my best friend.
It sounds like the possibility of having to give up Oscar is really upsetting you.
It is.  He’s been with me through thick and thin.  And then there’s the drinking…
So, cutting back on your drinking is also something you’re thinking about?
Yeah, it’s on the list.  Along with cutting back on cigarettes, which I’ve already made some progress on, actually.
That’s great to hear!  So, you’ve already started making some positive changes.
Yeah, but it feels like there’s still so much more.  And with my wife on maternity leave, and me being the only one working… it’s just a lot.
It sounds like you’re carrying a lot right now, Sal.  Between your health, your family, and the pressure to make these changes, it’s understandable that you’re feeling overwhelmed.
Exactly.  It just feels like too much.
So, Sal, we have about [duration] together today.  Where would you like to start?  What feels like the most pressing issue for you right now?
I think the Oscar situation is really weighing on me.  And my asthma has been pretty
So, you mentioned you sprained your ankle yesterday. Tell me a bit about how that happened.

Ugh, it's so embarrassing. I was at a 90s-themed pub crawl, and, well, you know how those are. A few drinks, and then I thought it would be brilliant to jump off the bus stairs to catch up with my friends. I was wearing stilettos, of all things. And, yeah, I landed wrong.
A 90s pub crawl in stilettos – sounds like quite an adventure.
Definitely an adventure. Though my ankle didn't think so.
So, the dancing ended abruptly, I imagine?
Yeah, the dancing was over. And so was my night, pretty much.
I understand. I'm curious, would you be open to talking a little about your alcohol use in general, beyond last night?
Uh, sure. As long as we don't dwell on the vodka shots. I'm still… yeah.
Still feeling the after-effects?
Definitely.
That sounds rough. So, what does a typical week look like for you in terms of alcohol consumption?
Well, my friends and I, we usually go out on weekends. We're all university students, so it's kind of the norm to have a few drinks.
A few drinks being a regular part of the university experience, as you see it?
Yeah, pretty much.
And what does 'a few' mean? Is that per night, or are we talking two or three drinks?
If we're going out, it can be more than a few. Like, if I'm really going for it, maybe seven or eight. And then, you know, a beer or two after a long day at the library.
Seven or eight drinks – that's quite a bit. Do you ever have any concerns about your drinking?
Not really. It seems pretty normal for university.
So, no real concerns at this point, and you feel it's in line with what other students are doing?
Yeah, exactly.
Would you be willing to take a look at the low-risk drinking guidelines?
Sure, why not?

I know you might not be feeling your best right now, but let's just briefly glance at these. They suggest that for women, the safe limit is around 10 drinks a week, with no more than two drinks on any single day.
Oh, wow. Really?
Yeah. Where do you think you fall in relation to those guidelines?
Uh… probably a bit over, especially with midterms coming up.
So, it's maybe a way to manage stress a bit?
Yeah, I guess so.
And has that been your way of coping for a while now?
Yeah, it has, I think.
Okay. Does that concern you at all, even a little?
Um, the 10 drinks just seems like such a small amount, especially with my tolerance. I've built that up over time.
I understand. So, the guideline amount seems low given your experience.
Exactly.
Do you see any potential benefits to staying within those guidelines, or reducing your alcohol intake?
Uh, benefits… Well, health-wise, I guess.
Tell me more about what you mean by that.
Well, I mean, I definitely don't feel great right now. And I know I'm more productive when I'm not hungover.
So, you recognize some advantages to drinking less?
Yeah, definitely.
That's a great insight. Would you be open to exploring this further with me sometime when you're feeling a bit better? Maybe we could talk more about those potential benefits?
Yeah, I think so. Maybe when I haven't just… you know… done this to myself.
I'd be happy to schedule another appointment with you. Would later this week or early next week work for you?
Okay, yeah. That sounds good. Just not on another Saturday morning.
Absolutely. We can find a better time. Thanks for talking with me today.
Yeah, thanks.
Hi Bob, thanks for coming in. What's on your mind today?

Well, honestly, my wife's the reason I'm here. She thinks I have a smoking problem. I've smoked for years, and now, since she quit six months ago, it's like I'm the villain. She's really been on my case about it.
It sounds like you're feeling pressured to be here, and maybe a little frustrated.
That's putting it mildly. I mean, I'm missing work for this. It feels like a waste of time.
So, it's not just the smoking itself, but the feeling of being forced into this that's bothering you?
Exactly. It's the constant nagging. Six months of it! She quit, so now I have to?
Help me understand. What are some of the specific things your wife is concerned about?
The usual – my health. She's always showing me these articles about secondhand smoke. It's like a daily dose of guilt.
So, she's worried about the impact on your health, and maybe even the impact your smoking has on others around you?
Yeah, and it's changed our routines too. We used to enjoy a cigarette together, now I'm banished outside, even in the worst weather. It feels like she's completely changed.
It sounds like you feel like your shared habits and rituals have been disrupted, and that's creating some tension.
Absolutely. And the kids are in on it too. It feels like I'm the target of a family campaign.
So, you've got your wife, your kids, and the constant reminders about health risks. It sounds like you're feeling ganged up on.
Yeah, exactly. It's like I'm the only one who smokes anymore.
Bob, you mentioned your dad still smokes at 85. What comes to mind when you think about that?
Well, he's fine. I mean, it makes me wonder if all this fuss is really necessary. But I also know things are different now.

It sounds like you're weighing the immediate pressure from your family against your own experience and observations. You’re also acknowledging that times and understanding of health risks have changed.
Yeah. I mean, I love my wife and kids. I don't want to lose them over this.
It sounds like your relationship with your family is a top priority for you. You’ve been married for 25 years, and this is the first major conflict you've faced.
Yeah, it is. We’ve always been good together. This is really putting a strain on things.

So, on the one hand, you value your relationship and don't want to lose it. On the other hand, you're feeling pressured and maybe a little resentful about the way this is being handled. Is that a fair summary?
Yeah, that's pretty much it. I don't want to lose my family, but I also don't like being told what to do.

It sounds like you're in a tough spot, Bob. It's not just about the cigarettes; it's about navigating these important relationships and finding a way forward that works for everyone. It's not an easy situation.
No, it's not. I don't know what to do.
It seems like you're thinking about the future, and how this issue might impact your relationship long-term. You mentioned the possibility of gradual change. What are your thoughts on that?
I’d be more open to that. Just quitting cold turkey feels impossible.

It sounds like a more gradual approach might feel less overwhelming and more manageable for you. There are definitely strategies and resources we can explore to support that. We could also talk about involving your wife in this process. Would that be something you'd be open to?
Definitely. She needs to hear this. She thinks I can just snap my fingers and quit.
I’d be happy to have her join us. Perhaps we could find a time that works for both of you to come in and discuss this together.
Okay. I'll talk to her and give you a call tomorrow.
Great, Bob. I look forward to it.
Thanks.
Hi there. Thanks for coming in today.  I understand you're here to talk about managing your diabetes. Is that right?
Yeah, that's right. I was just diagnosed, and honestly, I'm a bit overwhelmed.
I can imagine.  Being diagnosed with diabetes can feel like a lot to take in.  It sounds like you've already had a conversation with your doctor about it?

Yeah, I did. She went over my A1C results, which were pretty high, and talked about all the potential complications – eyesight, feet, all of it.  It was really scary. That's why I'm here, I guess. I need to figure out how to manage all of this, but it just seems so daunting.

It sounds like you're feeling quite anxious about the potential health risks and the changes you might need to make.  It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed when faced with something like this.  It's a big adjustment.

Exactly!  She talked about medication, diet changes, exercise...it's a huge list.  I'm not even sure I can do all of that.  And the thought of all those complications if I *don't*...it's just a lot to handle.

So, if I'm hearing you correctly, you're feeling overwhelmed by the sheer number of changes that seem necessary, and also quite worried about the potential consequences if you're not able to make those changes. Is that a fair summary?
Yeah, that's pretty much it.

Okay.  So, let's break things down a little.  Instead of looking at the entire list of changes all at once, maybe we could start by exploring what *you* feel might be the easiest or most manageable first step.  What comes to mind when you think about that?
Hmm... I guess the diet thing seems the most immediate. I know I need to change how I eat, but I don't even know where to start. It feels like my whole life revolves around food.

That's a very common feeling.  Many people find dietary changes challenging.  It's understandable that you feel that way. So, it sounds like you're identifying diet as something important, and you're also recognizing some of the challenges you anticipate.  Tell me a little more about what makes you say your whole life revolves around food.

Well, I work long hours, and when I get home, I'm exhausted.  Cooking a healthy meal feels like a huge effort.  Takeout is just so much easier.  And then there's social stuff – going out to eat with friends, family gatherings... food is always a big part of it.

So, convenience and social connections both play a role in your current eating habits.  It sounds like there are several factors to consider.  It's not just about the food itself, but also the context in which you're eating.  Is that right?
Yeah, that's a good way to put it.  It's not just the food, it's everything around it.

Okay.  So, given that convenience and social connections are important factors, what are some small, realistic changes you could imagine making to your diet that might address those factors?  We're not talking about huge overhauls here, just small, manageable steps.

Hmm... maybe I could start by packing my lunch for work instead of getting takeout every day.  That would at least take care of one meal.  And maybe I could look for healthier options when I do go out with friends.

Those sound like some great starting points. Packing your lunch could definitely increase convenience and give you more control over what you're eating.  And looking for healthier options when dining out is another smart strategy. So, it sounds like you've already got some ideas.  What feels most doable right now?
The lunch thing, I think.  I could probably manage that.

Okay, great.  So, packing your lunch is something you feel confident you could try.  Let's talk a little more about that. What kind of support or resources might be helpful for you to make that happen?
Maybe some quick and easy recipes? I'm not a great cook.
Absolutely.  We can definitely find some resources for that.  So, it sounds like some quick recipes would be helpful.  Is there anything else that might make this easier for you?
Maybe some containers? I don't have very good ones right now.

Great idea.  Having the right containers can make a big difference.  So, we've identified some quick recipes and new containers as potential supports.  How do you feel about trying this out for the next week and then we can check in and see how it's going?
Yeah, I think I can do that.

Excellent.  Remember, we're taking this one step at a time.  Small changes can lead to big results.  I'm here to support you in any way I can.  We'll talk more next week and see how things are progressing.
Okay, thanks.
So, tell me more about what brings you in today.
Well, they found a small amount of marijuana on me.
I see.  Can you tell me a little more about that?
It wasn't much, honestly.
Okay.  So, it sounds like the quantity is a key part of this for you.
Yeah, I mean, it's not like I'm some big dealer or anything.  It was just for me.
Just for personal use?
Yeah, exactly.  And honestly, it's California.  Everyone does it.
It sounds like you're thinking about the context of where we are and how common this is.
Yeah, pretty much. So, how long is this whole thing going to take?

That's a very understandable question. We have about 15-20 minutes for our session today, and this is the first of several sessions we'll have together over the next six months.  It's natural to want to know the timeframe.  Beyond the time commitment, what else is on your mind about this whole process?
I just want to get this over with as quickly as possible.
So, your focus is on completing whatever is necessary to put this behind you?
Exactly.

Okay. That makes sense. I have a form we can use to create a shared agenda for our sessions. This can help us stay focused on your goals and ensure I'm supporting you in the best way possible to get this resolved. Would you be open to working on that together now?
Sure, that sounds good.
Great. Let's start by thinking about what a successful outcome would look like for you.
Well, obviously, getting through this without any major consequences.
So, minimizing any negative impact is a top priority.
Yeah, and also, I guess, figuring out how to avoid this kind of situation in the future.
That's a really important point.  So, we're talking about both immediate consequences and longer-term strategies.
Exactly.
Okay, let's write those down on the form.  We can then break down those goals into smaller, more manageable steps we can work on together.
Sarah, it's good to see you again.  How are you doing today?
I'm okay, I guess.  A little stressed, to be honest.
I understand.  Life can be hectic.  We talked last time about your smoking and drinking habits. How have things been going since then?
Um, not great. I haven't really made any changes.
That's perfectly alright.  Change can be challenging.  What's been getting in the way?
Well, work has been crazy, and then my son has been sick.  It's just been easier to light up a cigarette or have a drink to unwind.
It sounds like you've had a lot on your plate.  So, smoking and having a drink in the evenings have been your way of coping with that stress?
Yeah, pretty much.
I hear you.  It makes sense that you'd reach for something that helps you relax when things get overwhelming.  Tell me more about what those evenings are like.
Well, I put my son to bed, and then I finally have some time to myself.  That's when I usually smoke and have a couple of drinks.
So, it's that 'me time' that you look forward to?
Exactly.
And what else do you do during that 'me time' besides smoking and drinking?
Not much, really.  Sometimes I watch TV or scroll through my phone.
So, it sounds like those activities are also part of your relaxation routine?
Yeah, I guess so.
Okay.  Let's talk a bit more about your smoking.  You mentioned you haven't made any changes.  How many cigarettes are you smoking a day now, roughly?
Probably still around eight or nine.
And how about alcohol?  How many drinks are you having in a week?
Probably closer to ten than seven, if I'm being honest.

Thanks for your honesty, Sarah.  I appreciate you sharing that with me.  It takes courage to be open about these things. So, on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is 'not at all ready to consider making a change' and 10 is 'completely ready to make a change,' where would you say you are right now regarding your smoking?
Probably still around a five, like last time.
Okay, a five.  That's interesting.  What makes you say a five and not a three or a two?
I know I should probably cut back, especially with my son.  And you mentioned the health risks last time, and those are in the back of my mind.
So, those health concerns and your family are motivating factors for you?
Yeah, definitely.
That's understandable.  It sounds like you have some important reasons to consider making a change. What would it take to move that number closer to a seven or an eight?
I don't know.  It just feels so hard.
I understand.  Change can be difficult, especially when it's something you enjoy and use to relax.  What are some things you could try that might make it a little easier?
Maybe I could try going for a walk instead of having a cigarette. Or maybe try drinking sparkling water instead of wine.
Those sound like some great ideas, Sarah.  So, you're thinking about replacing the smoking and drinking with other activities?
Yeah, maybe.

That's a fantastic starting point.  We can explore some other strategies as well.  How would you feel about trying those out for the next couple of weeks and then we can check in again and see how it's going?
Yeah, I think I could do that.
Great.  And remember, I'm here to support you every step of the way.  We can work together to find what works best for you.  We can also talk more about managing stress in other ways, if you'd like.
That would be helpful.
Absolutely. We can schedule another appointment in a couple of weeks to discuss your progress and explore some stress management techniques. How does that sound?
Sounds good.
Wonderful.  I'm glad we had this conversation, Sarah. You're taking a positive step by even considering these changes.  I'll see you in a couple of weeks.
Okay, thanks.  See you then.
Hi, Mrs. Smith.  It's good to see you and Lilly today. We're scheduled for some routine vaccinations today.
Oh, hi.  Actually, I'm a little hesitant about the vaccines. I've been reading some things online, and I'm not sure they're the best thing for her.
I understand. It's perfectly normal to have questions and concerns, especially when it comes to your child's health.  Tell me more about what you've been reading and what's making you unsure.
Well, I've seen some articles saying it's better for kids to build their immunity naturally, you know, by getting the actual diseases.  Like, I had chickenpox as a kid, and now I'm immune.
That's a great example.  You're right, having chickenpox gives you natural immunity.  It sounds like you're thinking about the benefits of natural immunity versus the immunity provided by vaccines.
Exactly.  I just worry about overloading her little system with so many vaccines.  And I've heard some scary things about side effects.

I appreciate you sharing your concerns. It's important to weigh all the information. Let's talk about the specific diseases these vaccines protect against and how they can impact children.  Before vaccines, diseases like measles, polio, and whooping cough were much more common and could have devastating consequences, sometimes leading to serious disabilities or even death.
Wow, I didn't realize they were that serious. I've heard of polio, but I don't really know much about it.  And honestly, some of the other diseases you mentioned, I've never even heard of.

That's actually a testament to how successful vaccines have been.  They've become so effective at preventing these diseases that many people today haven't seen or experienced their impact firsthand.  Because of this success, sometimes we forget how dangerous these diseases used to be.  Would you be open to learning a bit more about the specific diseases we're vaccinating Lilly against today?
Yeah, I think that would be helpful. I want to make an informed decision.
Absolutely.  Let's start with measles.  It's highly contagious and can cause a rash, fever, and in some cases, serious complications like pneumonia, brain damage, or even death.
That sounds scary.

It is. And before the measles vaccine, it was a very common childhood illness.  Polio, which you mentioned, is another example. It can cause paralysis and was a major public health crisis in the past.  These are just two examples, and each vaccine protects against a disease with its own set of risks.
So, the vaccines are meant to prevent those kinds of serious illnesses?
Exactly. They work by helping Lilly's immune system develop antibodies to fight these diseases without her having to actually get sick.  It's a way to build immunity safely.
I see.  I guess I hadn't really thought about it that way. I was so focused on the potential risks of the vaccines themselves.

That's understandable. It’s important to discuss those risks too.  Vaccines, like any medication, can have side effects.  Most are mild, like soreness at the injection site or a low-grade fever.  Serious side effects are very rare.  We can talk more about those if
So, it sounds like your goal is to enjoy the things you like, but in a healthier way, by cutting back rather than giving them up entirely?
Yeah, I think so.
Okay.  This feels really important to you, right?  You mentioned wanting to be healthier and more active, like your friends.
Definitely.
On a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is 'not at all confident' and 10 is 'completely confident,' how confident are you *right now* about starting this new approach?
Right now, probably a six.
A six. Okay. What makes it a six and not lower, say a three or a four?
Because I've been thinking about this for years. It's something I've wanted for a long time.
That makes sense. So, what's holding you back from a higher number, like an eight or nine? What makes you think it might drop when you get home?
Well, when I'm around the food, it's just harder.  The temptation is there.
I understand. So, it sounds like the environment plays a big role. Let's explore that a bit. What kind of support or changes in your environment might make it easier to stick to your goals?
Hmm, I'm not sure. Maybe having healthier options readily available?
That's a great idea.  So, if you had healthier, readily available options, that would boost your confidence?  How much would that move you up the scale, do you think?
Probably to an eight, maybe even a nine.
That's significant! So, let's focus on that for a moment.  What are some specific, concrete steps you could take to make those healthier options more readily available?
I could maybe meal prep more, or talk to my family about buying different foods.
Excellent! Those are actionable steps.  Which one feels more doable right now, or which one would you like to explore first?
Meal prepping, I think.  That feels like something I can control.
Great. So, let's talk about meal prepping. What kind of meals would be helpful to have prepped?  What would make it easier and more enjoyable?
Maybe some salads, and some pre-portioned meals for dinner.
Fantastic.  So, salads and pre-portioned meals. What ingredients would you need for those?  And when would you have time to do the prepping?
I could probably do it on Sunday afternoons.  And I'd need, like, lots of veggies, some lean protein...

Sounds like you're already thinking this through.  So, Sunday afternoon for prep, focusing on veggies, lean protein, and pre-portioned meals.  How confident are you that you could make that happen this week?
Pretty confident, maybe a seven or eight.
That's wonderful! You've moved your confidence up just by talking through some concrete steps. What else could we explore that might further boost your confidence and help you achieve your goal?
I guess I could also look for some healthy recipes online.

Excellent idea! That could add variety and make the meal prepping even more appealing. So, you've identified meal prepping, talking to your family about healthier food choices, and finding new recipes.  You've already taken some big steps just by exploring these ideas. What feels like the most important step to focus on first?
Definitely the meal prepping.
Okay, meal prepping it is. Let's delve into the specifics of that a little more. What resources do you have available, and what might you need to get started?
I have containers, and I can go grocery shopping...

Hi Rick, it's good to see you again.  We've talked before about your living situation with Tristan and how it relates to the goals you're working towards.  I'd like to explore that a bit more today.  Could you tell me about some of the advantages and disadvantages of staying where you are?
Well, the place is great.  It's close to work, and Tristan's a good mate.
That makes sense.  It sounds like there are some real positives.  Thinking about the changes you're hoping to make, how do you see your current living situation supporting those changes?
That's the tricky part, isn't it? I'm not sure if it's the ideal environment for me to make these changes.
I hear you.  It sounds like you're weighing things up.  You mentioned Tristan being a good mate.
Yeah, he is. But we're at different stages of life now.  He doesn't have the same responsibilities I do, and I can't expect him to change his lifestyle just because I want to change mine.
That's a very insightful point. It sounds like you're recognizing the differences in your current situations.  Have you talked much with Tristan about the changes you're aiming for?
I've mentioned it, and he says he's supportive. But, like I said, he's in a different place. He doesn't have kids.

Right.  So, it sounds like while he's supportive, there might be a gap in understanding due to those different life experiences.  Let's switch gears a bit. You also mentioned considering moving in with your aunt and uncle. What are some of the potential pros and cons of that option?

The food would be amazing! And I know my family would be really supportive.  But I'm also worried about losing my independence.  I'm worried they might take over, you know? I value the freedom I have now.

That's a valid concern.  It sounds like you're balancing the support your family offers with the desire to maintain your autonomy. Because I'm really sick of being overweight.
Mm-hmm.
Not ha-- I just don't like being unhealthy. It doesn't make me feel good, so I'm motivated to change, it's just getting there.

So, to summarize, it's important for you to do this. You're starting to feel sluggish, you're not feeling healthy, and you know that you've got other people in your family watching you, and you want to be a good role model for them to know that this is gonna be just a part of your life, is your exercise. Yet for you, you're struggling just a little with the logistics of when to schedule time for you so it doesn't interfere too much with your family.
Exactly, yeah.
So, knowing this, what do you think you'll do next?

Mm, I'll probably, I don't know, find-- Now, while it's still somewhat okay outside, maybe pick days I'm gonna go for walks or runs, um, maybe look for a gym close to the house so that I know I can go there quickly or maybe that has daycare, um, yeah, maybe I'll just start to look for that, and find ways I can do it first.
That's great. It sounds like you've got some options and leads on how- on how to get that done.
Yeah.
Hi [Client Name], thanks for meeting with me today.  I understand you're feeling frustrated about losing your phone call privileges. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?
Yeah, it's ridiculous. I just want to call my mom, that's all.
I can understand wanting to talk to your mom. It sounds like that connection is really important to you.  So, if I understand correctly, you've lost your call privileges recently.  What led to that?
Some officer is on a power trip or something.  He said something about my bed and my 'attitude'.  It's petty. I just want to talk to my mom.

It sounds like you feel the reasons given weren't justified, and it's definitely frustrating when you feel something important is taken away unfairly.  Help me understand – how has not being able to call your mom been impacting you?
It's just… I talk to her almost every other night.  Now, nothing.  It's been a week.  It's hard.  My dad's birthday is tomorrow, and I really wanted to talk to her about it.

That makes perfect sense.  Your dad's birthday is a big deal, and it's natural to want to share that with your mom.  It sounds like this isn't just about any phone call, but specifically connecting with her, especially given the upcoming birthday. Is that right?
Exactly.  I just wanted to wish my dad a happy birthday with her.

So, it’s not just the call itself, but the connection with your mom, especially with your dad's birthday tomorrow, that's really weighing on you. It sounds like this is more than just a minor inconvenience.
Yeah, exactly.

I've also heard that, up until recently, you've been doing really well here – consistently following the rules and being respectful.  This recent situation seems out of character.  It makes me wonder if there might be something else going on, perhaps related to your upcoming release in three weeks.  Sometimes, big transitions can bring up unexpected feelings. Could that be part of it?
Maybe… I mean, yeah, I'm excited to get out, but also… it's a lot to think about.

Absolutely.  Getting ready to leave can bring a mix of excitement and maybe some anxiety about what's next.  It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed by that.  It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now – the frustration of losing your call privileges, the importance of your dad’s birthday, and the anticipation of your release.  Is there anything you’d like to explore further about any of this?
I just want to call my mom.
I understand.  Let's talk about that.  What are some possible ways we could work towards getting you back on track with your phone calls, especially with your dad’s birthday being so soon?

Hi Sal, thanks for coming in. I understand your asthma has been really difficult lately, and we need to find some ways to manage it so you can stay healthy and avoid future hospital visits. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?
Yeah, I definitely don't want to be back here. But the doctor said Oscar, my dog, might be connected to my asthma. It's ridiculous, I've had him for 12 years and he's never been a problem before.

I hear your surprise. It's understandable to feel that way when something you've had for so long suddenly becomes a concern. You've probably seen some of the information we provide about managing asthma, and how pets can sometimes play a role.  What are your thoughts on that information?
Yeah, I've seen it. I even read it.  Honestly, all I've been focusing on is taking the medicine. I haven't really looked into all the other stuff.

Thanks for being honest about that. I appreciate you sharing that with me. It sounds like you've been primarily focused on the medication, which is important, but there might be other pieces to the puzzle we haven't explored yet.  Tell me more about what you understand about the connection between pets and asthma.
Well, I don't really get it. I've had Oscar for 12 years. Why is it a problem now?

That's a valid question.  It's not uncommon for things to change over time, even with long-term companions like Oscar. Sometimes sensitivities can develop, or existing ones can worsen.  What has your experience been with your asthma over the past year or so?
It's definitely been getting worse.  I've had to use my inhaler more, and the attacks have been pretty scary.

That sounds really tough, Sal.  It’s concerning that your asthma has been worsening, especially with those recent attacks.  I also know you have a young baby, John Carlo, and that you're very committed to his well-being. How does your asthma impact your ability to be the kind of parent you want to be?
It's hard. Sometimes I'm so short of breath I can't even play with him.  That's why I want to get this under control.

It sounds like being able to be fully present for John Carlo is a big motivator for you.  So, thinking about that, and also considering your own health and the increasing severity of your asthma, what are your thoughts about exploring all the potential factors that could be contributing to it, including the possibility of Oscar playing a role?
I guess… I just really love that dog. He's part of the family.

I understand.  It's clear how much Oscar means to you. It's a big decision, and it's okay to feel conflicted about it.  Let's explore this a little more.  What are some of the things you've considered regarding Oscar and your asthma?
I don't know… I guess I could try more cleaning, maybe get an air purifier?

Those are some good ideas.  Sometimes those strategies can make a difference.  We can definitely talk about some options and resources for managing pet-related allergies.  In the meantime, given how severe your asthma attacks have been, it’s also important to consider all the options, even the difficult ones, to ensure your health and well-being. Would you be open to discussing some of those other options as well?
I… I don't know.  It's just hard to think about.

Of course it's hard. It's a significant decision.  No one is asking you to make any decisions right now.  Let's just talk openly about the possibilities, the pros and cons, and explore all the information so you can make the best choice for yourself and your family.  Would that be okay?
Okay.
Hi Carrie, thanks for coming in today.
Thank you.
What brings you in?
Well, I'm having an ongoing problem with smoking and trying to quit.
So, you'd like to give up cigarettes?
Oh, I've been wanting to for a long time, for years.
So, at this point in your life, why is it so important to quit?

Well, I have a 15-year-old daughter, and she's very much against it. And there are health issues. I'm not getting any younger, and I have asthma and chronic bronchitis, and emphysema. I have a hard time breathing when I exercise, and it's socially unacceptable.
It's like being a leper in a non-leper colony these days.
Exactly.
So, it's really important for you to be a good role model for your daughter, especially at this age when she might decide to smoke.
Right. She's been expressing her feelings. She'll walk in and it's embarrassing for her friends, and in turn, it's embarrassing for me.
So, you want to make her proud, and this would be an added benefit.
Right.
You mentioned several medical problems: asthma, chronic bronchitis, and emphysema. That must be scary.
Thank you.
When were you diagnosed with emphysema?

I'm not sure. I remember when my daughter was five, it was humid, and I have trouble breathing in humidity. I was trying to get air at the window, and my daughter was so frightened she called 911. She thought she was going to lose me.  That was ten years ago. I've tried Chantix, unsuccessfully.
Tell me about your experience with Chantix.
I don't know if it's my lack of willpower, but I had very bad side effects.
What kind of side effects?
Nightmares, nausea, stomach problems, and agitation.
Those are pronounced side effects.  I've heard that some people have success, but others experience significant adverse effects like you described.
Right, and it didn't stop me from smoking.
How long ago was that?
Two or three years ago. I tried it a couple of times. I'd get a refill, thinking I could try again. I had friends it worked for, and they suggested the online support group, but I didn't do that.
So, the online support wasn't a fit for you?
No.
You gave it a good try, but it wasn't a good fit.  You listened to your body – nightmares, nausea, those are serious.
And the agitation.  Being my age, going through menopause, and having a 15-year-old… I don't need extra stress.
So, you're looking for relief, not something that makes you feel worse.
Exactly.
Have there been times in the past when you quit smoking completely?
Only when I was in the hospital.
What's the longest you've gone without a cigarette, including being in the hospital?
Three days.
That's a long time. What did you notice during those three days?
Constant thoughts about smoking, like a chocoholic craving chocolate. The first thing I did when I could smoke was grab any cigarette, any brand.
So, the nicotine is the addiction?
Yes, and the psychological aspect too. I associate cigarettes with coffee, stress…
It sounds like it's paired with many things.
Yes.
Cigarettes can feel like the perfect drug, fulfilling different needs at different times. The downside is the health impact.
Yes.
It can take years off your life.
My aunt used to say, 'Another nail in your coffin.'
What do you think when she says that?
I used to be cocky and say, 'You were my role model, Aunt Kathy. I thought you were so glamorous like in the old movies.' That's what I associated with it then, but now I'm ostracized for it.
It's become harder to be a smoker. People make assumptions.
Yes, and you have to go far to smoke. If you have a short break, you might not even finish your cigarette.
So, it's become very inconvenient as well.
Yes.
Hi Carrie, thanks for coming in today.
Thank you.
