Yes, and you have to go far to smoke. If you have a short break, you might not even finish your cigarette.
So, it's become very inconvenient as well.
Yes.

So, if I understand correctly, the report from Minnesota State, Mankato indicates you were stopped on Stadium Road last Friday, cited for driving under the influence, and then taken to detox.  And you're 20, soon to be 21. Does that sound right?
Yeah, I guess so.  It's kind of fuzzy. It was last week, and I was pretty drunk.
It sounds like a difficult night.  This kind of incident could lead to suspension from the university. How do you feel about that possibility?

Hmm. I mean, not great. But I'm turning 21 in a couple of months.  Once I'm legal, they can't give me a minor anymore. And it's not like I'm a big drinker, not like some of my friends. I just need to be more careful, you know? Not get caught.

It sounds like you're thinking about how to avoid getting caught in the future.  I'm curious, what was going through your mind when you decided to drive after having six beers?  That could have put you and others at serious risk.
Well, I didn't hurt anyone. I did call my roommate for a ride, but he was really tired. I needed to get home somehow.  Honestly, it feels like he's partly to blame. I give him rides all the time.

It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and maybe a little like you were put in a difficult position.  It's understandable to feel that way.  At the same time, it's important to consider the potential consequences of driving under the influence, not just for yourself, but for others too.
Yeah, I get that.  But like I said, I didn't hurt anyone.  So, are we done here? I have class in 15 minutes.

I understand you have to get to class.  Before you go, I want to make sure we're on the same page. The university has expectations for student behavior, and this incident doesn't align with those expectations.  We want to support you in being successful here, and that includes following the rules.  Do you see yourself being able to do that?
Look, I like it here. I get what you're saying, and I appreciate you talking to me. I'll think about what you've said.

Okay.  So, the next steps are that you'll be placed on university disciplinary probation. You'll also need to attend an alcohol education seminar, which has a $150 fee.  It's important to know that further violations could result in a more serious consequence, like suspension.
$150? Seriously?  That's a lot of money. I don't know if I can afford that.

That's understandable.  Let's talk more about that fee and explore some options. We can discuss payment plans or other resources that might be available to you.  It's important that you complete the seminar, so let's work together to figure out a way to make that happen.
Okay, David. So, you've had a rinse. How are you feeling?
Pretty good.
Would you like to take a look at the results?
Yeah, sure.
What do you think?
Oh, that looks really nice.
Yeah.
You got rid of that discoloration that was there.
Yeah, completely.
I like it.
Excellent. It went well. I did notice quite a bit of staining, actually. I'm wondering what you think might be contributing to that.
Well, the usual suspects: smoking, wine, coffee – all of the above.
Yeah.
All of them.
Have you given any thought to quitting smoking at this point?
Yeah, I've thought about it.  It's just… I hear it from everyone. I've tried before, and it didn't work. I get the lecture all the time.
So, it's like here I am, one more person, the next doctor saying, 'You need to quit smoking, David.'
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
And I'm sorry, that's not how I mean to come across at all.
Yeah, I know. I'm not an idiot. I know smokers are seen as… 'How can you still smoke?' It's just not that easy to quit.
I understand. If it was as easy as doctors or your partner make it sound…
Yeah.
…saying you have to quit…
Who wouldn't do it? You'd have to be a real fool not to do it if you thought it was going to be that simple.
Yeah.
I just hear it every day.
Yeah. Tell me a little bit about your past experiences with smoking.  How long have you smoked, and what role does it play in your life?
I've smoked for 40 years, since I was 14. I quit a couple of times, off and on in my 20s, but it's been pretty consistent. I can't see myself changing now.
Mm-hmm.
No matter what kind of talk I get or what new methods they come up with.
It sounds like you've tried a lot of things, and it's not something you're currently interested in pursuing.
No.
Yeah.  I understand. It sounds like you believe cold turkey is the only thing that works for people who have successfully quit.
Mm-hmm.
And that's what worked for people you know.
Yeah, and then they fight the cravings. But it's my choice.
Mm-hmm.  And it really is your choice. You're absolutely right; nobody has the right to tell you what to do.
Yeah.
Can I ask, though?  If there were a situation where you decided, 'I must quit,' what would that situation be?
Hard to say, because I already had open-heart surgery. That didn't do it.  And prostate cancer; that didn't do it either.
Right.
I don't know. I really don't want to quit.
So, this is something you pretty much see yourself doing for quite a while?
Yeah, quite a while.

Yeah. Okay. Well, I really appreciate you being willing to even talk about it. I understand that right now, this isn't something you want to pursue. Would it be alright if I brought it up again at our next visit? I know you said you don't want a lecture, but I am concerned.
Okay, yeah. I'm always open to listening.
As long as I don't talk too much?
Yeah. I'm open to hearing about options.
Okay.  David, honestly, wherever you're at with this, we'll work with it.
Okay.
Thanks for taking a few minutes to talk about smoking.
Thanks, doc.
Okay.
Okay.
Hi, David. How are you doing today?
Hmm, pretty good.
That's good to hear. I wanted to touch base about something I noticed during your rinse—you had some noticeable staining. Any thoughts on what might be contributing to that?
Mm, well, the usual: smoking, wine, coffee.  Probably all of them, I guess.
So, you're aware of some of the things that could be playing a role. Have you given any thought to quitting smoking, or is that something on your radar at all right now?
Yeah, I've thought about it. But honestly, it's just not something I'm interested in.  I hear it from everyone, and I've tried before—it didn't work. I get the 'you should quit' speech all the time.

It sounds like you've had a lot of people telling you what to do, and that can get old pretty quickly. I'm definitely not here to lecture you, David. I'm just curious about your past experiences with trying to quit.
I've smoked for 40 years, since I was 14. I quit a couple of times in my 20s, but it's been pretty consistent since then. I just don't see myself changing now, no matter what anyone says.
So, you've tried quitting before, and it hasn't really stuck. That can be really frustrating. What do you think made it so difficult to quit when you tried in the past?

I don't know. It's just such a part of my life, I guess.  I've had open-heart surgery, prostate cancer—you'd think *that* would have been enough to make me quit, but it wasn't. I just don't see it happening.

It sounds like you've been through a lot, and smoking has been a constant in your life through it all. I hear you saying that right now, quitting doesn't feel like something you're ready to take on. Is that a fair summary?
Yeah, that's about right. I know it's not the best thing for me, but I just don't see myself quitting anytime soon.

And that's perfectly okay, David.  This is your journey, and you're the one who gets to decide what's right for you. I'm just here to support you, wherever you're at in that process. If you ever *do* decide to make a change, I'd be happy to help in any way I can.
I appreciate that. I don't like lectures, but I'm always open to listening.

Understood. I'll definitely keep that in mind. Would it be alright if we checked in about this again sometime in the future?  No pressure at all—just to see where you're at and if there's anything I can do to support you.
Yeah, that's fine. I don't mind talking about it as long as it's not a lecture.

[chuckles] You got it—no lectures, I promise. I'll make sure to keep our conversations, well, conversational. Thanks for being open to talking about this, David. I know it's not always an easy topic to discuss.
Thanks, doc. I appreciate it.
Absolutely. And remember, wherever you're at with this, we'll work with it. You're in the driver's seat here.
Okay. Sounds good.
Alright, David. Thanks for taking the time to chat today. Let's connect again soon.
Thanks, doc. See you next time.
Hi, Natalie. I'm Dawn.
Hi, Dawn. Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you too. Thanks for coming in today.
Thanks for having me.
Tell me a little about yourself.

So, I'm 28, and I moved to Arizona about six months ago. I really enjoy spending time with my family and friends when I can. Work keeps me pretty busy. But I'm really looking to make some changes to my diet and physical activity. I'm not happy with where my weight is right now, so I thought it would be good to come and talk with you about some of that.
So, you're feeling a little dissatisfied with your current health habits?

Yeah. I'm starting to notice I feel more sluggish, and just not… My mood has shifted a lot too, which at first I thought was because it's getting colder outside. But I also think it might be related to my activity level, or lack thereof, and the foods I'm eating.
Okay, so you're experiencing some low energy, and you know from past experience that when you're more active and eating differently, you have more energy?
Right. Yeah. Especially when I'm more active, I notice the biggest change in energy and mood.
Tell me more about those previous times when you were active.

Well, I played sports in college, so that kept me pretty busy, and that was really fun. I think back now to how much I would cram into a 24-hour period and wonder how I did it. But I think part of it was because I was so physically active. I just had way more energy throughout the day, mentally and physically, to go to school full-time, socialize with friends, and do everything. So, when I think back to what was probably the peak of my life, when I felt my best physically and mentally, it was during that time.
You had tons of energy, like the Energizer Bunny, just going and going.

Yeah, exactly. And now it's not the same. When I get home from work, I'm exhausted. It takes a lot for me to want to be physically active when I've spent all day staring at a computer, thinking and working. That's probably been my biggest issue: when work ends, I just go home and don't really do anything. Just trying to unwind by watching Netflix or something.
So, your days are just as full now that you're working, but your energy level isn't what it used to be. Do you have any ideas why that might have changed?

Well, I think part of it is that when I was in college, it wasn't really optional. I *had* to go to practice, or I *had* to do those things because that was, in a sense, my job that was paying for school. Now, there's not that same commitment to other people or to scholarship money. So that's definitely shifted. But I do feel an urgency to do it; it just seems like the missing step is actually going to a gym or somewhere to be more active. I think I *want* to; it's just the *doing* it that doesn't seem to happen.

Right. So, in the past, it wasn't up to you whether you were physically active. Now it is, and you're looking back and saying, 'I want to do things differently. I want to be more physically active than I've been.'
Mm-hmm. Yeah, I think so. Not that I want to run a marathon, but I do think it would help me a lot just to have a better outlook on life and more energy if I were to pick up some type of activity.
Great. And you've noticed that exercise has a mood-enhancing effect.
Mm-hmm.
Tell me more about that. What specifically do you notice about your mood on days when you're physically active?

I'm just happier and more upbeat, and I think even my outlook is more positive. If I'm sitting in traffic and I haven't been physically active, I'll probably grumble about it. But if I'm sitting in traffic and I *have* been active, it's like I have a different perspective. I already feel like I've accomplished something that day. It just has a ripple effect into the rest of my day, making me more productive.
Yeah, you feel more accomplished and less bothered by the little things.
Mm-hmm. Yeah, exactly.

Okay, let me see if I've got this. You moved to Arizona six months ago, and you're trying to establish new routines. You're reflecting on the past few years, and you realize that in college, you were very active because you were an athlete. Now, it's up to you to choose physical activity, and you're realizing that not being active has affected your energy level and your mood. You're looking for more of both of those things: energy and a mood boost.

Yeah. And also, as I mentioned, I'm not totally happy with my weight. I'm hoping that increased activity would have some impact there and maybe help me. If my activity level improves, then my nutrition might also improve along with it.
Tell me more about your weight concerns. When did you start feeling dissatisfied with your body?

Probably about three or four months ago. My clothes started fitting tighter, which wasn't comfortable. And I'm just not happy with my appearance, which has never really been an issue before. I've usually been pretty okay with that, but in the last few months, I've had a more negative outlook on it.

Mm-hmm. So, it sounds like a bit of a cycle, and maybe the lack of physical activity has contributed to you feeling less confident. I wonder if that's also part of the picture, since you mentioned that's been a big difference from the past.
Yeah, I think the activity piece, and also the foods I'm eating, aren't that great.  That also affects how I feel about my appearance.
Okay. So, you had strong self-confidence and a positive body image until a few months ago, and you're hoping to get back to that place where you feel good about yourself.
Mm-hmm. Yeah.
Great.
Barbara Roberts?
Yes. Good morning.
Good morning. I'm Dr. Betty, one of the new GPs here. What would you prefer to be called?
Barbara is fine, thank you.
Okay, Barbara. I understand you usually see Dr. Brown?
Yes, he's my doctor.
What brings you in to see me today?
I've been having terrible trouble with my stomach, and Dr. Brown hasn't been able to figure it out. I was hoping you might be able to help.
I see. Tell me more about these stomach problems.

Well, I have almost constant discomfort. I often feel bloated. I swing between constipation and diarrhea. I get cramping, sometimes it's a stabbing pain. I frequently have the urge to go to the toilet, and I pass very smelly gas.
That sounds like quite a few troublesome symptoms.
Yes.
How long has this been going on?
I can trace it back to a holiday in Egypt about four years ago. I had a horrible bout of sickness and diarrhea, and my stomach hasn't been right since.
So, you think it started about four years ago after that trip?
Yes.
What treatments have you tried?
Dr. Brown gave me muscle relaxants initially. I've also been to a health shop, and they've been very helpful, giving me various tablets and medicines for different symptoms. Oh, and I use Immodium.
So, you're taking different herbal tablets depending on your symptoms?
Yes, because the problems aren't the same every day.
So, you decide day-to-day what to take based on how your stomach feels?
Yes.
Have you had any tests done?
Yes, early on I had a… gastroscopy, I think it was called.
The one where they put a tube down your throat?
Yes. And I also had a barium enema, which was very uncomfortable.
I see. And what were the results?
They didn't find anything.  I don't think he's done enough tests. He said they didn't find anything and hasn't sent me for any more. He just sent me back to my regular doctor.
It sounds like you're not happy with that.

Well, I think the NHS is running out of money, and he's decided I've had enough tests. If you go online, there are loads more tests he could have done. If I had more money, I'd go private. I just don't think he's gotten to the bottom of it.
So, you feel like not enough tests have been done?
No, there are many more he could do, I'm sure.

Let me summarize: You've had these problems for about four years, with various stomach symptoms. You've tried prescribed and herbal remedies, and you've had some tests, but you feel they haven't been thorough enough.
Yes, that's right.
How is this affecting your day-to-day life?

It's had a big impact. I went from full-time to part-time at work because I couldn't sit comfortably all day. Eventually, about a year ago, I stopped working altogether. I miss it. I miss my friends from work. We used to go out at least once a week. I also used to go to a exercise class, which I miss. But I wasn't comfortable doing the exercise; I was always worried I'd need to use the restroom. My husband and I used to go out for meals, but we don't do that anymore.
It sounds like your life has changed significantly because of these symptoms.
Yes.
What does a typical day look like for you now?
I potter around the house. I probably watch too much daytime television. I read a bit, but mostly I'm at home.
Have there been times in the last four years when your symptoms were better?

Last year, my son got married. I was worried I wouldn't be able to cope, but surprisingly, I felt great for about three weeks in the summer, leading up to the wedding and the wedding itself. I hardly noticed my stomach problems then.
That's interesting. Are there times when your symptoms are worse?
I'm having a bad patch at the moment. It's particularly uncomfortable. I notice it's worse when my husband is away; he travels for work a couple of times a month.
So, it's worse when he's away?
Yes. Maybe I think about it more then, I don't know.
What has Dr. Brown said about what he thinks is wrong?
He thinks it's all in my head, that it's stress.
And what do you think?
It can't all be in my head. I have too much physical pain. It's real pain.
Have you had any thoughts about what might be causing it?

I thought it might be an infection that didn't clear up. Sometimes I think it's IBS, like a friend of mine has. Other times, I wonder if it's an ulcer. On bad days, I worry it's cancer. My mother-in-law died of cancer; the doctor didn't investigate a growth until it was too late. So, I check myself at night to make sure nothing is changing.
So, you check yourself regularly?
Yes, to make sure nothing is changing.

Let me summarize: You've seen Dr. Brown for a few years, tried various medications (prescribed and herbal) with no real difference. You've had some tests, but you feel they weren't enough. You sometimes worry it's something serious, like cancer.
Yes.
What were you hoping I could do for you today?
Since you're a new doctor, I wondered if you might have a fresh perspective. Maybe you know about new tests that my doctor doesn't. I was hoping you could send me for some different tests.
So, you were hoping I'd order more tests?
Yes, I think there must be a test that would reveal something.

I understand.  However, given your history and the tests you've already had, I'm not sure more tests are the best approach right now. You've had some of the main investigations, and your symptoms haven't changed much.  More tests might not show anything different.  It could be a waste of time.
So, you think it's all in my head too, like Dr. Brown?

No. You clearly have pain and physical symptoms that are affecting your life. But I think these things aren't always just physical or just mental. Sometimes they're connected. You mentioned that at your son's wedding, when you were busy and happy, your symptoms lessened. And when your husband is away, which you don't like, they seem worse. I wonder if there's a link between how you feel emotionally and what's happening in your life, and how much your symptoms bother you. Is that possible?
I can't see how my mind could cause this much pain.

I'm not saying the pain is *just* in your mind. But sometimes how we feel and what's happening in our lives can affect how we experience symptoms. Since medications and tests haven't helped, I wonder if a different approach might be better.
What kind of approach?
Thinking about other areas of your life.  Over the last four years, your life seems to have become much smaller. You're not doing many of the things you used to enjoy.
I can't do them anymore.
You've stopped doing them because you felt you couldn't, but I wonder if not doing those pleasurable things has contributed to you feeling unhappy, which could then make your symptoms worse.
I don't know.

I wonder if focusing on what you do with your day and bringing back some of those pleasurable activities, even something small like meeting friends, might improve your overall quality of life.  I'm also thinking about the tablets you're taking.  You're taking quite a few, and I wonder if we could review them and see which are helpful, which aren't doing anything, and which might even

Hi Sarah, it's great to meet you. My name is Delwyn, and I'm a counselor here at the clinic. I understand from your nurse practitioner that during your recent annual exam, the topics of smoking and alcohol use came up. Would you mind telling me a little bit about that?

Yeah, um, last week I met with my nurse practitioner, and she's concerned about how much I'm smoking and drinking. I agreed to work on the smoking and try to cut back. But, regarding the drinking, I don't really think I drink that much.
So, you've decided you want to cut back on your smoking a little, but you're not really concerned about your drinking.
Right, I mean, I don't drink that much, and honestly, it's just a good way to relax.
It's a nice form of stress relief.
Yeah, exactly. It's like that 'me time' at the end of the day.
A sort of escape from your hectic schedule.

Yeah. I have a two-year-old son, and I work full-time. I also started going back to school. So, I'm trying to juggle everything. It's tiring, and at the end of the day, I just want to relax and enjoy myself.
So, you're working, and on top of that, juggling being a single mom and going to school?
Yeah, and for work, I'm a server. I'm on my feet all day, and it's really tiring.
It's pretty exhausting work.
Yeah, it's hard trying to please customers all day. And I'm worrying about making enough money to support my son.
So, you're not only doing really tiring work and going to school, but you're also worrying about your finances.
Yeah, and with going back to school, I have to figure out how I'm going to pay for everything. It's a lot right now.
It does sound like a lot you're trying to deal with. It makes sense that you feel like you need some kind of break or reward.
Mm-hmm.
Tell me a little more about your drinking. How much are you drinking, what's the pattern, and what raised concern?
That's the thing. I don't understand what raised concern. I don't drink that much. I've gone up to maybe two drinks a day, max.
So, you're drinking perhaps two drinks a day. What have you heard about the recommendations for drinking levels?
Not much.
Would you be interested in hearing about those recommendations?
Sure.

The recommendation for women is no more than three drinks a day, and no more than seven drinks over a week. The reason for those recommendations is to reduce the risk of accidents or chronic diseases like certain cancers, high blood pressure, and psychological problems. What do you think about all that?
It surprises me because two drinks a day doesn't seem like a problem or risky. I have family members who drink a lot more than that per day, and it's not a problem for them.
It just doesn't seem that abnormal to you, especially compared to your family.

No. I'm getting kind of annoyed, honestly. I agreed to work on my smoking, but with this drinking thing, it's like everything I enjoy is being taken away. If I give up drinking, what will I have to enjoy myself?
You really feel like you need that reward.
Yeah.
It also sounds like your drinking has perhaps increased a little over time?

Yeah, I guess it has. Probably just from being so stressed. I'm in my second semester of school, and that's adding to everything. I'm trying to figure out childcare. My mom usually watches my son, but lately, she can't always. I'm always worrying. It's stressful.
So, it sounds like the more stressed you feel, the more you're drinking.
Yeah, I guess that's right.

Let me summarize. You have a hectic, stressful life, and you feel like you need some kind of reward or stress relief. You've noticed your drinking has increased, and the more stressed you feel, the more you're inclined to drink.
Yeah.
Have you noticed any problems from your drinking?

No. The one thing is, there are evenings when I want to get my son to bed a little earlier so I can have alone time to unwind, maybe smoke, have a couple of drinks. I feel guilty about that sometimes because I should enjoy spending time with my son, but I just want to be by myself and relax.
So, you've noticed it's starting to call to you in the evenings.
Yeah.
It's perhaps taking you away from things that are more important to you?
Yeah.
And it doesn't feel good?
No.
It sounds like there's a dilemma there. It's not the occasional drink that's the issue. It's the quantity and whether your drinking is escalating and interfering with things that are more important.
Yeah.
You've perhaps never seen it that way before.
No. It's hard to take in. I've never thought about it like this. I feel worried.
It seems like it would be a hard pattern to change.

Yeah. It's part of my routine. I don't want to sacrifice something I enjoy, but I'm trying to be a good mom. I'm trying to go back to school. I'm trying to work. I don't know how I can do all that if I don't have a way to enjoy myself or relax.
It seems like it would be difficult to change because it's important to you right now.
Yeah.
But there are things you value that you don't want the drinking to interfere with.
Yeah.
Have you thought about other ways to cope with stress without relying on drinking so much?
If there was some way to relieve my stress, I'd feel better, and maybe at night, I wouldn't feel like I had to unwind the same way.
If you could tackle some of these stressful issues, that could make a difference. What would that be, for example?

My biggest problem is childcare. My mom usually watches my son, but she's been backing out lately. I'm worrying about having to call in sick to work or missing class. Worrying about that really stresses me out.
So, having more reliable childcare could make a big difference.
Yeah, definitely.
It sounds like your mom has been an option, but perhaps not so much anymore.
Yeah. She watches him so much. I think she's just getting stressed too. I feel bad because it's not her son, but I need something reliable.
One thing that could make a big difference is if you could figure out more reliable, affordable childcare. That would help you not want to drink as much.
Yeah.
Anything else?
Most of my problems go back to money. If I had more money, I could afford daycare, I could work less hours. It's usually related to money.

Money could make a big difference. You are working full-time and going to school to address that long-term. You have other ideas of how you might cope with stress better. Given our conversation, where are you with everything?

We started talking about how your drinking has drifted into a risky area, and it would be advisable to cut back. You feel like that's important to you and not something you want to do. We've talked about ways that could be made easier, but I'm not sure if you're ready to tackle that. Where are you?
I'm ready to consider changing my drinking, but as far as actually doing it, I don't know. I have a lot of problems I'm trying to work out.
It would be helpful if you could narrow it down to one thing. What would that be?
Childcare, probably.
It sounds like that keeps coming up as a main issue. There may be some resources I can point you towards. Have you looked into alternatives, more affordable, reliable childcare?
Not really. I just usually see if my mom can watch my son, so I haven't really looked around.
One thing you could consider is talking to one of our social workers. They specialize in helping people identify resources they
Pretty good. It's been three months now.
Nice.
Um, and—
Since the-- since you used, uh-- since the last time you used meth, right?
Right.
Okay.
Right. It's been three months, and I've been doing pretty well.
Good.
Um, and I met a couple new friends.
Nice.
So—
So-so, uh, have-- last time we talked, you know, you were kind of cutting the-the ex-boyfriend out. This is because he was your dealer, so--
Right.
And how is that going for you?
Right. It's been good. I haven't answered the phone when he's called-
Okay.

-and a couple of my other friends have tried to call me as well, and I haven't answered the phone. Um, so it's been good for me to just reach out and like, meet a couple of new people, um, in the neigh-neighborhood that I'm living in.
So it sounds like you've made some good changes. The change in your environment, and some of your behaviors, and, uh, and these new friends.

Yeah, the new friends, and I've been using the, you know, the breathing exercises you taught me, when I get-- start to feel a little stressed out, and I've been- I've been using those and it helps me. I go for a walk and do my breathing exercises, and it calms me down and kind of gets me through that time.
So it sounds like--
So, thank you for coming in today.
Yes.
How are you feeling today?
I feel great actually.
Yeah? Good.
Yeah.
Good.
I feel good.
And so you did your clarifications, value clarifications-
Yeah.
-and What are your top five?

Yes. It was a good experience for me. It was different. It was different than usual. There were several things that were different, and the number one value that I put was self-respect. And I-I don't even know if self-respect has ever been in my top five let alone my number one.
Really?
Yeah. And, um—
Do you have any idea why that is?

I do have an idea, I think, why that is. Um, I think that there's been a few things that have happened recently and something that really came to my awareness, when I visited with my family, is that I have consistently through my whole life, probably, put other people first. And I have consistently, uh, almost not even considered myself in the equation. It was kind of sad in a way, at the time that I realized it. Uh, I didn't realize how severe it actually was, but I was kind of glad that I realized it because I feel like it's never too late to change-
True.
-and I feel like I can- I can, uh, respect and value myself just as much as I have other people. I know that's important. And I feel like when I do that, I'm a better person for other people as well.
Mm-hmm. By not putting yourself on the back burner so much?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Because I get stressed, I get resentful, I get overwhelmed and, uh, out of- out of alignment, I guess, out of sorts.
Mm-hmm.
And I can't be the best- the best me possible.
For someone else?
Yeah.
For your family?
For myself or for someone else, either way, yeah.

You think it is so much of a fact that you put yourself on the back burner that you were neglecting yourself, or that you were putting others so much before you that you just didn't even think about yourself?

I-it's almost-- Like, I think that some people might not even think that I put that first, but in my mind and my emotions, I was carrying concern about what other people think, and I was letting that concern dictate my actions. Instead of letting my own values dictate my actions, I was letting what I thought other people wanted me to do to dictate my actions.
Wow.
And that's something that I had done for so long, literally since I was a child, that I didn't even know I was doing it.
There's so much of your-- Part of your paradigm?
Yes, yes.
So, do you think sometimes you weren't even aware

Not aware at all. Completely unaware. Totally unaware, yeah. And so to me, I feel like it's a celebration. I used to, uh, moan and complain about my childhood and about all the things that I didn't get to have, and all the cruel, mean things that people said and did, and I felt-- I feel like I had this aha moment where I realized that I could be my own parent, and I could give myself the things that weren't given to me, now. I can give myself a voice. I can give myself an opinion. I can live like that, if I want to. Nobody's stopping me from it, only me.
Yeah.
So, that's what I want to do.
Mm-hmm.And it's the first time in my life I haven't felt guilty for saying that.
The very first time that you can remember?
I would say so, yeah. I don't know if I've ever said that in front of people and not felt the least twinge of guilt for it. [chuckles]
That's not a selfish thing.
No-
Right.
-it's not, it's really not.
Cool, that's great.
Yeah.
Yeah. And so you felt you came about this change, and-and-and how does it make you feel?

Well, it makes me feel jubilant. It makes me feel joyful. It makes me feel hopeful. It makes me feel like I count, like I matter. Uh, it makes me feel like I'm going to be able to do what I want to do with more joy and more passion, and less dread and a sense of responsibility, because one of the things that kind of happened along the way I really didn't notice, is that, um-- Like, let's say for example I like being a teacher or I like being a teacher or I like being a counselor to a certain degree but because of all the shoulds and all of the sense of responsibility and all of the caring about what people think, I started to lose joy doing things I actually enjoy doing.
Because you're- felt so obligated.

Yes, because it turned into an obligation instead of just really really a sense of like you know passion you know. My passion is gone completely. I don't know I'm just happy to, I feel like I got back in touch with myself. It's like I was like lost for a while and now I'm like back again, yes, now I remember why I wanted to do this or like why this is important to me because it is actually one of my values to be and help, but it just has to be, uh, balanced.
Yeah, is that on your top five also
No, but um, the other ones I have on there, uh are, number two, inner harmony. For the same reason, like I feel like I need to harmonious within myself before I can be harmonious with other people.
You get peace with yourself?
Yes, and then I put family happiness.
That's very good.
Yes, because I think that when I'm at peace with myself, uh, that automatically contributes to my family happiness. When I am unhappy with myself, I bring my unhappiness to my family.
Sure.
Uh, yeah, when I don't have self-respect and I am only giving my family a say on who I am and what I should do, I'm angry at them, I quarrel them.
You feel resentful.

I resent them, I really do, when I am in the mode. But when I just say, 'Hey, I'm a person of this family and I deserve this much time and energy and attention and just more than anybody else,' I don't care, you do what I do I do what I do life goes on [chuckles].
Right.

And then I have health and achievement, and to me, this one on achievement says a sense of accomplishment and to me that kind of goes along with what we were talking about earlier like I think I can show up and be a teacher and be a counselor in many different, uh, capacities. I could be your- I could be- I could be a teacher and I could be a really bad teacher. I could still be a teacher you know, I could show up an I could just do a really poor job and I could go home and I probably could keep my job for a while, it wouldn't be the first time right?
Right.
But I don't feel good about that.
You don't feel fulfilled.
No.
Like you've done anything helpful.
Right, right.
It's because you showed up and you gave out

It's not enough for me to just show up and get my paycheck. That doesn't, I don't feel fulfilled so it-it, that's the way I see it going together with the helping. It's not just about helping to like look good or to exhaust myself or do what I think I should do but to really give something needy, something substantive, something real.
Meaningful.
Yeah, meaningful, even if it's-it's small.
Sometimes it's the small things that really count, too.
Yeah.
So all of these things put together feel like right now at this point in life, that it is really healthy change for you, like where you
Utterance_text

I don't know, I'm just having a lot of hard trouble trying to lose the rest of the weight. Um, right now, it's like no matter how much I try to exercise, run, or whatever, it doesn't matter like nothing else is coming off.
Right, so you've hit a plateau in your weight and despite all the things that you're trying to do to increase your activity, it doesn't seem to be working on the scale?
No, and I don't know what I'm doing wrong because I keep trying the exercise but nothing's happening.
Right. So you feel like you're spinning your wheels, you're doing more exercising and it's not showing results on the scale?
Yes.
And you're not feeling so good about that?

No, and even when I'm coming home, like, I'll go to the gym and then I'm noticing nothing is happening and I'll come home and I try to talk to my mama about it or even my father, and no one even cares about it. Like no one wants to support in it anyway.
Uh, so you feel like you're doing this all alone?
Yes.
At home or you think that they'll be supportive but they're not giving- they're not giving you what you need?
No, and specifically my father, he just-- Not only does he not want to support me with it but at the same time, he feels like I need to be gaining my weight back.
Oh, okay.
So I—
Tell me about that.

It's as though by me losing weight, it's like I'm somehow disconnecting from my family, and he thinks that I'm trying to form myself to fit into like this perfect American picture and I just want to be healthy, I just want to have a good body and he doesn't think of it that way.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Tanya, thanks for meeting with me today.  Let's talk about something you'd like to change, something you might be feeling ambivalent about.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Well, I have a lot of anxiety, especially about this big test I have to take. I've been putting it off because I get so anxious and I don't trust myself to do well. It's always on my mind, and I know I need to just do it, but the anxiety stops me. I just don't want to feel this way anymore.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, this anxiety is a real obstacle, and it sounds like you're not confident you can manage it and succeed on the exam.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah, exactly.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, avoiding it feels easier.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Definitely.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being not at all confident and 10 being very confident, how confident are you that you can manage your anxiety about this exam?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Maybe a four or five.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay, a four or five. That's not a two or three, so you've got some confidence there.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Right. It's been so long coming, and I still have a ton of anxiety, but I think I'm taking that first step. That's why I'm at a four or five.  It's still scary.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: You mentioned you've actually scheduled the exam this time, after putting it off before.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yes.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: And you've rescheduled it in the past because of anxiety.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yes.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: What's different this time that makes you think you won't reschedule again?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Well, it's just been hanging over me for so long. I need to do it. If I don't pass, I have to wait three months to retake it, which means three more months of studying. If I do pass, it'll be such a weight off my shoulders. I think about it every day, and I'm just sick of it.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, the thought of how good it will feel when it's done is a real motivator.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yes, but then the negative thoughts creep in. You know, with anxiety. I worry about failing, about people asking me how I did, and being embarrassed if I don't pass. That makes me really anxious.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: You want to avoid those feelings that might come up if you don't succeed.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Right.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Tell me about a time in the past when you were anxious about something, you did it anyway, and it turned out well.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: A few years ago, I had to do a recording for work. I was terrified and tried to get out of it.  When I finally played it, it was one of the best recordings I'd ever done. My supervisor and our national consultant were shocked, because of how unconfident I usually seem. I don't really like compliments, they make me anxious too, but it felt good because I really didn't trust myself, and I did a good job.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, that experience boosted your self-confidence, and maybe even changed how others saw you. You liked that feeling.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yes, I did.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: It must have been brave to do something so daunting and be so successful.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: How can you connect that experience to what you're facing now?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: I think it's the same anxiety I have about this test. But if I pass, I could have that same feeling I had with the recording, that feeling of doing a good job. I'd love to have that again.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, you want to create opportunities to have that feeling again.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Right.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: You mentioned feeling proud of yourself.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: To wrap up, you started at a four or five for confidence. What would it take to get you to a seven, to feel more confident?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Well, the test is soon. I think practicing and seeing how I do might help. If I do well on practice tests, my confidence might go up. And maybe just having faith in myself, instead of assuming I'll fail.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, positive self-talk could make a big difference.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, to summarize, you're anxious about this upcoming test, which you've rescheduled before. But this time, you seem more determined to get it done. You've even recalled a past experience where you were anxious but successful, and you felt proud.  It sounds like you're ready to take this exam and remind yourself that you can succeed.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay, Tanya, thank you.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Thank you.
Hi Andrea, thanks for coming in. I'm meeting with all the students to talk about life, goals, and behaviors.
Okay.
Why don't you start by telling me a little about yourself?
My name is Andrea, I'm in the marching band, I play the tenor sax. I'm also in the jazz band and wind ensemble, and I'm an IB student.
Wow, music's a big part of your life. How long have you been playing saxophone?
About four years, but I've been involved in music for about ten years. I started with violin for six years, then clarinet, and then found the saxophone.
That's great. And how long have you been in marching band?
Since freshman year, so three years.
And how do you like it?
It's fun, a lot of work, long summers, but fun. I really like the group setting, working with classmates, and putting on the show. It's exciting, especially at competitions.
That sounds awesome. Do you have a lot of friends in band?
I have two groups, friends from class and friends from band.
Great. Tell me about your family.
I have an older brother, nine years older, my parents, and my dog, a golden retriever named Charlie. He's eight years old.
Nice. What are your plans after high school?
I'm planning on going to school to become a doctor. I'm interested in psychology or psychiatry.
Big dreams. Have you started thinking about schools or majors?
Psychology, maybe. I haven't thought much about schools, everyone wants to go to the Ivy Leagues.
And how are your grades?
Pretty good, high three-point something.
Good. What do you do for fun on weekends?
I usually go out with friends, to the movies or someone's house.
Is there ever alcohol involved?
Sometimes, honestly.
How often do you drink?
It depends on schoolwork. When it's light, maybe every other weekend, or three weekends a month.
So, quite a bit.
A little, yeah.
How much do you drink when you do drink?
We don't get blackout drunk. It's more of a tipsy thing. I have gotten blackout drunk before, but I learned my lesson, didn't like it.
Got it. So you've had some heavy drinking experiences. What's the most you've ever had?
How many drinks?
Yeah.
It was a lot. It was my first time, like three or four cups, but mixed drinks.
So you're not sure how much exactly.
No.
And your friends drink too?
Yes, some of them. Not all.
How much do they typically drink?
More or less the same. Now, the most we'll have is maybe one cup after that one time, sometimes one or two, but they can be strong.
So it's one cup, but not one standard drink.
Right, it's a typical red party cup.
Okay. You're actually drinking quite a lot. It puts you in a high-risk group.
A little bit.
It means there's a higher chance of negative consequences, like car accidents, other accidents, fights, sexual assault, health problems, or alcoholism. Have you thought about these things?
Not too much. Since it's with my small group of friends, and we usually sleep over, I haven't worried about drinking and driving or sexual assault. But I haven't thought about alcoholism.
It's good you're not drinking and driving, but you're still drinking a lot. Let's talk about making some changes. I think you need to stop drinking like this.
Okay.
Do you think you could quit?
Yeah, I think I could. I don't need it. It's just something we do to get the party going.
So, does that mean you're going to stop?
I'd probably start by telling my friends, 'Hey, I don't think I'm going to drink today.'
That doesn't sound very convincing.
It's one thing to control my own drinking, another when everyone else is drinking. There's pressure, like, 'They're going to think I look stupid.'
How are you going to quit without your friends thinking you look stupid?
Yeah.
Are they really good friends if they're going to give you a hard time?
My close friends wouldn't have a problem. But the ones I'm not as close to might ostracize me.
It sounds like you might be better off without them. They're maybe not very good friends.
Probably too judgmental.
I think we should set a goal for you to stop drinking.
Okay.
And I think you should probably stop as soon as possible, like this weekend.
Okay.
We'll set the goal, and you'll come back in a couple of weeks to talk about it and make sure you've stopped. What do you think?
I think it's possible. If I make a good plan, I think I can follow through.
Great. The plan is to quit, and you're going to stop hanging out with the friends who aren't supportive.
Yeah, I think I can do that.

So you're questioning whether it might be useful. It comes down to what works for you. I'd like to work with you  "betrayed." A little  but I know it's true. My friend who does Tai Chi loves it. Maybe it's just not for me.
Right.  as I know Dr. Fields would  to build a plan to help you feel as safe as you can in your home.
What do you think about that?
Absolutely. I'm feeling a little frightened.
Yeah.
What if I fall down and nobody comes around
Yeah  and I'm lying there for two days?
I'm alone.  right.
Yeah.
So…
It really strikes you that you're there alone
I think there are some things that could be done. People who live in residence have a cord they can pull  and this could happen. What thoughts do you have about that?
Yeah  but how do they get to the cord? Is there anything else I could do to communicate if something does happen?
I think I saw something like that on TV. Does it really work?  yeah. What's worked for a lot of people is a lifeline. You wear it around your neck  and if you need help  you push the button.
It does really work.
They sell so much stuff on TV.
Right. There are a couple of different products
Yeah. I'm feeling a little scared.  but it can really help and give you a sense of security.
Mm-hmm.
It's probably a signal to make some changes.
Mm-hmm.
I don't want to go back to the hospital. Do I have to?
We're going to work with you to help you stay home as long as possible and be safe. What do you think that will take? The lifeline is a possibility.
I definitely want to do that.
Mm. What else would it take for you to feel safe?
Maybe a refresher on the things they showed me in the house when I first came home. Maybe support
Mm-hmm.  maybe a buddy  some way to be reminded. I was moving along  and things were feeling more positive  but now it's like two steps forward and three steps back.
Is there support somehow? My daughter calls me
So you'd like a little more support and connection. Would you like some suggestions?  but she lives in Seattle. I don't want to impose on my neighbors or my friends.
Yeah.
We have case management services. Someone comes in and checks with you at home
Yeah  helps you figure out things that need to be done  gives you a refresher on safety at home  and helps you connect with other services. How does that sound?
I was going to say  that would be good. Do you think I should try to go back to the Tai Chi?

Yeah. I guess I've kind of gone to the extreme. I tend to do that. So  I would consider the senior center. I know you were really active there before. I'm wondering if you feel like there's support there. They have a lot of activities.
Yeah. It sounds so crazy  keep moving?
Yeah.  doesn't it? It feels like inside  moving is unsafe.
We know we can't make perfect safety
Really?  but the more you move and the more active you stay  the less likely it is that you're going to fall and the more safe you're going to be.
Yes.
Oh
We can't prevent all of it  okay.
Okay. I'm willing to start again  but we can make it less likely.
Mm-hmm.  so to speak.
Yeah. It's scary.
Yeah. It takes a lot. You're the only one who can know what you're willing to work through that fear for.
I'm willing to work through my fears to be in my little house with my little dog and my little garden. I've been there since my husband and I got married
Mm-hmm. That's a strong enough motivator  and I don't want to give it up yet.
Mr. Johnson?
Yeah?
I'm here to talk to you about your cholesterol and the medicine your doctor prescribed.
I talked with my doctor about my medicine. That's his job.
It's my job too
To be honest  to help you understand how to use your medicine and give you information about getting the most benefits from it.

Your doctor told you that if your cholesterol remains elevated  I'm not even certain I'm going to take the medicine. I know I've got high cholesterol  I've got to get that down  but this medicine can cause severe muscle weakness  and I just can't afford that. I'm a truck driver  and I haul those heavy boxes.
Yeah  you're at risk of stroke or heart attack?
The side effect is very rare  down the line  but…
Right now  it's not really something you need to worry about  and the risk of stroke or heart attack is much worse.
I understand that. But like I said  it's the muscle weakness I'm concerned about. That's the present. I've got to do my job.

Why don't you just give me the medicine? I'll take it home  it's very rare. If you feel some muscle weakness  you'll let your doctor know. It's not permanent. It won't get to the point where it affects your job.
You really need to take it. The muscle weakness is rare. If you feel it  and I'll think about it. I'm worried about my job.
Sure. Fine. Just…  let your doctor know. He can take you off or switch you. It's not permanent.
It's not permanent.
Whatever.
A stroke or heart attack is much worse
Okay  so make sure you pick up your medicine as you're on your way out. One every day to get your cholesterol down.
Okay?  sure. Fine.
Hi Mrs. Smith, my name is Terri, I'm one of the nurses who works with Dr. Fields.
Well, I remember you. Yeah, we met once before.
Yes, I think when you were in last time.
Yeah.
And I know that, uh, Dr. Fields talked with you last time about maybe trying a tai chi class to see how that would go, and I wanted to-to check in with you and see how tai chi went.
Well, I went once.
Uh-huh.
Yeah and, um, it was very-very beautiful to see and the instructor was very nice, but I felt kind of self-conscious because I'm still in my walker.
Uh-huh.
And I had to sit in the chair. I couldn't, you know, do what they were doing.
Mm-hmm.
So, it's-- it was-- I simply felt self-conscious.
Uh-huh. So, you thought it was beautiful and you liked the instructor, but you were a little self-conscious because you were in a chair?
A lot self-conscious.
A lot self-conscious, uh-huh.
Yeah.
What were you hoping to achieve with the, um, by going to tai chi?

Well, like Dr. Fields told me, it helps with balance, and I'm still having the wobblies. So, I was really hoping that I could get to the point where I could benefit from what they had to offer. Um, yeah, mostly my balance, mostly my balance.
Uh-huh. So, you're hoping that it would help with balance, but you didn't see the- maybe the results you were looking for?
Not yet.
Not yet.
Yeah.
Uh-huh. What is your overall goal? What are you working towards?
I wanna go home.
Uh-huh.
Yes, I really do.
Mm-hmm, and what is it that's important to you about getting home?
[sighs] Everything. I want to be with my little dog.
Mm-hmm.
He's really so cute, and I miss my garden.
Yeah.
And I just miss being independent, going to sleep when I want to sleep and getting up when I want to get up and-and, uh, cooking for myself. The independence. Sure I miss being independent.
Uh-huh. So, you're wanting to get home to your dog, your garden, back to your life, your independence?
Yes.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.
What do you think you need to do in order to be able to achieve that goal of getting home?
Well, they told me that I need to be able to walk down the hallway and back, even with the walker, being secure and not with the wobblies.
Uh-huh.
And I haven't gotten there yet.
And do you agree that that's what you need to do in order to be able to get home?
Yeah.
Uh-huh.
I-I don't want to fall.
Uh-huh.
I-I've had friends that had that happen. So, um, I-I agree a little, with some hesitation, but I do agree.
Uh-huh, and tell me how your physical therapy is going?
Oh, it's better.
Mm-hmm.
It still hurts. It- it's-- I'm getting better. I'm-I'm getting better. It's not quite as painful.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah, so-
So, it sounds like, um, you can see that you're making some progress in physical therapy-
Yes.
-and that you were hoping that the tai chi would help you with the wobblies. Uh-huh?
Yeah.
And so, are you wanting to go back to tai chi?
[sighs] Um, yes-yes I-I do because I-- my friend, I think I told you, really, really loves it and I just, I wish I could go back, and yes I do. I'm not making much sense, but I do.
Uh-huh. I think it's important, um, that you know that you're the one who has to make the decision about whether or not tai chi works for you.
Oh, I don't really know yet after just one time.
Uh-huh.
Yeah. It's-it's-- I can't make that-- It wouldn't be fair for me to say it does or doesn't. It didn't that one time, but you know.
So, you haven't seen the results that you want yet-
Yeah.
-but because Dr. Fields has recommended it and your friend has-
Yeah.
-and it sounds like you like the instructor-
Yeah, I do.
-it sounds like you'd like to try and give it another chance?
Yeah, I would.
So, what has to happen in order for you to get to tai chi again?

Well, I'd have to make the arrangements again, that was a little complicated, and, um, I'd have to get my head straight about feeling self-conscious, because I-I know that nobody's really looking at me, but I have to convince myself.
Uh-huh. Yeah.
Yeah, and the arrangement, arrangements a little complicated.
Uh-huh. So, how confident are you on a scale of 1 to 10 with one being not at all confident and 10 being very confident that you can make the arrangements in order to get to tai chi.
That I can make the arrangement?
Mm-hmm.
Five.
Five.
Yeah.
Uh-huh, so-
I-I mean, I know I can, but it's really difficult.
Uh-huh. What is it that makes it a five instead of a one, no confidence?
That I'm doing it by myself.
Mm-hmm.
And I would really fe-- If I could have some sup-- Like if somebody could help me do it.
Uh-huh.
My-my daughter can't visit that often and, um-
Uh-huh.
Yeah.
So, in order for you to feel more confident, you would like some help in making those arrangements?
I would.
Uh-huh.
I would.
And is that something that your daughter can do for you?
Well, she's-- she could, but I'd have to wait at least a week.
Okay. Um, so is that something that you'd like us to help you with?
I would.
Uh-huh.
Yeah, yeah. Is that possible?
Sure we can make those arrangements with the rehab center. They have a van-
Uh-huh.
-and-and they've done this for other patients so we can certainly make those arrangements if you'd like.
That would- that would be good. And then as far as feeling self-confident, I'd have to do that myself.
Okay. So, are there any other barriers or obstacles in the way to you getting to tai chi?
Um, I can't think of any.
Okay.
That's-that's the main thing-
All right.
the arrangements.
Well, it sounds like you can see that you're making some progress in your physical therapy.
Yes.
And that you're wanting to give tai chi another chance, and that if we can help make arrangements for you to get there with the van to the rehab center, that you'll give it another chance.
That's-- Yeah.
Okay.

So Tom, this infection has been pretty painful for you, but we have antibiotics. If you take them faithfully for ten days, I'm sure your infection will be gone. Can you do that?
Definitely.
Do you mind if we talk about a screening form that you filled out earlier today on drug use?
Okay.
Let's take a look. It says that on occasion, you use drugs for non-medical reasons. Which drugs do you use?
I do some meth.
Snort it, smoke it?
Snort it, always snort it.
Don't inject it?
Mm-mm.
Use any other drugs?
Just some alcohol.
How often do you use meth?
Um, two, three times a month.
So you're an occasional meth user. You don't use very often?
Right.
Only snort it?
Right.

Well, as I think you know, methamphetamine use is associated with some health risks. The amount you're using puts you in a category that we consider a risky user. That contrasts with someone who is addicted, a heavy user. It's not a healthy category because people who use methamphetamine tend to experience several consequences. One of them is sexually transmitted diseases. Do you suppose that your STD might be associated with your methamphetamine use?
Yeah, it could be because I was high when I had unprotected sex, and I would not do that if I were not high.
So you're normally very careful and you use protection when you have sex?
Definitely, yeah.
It seems to you that methamphetamine may have clouded your judgment?
Yeah.
Anything else happening with methamphetamine in your life? Is it affecting you in any way?

No, I mean, no. Like I said, I only do it in clubs, with my friends, two or three times a month at the most. I don't think it's really having other impacts. But I'm concerned about this one. I never expected to get gonorrhea.
I'm concerned about it too, and I'd recommend that you stop using methamphetamine altogether. There are a lot of reasons for this, but that's my recommendation.

I understand, but I think that would be a hard thing for me to do. I know I should, but that's like my whole social life. All my friends go to these clubs. That's where I see them. That's my sex life basically, and meth is just a part of it. Everyone is doing it there. So while I would like to stop, it's kind of hard to think about doing that right away.
So you recognize methamphetamine has some problems associated with it, and you also see that a lot of your social life and your sex life involves methamphetamine. It would be difficult to quit using?
Yeah, I don't think it would be easy, but I'm not saying that I'm not willing to try.
If you were to consider how ready you are to stop using methamphetamine completely-
Mm-hmm.
-with zero being not ready at all-
Mm.
-and ten being ready, where would you put yourself?
Uh, three.
Why not a one or a two?

This has been really uncomfortable, gonorrhea is a really bad experience. I don't think the same when I'm on it. What I have is bad enough, I could easily get AIDS. I could get HIV the same way. That scares me a lot. That's why it's higher than a one or two.
Are there any other concerns that you have about methamphetamine?
Well, I do just snort it, but you don't know what it's cut with. It could be really bad if it was cut with something dangerous. I worry about that sometimes.

When I was first talking to you, I thought that you'd have very little interest in stopping using methamphetamine, but it sounds like you have several reasons why you really would like to stop. That it might be cut with something else, you could get another STD, including HIV.
Yeah.
What do you think would make it easier for you to cut down or quit using methamphetamine?
Something else to do on weekends, you know, different social life.
How could you get a different social life?
It's the hard thing. Almost everybody I know uses it.
Is there anyone in your life who doesn't use methamphetamine?
My sister.
Have you talked to her about your meth use?
I haven't talked to her about it. I think she knows I do it sometimes. We're pretty close. I think I could talk to her about it, and I think she would probably help.

On the one hand, it would be difficult to quit using methamphetamine because there are so many positives that you get from using it. But on the other, there are reasons why you want to quit using methamphetamine.
Yes.
There are some things that you might be able to do that would make it easier to not use methamphetamine, including talking to your sister and getting some support.
Yes.
Great. I recommend that you not use methamphetamine at all, but what you do is up to you.
Okay.
I could see you again in a month. Would that work out for you?
Yeah, sure.
Welcome, Ricky.
Thank you.
Nice to meet you.
Yeah, you too.
And you found us okay?
Yeah. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Alright.
Yeah. Yeah. pretty straightforward-
Yeah
always good.
Have you been here before?
No. No, not at all.
Mm. Okay. Alright. Well, um, I know a little about why you're here today-
Yeah.
-um, but it's great to see you, and so maybe a good point to start with is, tell me why you're here.

Sure. Um, I guess, you know, maybe two or three weeks ago, I had sort of like this group of friends come around to my place, and um, you know, they-they were sort of saying that it was just like a night to hang out and watch DVDs and stuff, and then they sort of sat me down and were like, "You know, maybe you need to get a bit of help for, you know, drug stuff." Then, you know, I was sort of like, "Well, mm." And I was quite annoyed by that at first, but I-I suppose, you know, I thought about it for a bit and then I was like, "Well, I guess it can't hurt to talk to someone about it, maybe."
Right.
Yeah.
And that's led you to being here today?
Yeah.
Alright.
Yeah. I just sort of did a bit of search on the internet and stuff and just read about this place, so I just thought I'll-
Right. So it sounds like you thought there was something that, uh, that you needed to look at, something that was concerning you?

Yeah, I guess. I-I suppose I hadn't really thought about it till they sat me down, and you know- I mean I could, uh, I could understand a little bit of where they were coming from, so yeah, I thought I'd-
They were concerned for you?
Yeah.
Alright.
Yeah. Yeah, which kind of was a bit of a sh-shock, I suppose.
You were surprised?

Yeah. Yeah, 'cause, you know, I don't know. You know, you see on movies when people sort of intervene or say, "You know, you need to go and get help." And then-- I don't know. Like you know those characters and, they-they do need help, you know-
Yep.
-because they're fucked.
Mm-hmm.
And you kind of go, "Woah. That's not me." So it's about am I-
You're not sure that applies to you?
Yeah, or well, not to that extent, you know what I mean? Like, I-I would-- l didn't think I was at anywhere near a point that I would need to be sat down and intervened with-
Okay.
if you know What I mean.
Alright.
I suppose.
I'm trying to understand you so far, something's concerning you and something's concerning your friends-
Yeah.
-but you're not sure whether it's- whether-- just how bad it is or- and you're just wanting to check that out?
Yeah. Yeah. Yeah, 'cause, I mean, you know, they are my friends and-
Mm-hmm.

- you know, I'm not gonna be so narrow-minded as to say for sure that, you know, they're entirely wrong 'cause there's a big group of them, you know? And they do care, so obviously, there's something there that I might have overlooked. But on the other ha-
Yeah.
-and just check it up, yep.
Because they care about you and-and you respect what they say, and you're wondering whether something about what they're saying may be right, but let's check that out a bit?
Yeah, pretty right.
Alright.
Yeah.
Well, let's do some checking out.
Okay, cool.
So tell me a little bit about what you're doing, what is- what is the concern that they are raising.
Um, dr-drugs, I guess.
Mm-hmm.
Mm, yeah. Sort of kind of do a bit of P now and again-
Alright.
-and, um, I guess less often, I do a bit of, you know, I smoke a little bit and, um, party pills in the- in the weekend sometimes.
Okay.
Yeah.
Tell me a little bit about what now and again means, and-and-and how often.
Um, a couple of times a week maybe.
Is this- is this with, uh, with the drug?
Yeah, yeah.
This is meth you're talking about? A couple of times a week?
Mm-hmm, yeah. Yeah. So I guess when I put it that way, it does sound quite a lot, but it doesn't feel a lot, you know? If you know what I mean?

Well, maybe, we c-- we can check that out to see whether-whether it's a lot or-- But maybe also importantly to-to discuss with you what the effects are and-and-and what your concerns are about it. But help me to understand a little bit more of what it's like for you. Tell me- tell me what are the things about your, uh, use of meth that you- that you've liked that you found good for you?
Right. Um, I suppose it's kind of hand-in-hand with just hanging out with, sort of, some new scene that I've-- Like, um, I moved to Auckland maybe three years ago.
Mm-hmm.

And, um, I still live in Palmy and, so as you can imagine, it's sort of a bit different down there. And, um, kind of just when I first got here I was sorta introduced a little bit to, um, like do you know Family Bar on-on [unintelligible 00:06:49]?
I know Family Bar, yes.

Yeah. It's that sort of- that sorta scene, that kind of, um, gay scene, I guess. And, like, it's not something I'd really thought about before and-- But then kinda hung out there and just met these people that were sort of like you don't really get there much Palmy. Well, I mean I suppose you do, but they're not-- You know, in Auckland bars like that you can just-- Uh, you can just be it out in the open, you know, and I suppose in Palmy you can't as easily. Um, so just to arrive and see that and kind of meet these people that were just really friendly, you know, and-and not judge me into it. I don't know. You know, Palmy often is they're sort of like, "Oh, you've gotta own a car, and soap it up, and drive up and down the Main Street," and I just couldn't give a shit about that, you know, so. Or play rugby and, you know, that didn't interest me at all and sorta come here and have people, you know, talk about interesting stuff and have a good time. I just want to go out and dance and stuff like that. Um, that was quite cool for me to know that that existed because I hadn't seen that before and-and I suppose there's a lot of that that goes on there, you know?

It's quite a heavy party scene most weekends and stuff. So it kind of goes hand in hand with that really, and just, you know, I guess when I have-have a slight-- I don't know, you just feel really good, I guess. Just feel, like, happy, and excited, and just to be surrounded by people that, you know, really care about you, and love you and-- Coming from a place where y-you didn't-- don't get that as much, it's just really cool, you know, to-to be able to go, "Okay, on this day I can take this." And it's just that instant, like, "I know- I know I'll feel good." I guess that's part of it.
So Auckland, coming to Auckland from Palmerston for you was-was like taking charge of something that you were going to look to make something different in your life?
Yeah, in-in a way. Although I wouldn't have been conscious of that really. I just sort of discovered it here. It's not like I came to Auckland looking for that kinda-
Right.
-lift to get away from, um, you know parents mainly, and that kind of lifestyle, that Palmy sort of lifestyle. But then yeah, I discovered this other thing, um-
Which you weren't aware of in Palmerston?
No.
Okay.
No. I didn't really know. I guess you see sort of things like that in-in movies from America you know, but you don't really-
Mm-hmm.
- think that it would exist in your own country. Well, not if you grew up in Palmy.
Palmerston. Mm-hmm.
Um, I don't mean to be mean about Palmy but, you know, it's just the different kinda attitude, I guess, kinda- this done-
Yeah.
to that sort of thing.
It sounds like you're ready to move up to something that was different.
Yes-
And-and you came-
-plus-
here to Auckland.
