I just, um, I don't- don't know where to start. I don't know.
It sounds like starting the program feels like a good first step.
Yeah, I hope so. I-- So I genuinely want to, I genuinely want to do something to help myself. I don't deliberately mess things up for myself.

Yeah.  It sounds like you're ready to make a real effort this time.  We're going to be working together on this, and sometimes it can get tough.  A lot of guys, when things get difficult, they drop out.  What do you think about that?
No, this is important to me.
Right.  You're committed to seeing this through.
I have, um, I've-- it's important to me.

Good.  Now, one of the things that can really help is having support.  Who else in your life could you be accountable to while you're doing this program?  Think about your children, your mom, anyone else you interact with.
I, um, I'm separated at the moment from my partner, and-
What was her name?
Uh, Kirsty.
Kirsty.  Would you like her to know you're doing this?
I would love for her to know that I'm doing this and for her to know that I mean it, but, um, I know she wouldn't care right now actually.
Right.  It sounds like things are difficult there at the moment. What about your employer?
Uh, yeah, I don't know. Maybe, but I don't know if I want them to know though.
Okay.  That's something we can explore later.  Any other family close by?
I'm pretty much by myself up here.
Okay.  So, it sounds like you're feeling a bit isolated here. Your family is down south.  Who else could be a support for you on this journey?
Um, I don't know. I don't, um, have that many people-

Okay.  Rick, it sounds like you've got a lot on your mind, and you're really motivated to make some changes for yourself and your kids. We've talked about your goals, the importance of this for you, and the challenges you might face, including finding support. For our next session, I'd like you to think more about who could be part of your support network.  Even one or two people can make a big difference.  How does
I just feel helpless about this whole deal.
It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure of what to do next.
Mm. I just feel helpless about this whole deal.
It's understandable to feel that way when facing challenges.  Can you tell me more about what's making you feel helpless?
No one wants to help me.
That sounds incredibly isolating. It must be difficult to feel like you're facing this alone.
No one wants to help me.
It seems like you're really longing for support right now. Is there anyone specific you were hoping would help?
Mm-hmm. I really shouldn't have done it.
It sounds like you're regretting a decision you made.
Mm-hmm. I really shouldn't have done it.
It's common to have regrets. What's making you feel this way about it?
Mm-hmm. I couldn't help myself.
It sounds like you felt powerless in that situation.
I couldn't help myself.
It takes courage to admit that.  Can you tell me more about what happened?
It's actually been a fabulous week.
That's wonderful to hear! It sounds like things have been going well for you.
It's actually been a fabulous week.
What's contributed to making this such a positive week?
Mm-hmm. I know who to hang out with, I'm not stupid.
It sounds like you're confident in your ability to make good choices about who you spend time with.
I know who to hang out with, I'm not stupid.
It's great that you recognize the importance of positive influences in your life.
Mm-hmm. I'm letting the whole family down. They had such high hopes for me.
It sounds like you're feeling a sense of disappointment and responsibility towards your family.
Mm-hmm. I'm letting my whole family down. They had such high hopes for me.
It's clear how much you care about your family and their expectations.  What makes you feel like you're letting them down?
Mm-hmm. This is not what I want for my life.
It sounds like you have a clear vision of what you *do* want.
This is not what I want for my life.
That's a powerful realization.  What steps could you take to move closer to that vision?
Mm-hmm. I really want to get off the program.
It sounds like you're eager to make some changes.
I really want to get off the program.
What makes you feel like leaving the program is the right step for you right now?
Mm-hmm. I still crave smoking, even though I've stopped.
It sounds like you're still experiencing some challenges with cravings, even though you've quit smoking.
I still crave smoking, even though I've stopped.
That's a common experience.  It takes a lot of strength to resist those urges.  What's helping you to stay strong?

So, thanks for coming in today. We're going to talk for a bit about the questionnaires you filled out, but before we dive into those, is there anything in particular you'd like to discuss or any specific concerns you have?

Um, yeah, I mean, when I was doing those questionnaires, it was weird because, I guess I don't really think about the drinking being this huge deal and I don't ever really think about how much I drink.
It sounds like completing the questionnaires brought to light some things you hadn't really considered before about your drinking.

Yeah, like, filling out how much I'm drinking every day, it was like, 'Wow,' you know, like, I just didn't ever really think about it like that I was-- like, if I try to actually count the drinks, it's kind of a lot.
So, actually tracking your drinks gave you a clearer picture of your consumption, and it was a bit of a surprise.

Well, yeah, 'cause, like, I also kind of thought that I drink about as much as my friends did and then, like, I went back and I was talking to my roommate about it and I was telling her that, you know, I was drinking, like, ten drinks on the weekends, including Thursday, so like, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday.
And your roommate was surprised by that?
Yeah, and she was like, 'That's crazy. Why are you drinking this much?' And I was like, 'Well, you know, like, different places.' And I guess my friends didn't really know.
It sounds like you realized your drinking habits were different from what you assumed and that even your roommate was taken aback by the amount you were consuming.
Yeah, and I guess it was just like, I thought that everybody was doing it, but that's not really what was going on.
So, the realization that your drinking patterns are different from your friends' and that it might be more than you thought is what stood out most from completing the forms?
Yeah, so, that was the thing that was really the most weird about doing those forms.

Okay. So, it sounds like this information about your drinking has been a bit of a wake-up call. We can talk more about what you'd like to do with this new understanding. What are your thoughts about it now?
I don't know. I guess I'm a little concerned, but also, I don't know, it's just kind of what I do.

That's understandable. It's not always easy to think about changing habits, especially ones that are part of your social life. We can explore those feelings and any concerns you have. What would you like to focus on as we talk today?
Maybe just understanding why I drink so much, I guess.
That sounds like a good place to start. We can definitely explore that. Perhaps we can begin by looking at some of the patterns you noticed in the questionnaires. Would that be alright with you?
Yeah, that's fine.

Okay, so, um, in this program, we encourage everyone to choose at least three goals they'd like to work on over the next 30 days. We'll be checking in with you to see how you're progressing.  It's important to pick goals that are meaningful to you and that you feel ready to work towards. With that in mind, is there anything you'd like to change or focus on, either at home or at school?
Um, I need to start getting to school on time for my first class. I always miss it.
Okay, so getting to school on time for your first class is something you'd like to work on over the next 30 days?
Yes.
That's a great goal.  Why is it important for you to achieve this goal?
Uh, so people will stop bothering me.
And who are these people?
My mom. She's always telling me to get to school. And my probation officer says if I don't get to school on time, I could face sanctions, and I really don't want that.
So, avoiding those sanctions is a strong motivator for you?
Yes.
Okay. So, getting to school on time for your first class is your goal.
I'll try.
What specific steps would you need to take to get to school on time for that first class?

I can never seem to get up in the morning. That's the hard part. And by the time I do get up, get ready, and get dressed, I miss the bus. So, I usually end up walking or trying to find a ride. There are a lot of reasons why I'm late.
Okay, so it's not just one single thing that's causing the problem?
No.
Knowing that a few different things can get in your way, what do you think would be the most helpful for you to get to school on time? What do you know you need to do?
Getting up on time would probably be a good start.
What time would you need to get up?
[sighs] If I'm going to catch the bus, I'd probably need to be up by 6:15. But that's so hard, because I go to bed so late. I don't know if I can do it.
So, you're a little unsure if you can do it, but you also mentioned that you really want to do it to avoid those sanctions.
Right. I could try...
Okay.
...and see how it goes.
So, you're willing to give it a try?
Yes.
What time would you need to go to bed at night to make sure you're up by 6:15?
I usually go to bed around midnight now, so if I tried maybe 11:00. I could try 11:00.
Okay, so you're willing to try going to bed at 11:00 and setting your alarm for 6:15 the next morning?
Yes.
When would be a good day for you to start this?
Uh, tomorrow or the next day.
Okay, so should I write down tomorrow or the next day?
Let's start tomorrow.
Tomorrow it is. Great. Who could help you get to bed on time and make sure you're up by 6:15?
My mom.
Your mom.
Mm-hmm.
Is there anything your mom could do to help you with that?
[sighs] She could, after my alarm goes off, if I don't get up, she could come in and wake me up and remind me that I told you I was going to get up, so I have to do it.

So, it's almost like you want your mom to remind you that this is something you want for yourself.  Not just because she's telling you to get up, but to remind you, 'Hey, remember, this is something you want – to be on time for your first class.'
Exactly. Yup.
Great. What could potentially get in the way of you not getting up by 6:15?
[sighs] Not going to bed on time.
Not going to bed on time.
Yup, that's going to be a struggle.
Okay. So, if you're feeling tempted to stay up later...
Mm-hmm.
...how could you respond instead?
Just go to bed and turn off the lights, and not have my phone.
Okay, so your phone is a distraction.  So, keeping your phone away...
Oh, yeah.
...and actually turning the lights off and making sure it's dark?
Yes.
Kind of a reminder that it's time to go to bed.
Have my mom check on me to make sure everything's put away.
And also having the support of your mom too.
Mm-hmm.
Great. So, how will you know that your plan is working?
When I'm at school on time, when the bell rings and I'm in class.
So, for you, being in your class when that bell rings, that's how you'll know you've achieved your goal.
Absolutely.

So, what I've been hearing so far – and this is a great goal – is that you've already had some insights into how to do this. It's really important for you to get to your first class because you don't want to face those sanctions. You don't want to have all those extra people checking up on you. You've already made a plan to go to bed by 11:00, turn off the lights, and put your cell phone away.  Having your mom's support will also be really helpful. You're going to try getting up at 6:15 in the morning when the alarm goes off.  I know that seems really early, but you seem willing to do it. And if you have trouble, your mom will be there to help you out.
Well, yeah, I hope so.
That sounds like a great plan, and you said you're going to start tomorrow.
I'll give it a try.
Great. Thank you.
You're welcome.
Tommy, I wanted to talk because I saw some pictures on Facebook of you and friends at a party.  I'm concerned. You're a good kid, and I'm worried about the drinking.

It was just a social gathering. I wasn't looking for it. The drinks were there, and all my friends were doing it. It's not something I do often, but when the opportunity comes up, it's nice to let loose and have fun.
I understand, but drinking has consequences. You're not 21 yet. You could get arrested, have an accident, or mess up school. You have a bright future, and this concerns me.
I get what you're saying. I thought I had it under control and didn't drink too much. I wanted to make sure my friends were okay, so I didn't overdo it.
There's no such thing as not drinking too much when you're underage. Think of what could happen.
Yeah, I understand.
How much are you drinking?
I don't think I drink that much. It's mainly at social gatherings. I don't do it alone.
Is it every weekend?
Every other weekend, I'd say.
Tommy, I'm concerned. Can't you think of better things to do?
I guess I could be more productive with schoolwork instead of going to parties. I understand where you're coming from.
Are your friends the problem? Maybe you should hang out with different people, like kids in your youth group.
I guess I haven't really thought about it.  It seems like my friends are doing it, and I'm just following along because it looks fun. I want to have a good high school experience.
Lots of things seem fun in the moment but aren't good choices. We've talked about making good choices.  I think you should consider making a change.
I see that drinking less could improve my life. It makes sense. I can try to lower how much I drink.
I think you should quit.
Alcohol is everywhere. It's hard to avoid at parties. I feel like I should understand its effects before cutting it out completely. I don't think it will ruin my life.
I disagree. It worries me.  Cutting down is better than nothing, but I'll keep talking to you about this. It's important.
I don't see the problem right now. Maybe it's because I haven't had a bad experience.
Do you want to wait for that? Do you want something bad to happen?

No. I don't want to go too far down that road. I can imagine things happening where I can't escape. I haven't had alcohol affect me or anyone close to me much, so I feel in control, but maybe I'm not.
Maybe we can work on this together. We can make a plan for you to get control and stop drinking.
That would be a good step towards being sober and experiencing life without alcohol.
Okay, sounds good.
Okay.
Hi Jean, I'm Dr. Selby. It's good to finally meet you in person.
Hi Dr. Selby.  It's good to meet you too. I appreciate you making time for me.
Of course, Jean.  So, tell me what brings you in today.
Well, it's...it's the smoking.  I've known for a while I need to quit, and my recent COPD diagnosis really brought it home.  It's scary, and honestly, I'm not sure I can do it.

That sounds like a lot to process, Jean.  A new diagnosis like that can be really unsettling. It’s understandable that you’re feeling scared.  It takes courage to face something like this, and it sounds like you're ready to take some steps.
Yeah, I know I need to.  I just...I've tried so many times before. Pills, patches, even therapy. Nothing seems to stick.  I feel like a failure.

It sounds like you've been through a lot, Jean.  Those experiences must be frustrating. It's important to remember that setbacks are a normal part of the process, and they don't mean you're a failure.  What makes this time feel different?

Honestly?  The diagnosis.  It's not just some abstract health risk anymore.  I can feel it.  I cough all the time, even when I'm just talking to clients on the phone. It's embarrassing, and it's frightening.

That makes complete sense.  It sounds like the COPD diagnosis has really brought the reality of the situation into sharp focus.  So, if you could wave a magic wand and have things be different, what would your ideal situation look like?
I'd love to just...not crave them anymore.  To not have it be such a constant battle in my head.  And to be able to breathe without worrying.
That sounds wonderful.  Imagine that for a moment – what would it be like to go through a day without that constant craving, without the coughing fits?
It would be...freeing.  I’d have more energy, I wouldn't feel so ashamed. I could actually enjoy things again.

That sense of freedom is something many people who quit smoking experience. It sounds like it's really important to you. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being 'not at all important' and 10 being 'extremely important,' how important is it for you to quit smoking right now?
Definitely a 10.  It has to be.
And on that same scale, with 1 being 'not at all confident' and 10 being 'extremely confident,' how confident are you that you can actually make this change?
Probably a 3 or a 4.  Like I said, I've tried so many times.
That's completely understandable given your past experiences.  What would it take to move that 3 or 4 up to a 5 or a 6?
I guess...some real support.  Someone to help me figure out what works this time. Maybe a group or something?

It sounds like connection and support would make a big difference for you.  We can definitely explore some options for that.  In the meantime, how would you feel about keeping a smoking journal for the next week? Just noting down each cigarette you smoke, when you smoked it, and what you were doing at the time. Sometimes, just becoming more aware of our habits can be a powerful first step.
Yeah, I guess I could do that.  It might help me see how much I actually smoke, too.
Exactly. It's not about judging yourself, Jean. It's simply about gathering information. We can then use that information to work together and find strategies that fit your life. How does that sound?
Okay. That sounds good. I appreciate you listening, Dr. Selby.
You're very welcome, Jean. I'm glad you came in. We'll work on this together.

So, we have several areas we could explore. You mentioned wanting to increase your physical activity, improve your eating habits, and boost your body confidence.  What feels most pressing for us to focus on today?

I think physical activity seems like the most manageable starting point.  Changing my nutrition feels more challenging right now, but if I can establish an exercise routine, it might make those other changes easier down the line.
Okay, so physical activity feels like the best initial focus.
Yes, I think so.

Great. Tell me more about what motivates you to become more physically active. You've mentioned wanting more energy and a better mood, feeling less irritable and stressed. Are there any other benefits that are especially important to you right now?

Yes, I'd like to feel physically stronger and more capable.  Like, the other night I struggled to open a jar of salsa.  So, things like that, in addition to the mood and energy boost, would be a definite goal. And I think if I'm more active, my body image and confidence will improve too.
So, you want to feel stronger, capable of doing things like opening jars, and also have increased confidence.
Yes.
On a scale of zero to ten, with zero being 'not at all ready' and ten being 'I'm excited and ready to go,' where do you see yourself regarding physical activity?
I'd say about an eight.
Okay, so you're feeling quite motivated.
Yes.
Why not a six?
Well, I've identified so many positive outcomes from being more active. I really want that improved mood and energy, and to feel better about myself.  Those things are driving my rating.
You're recognizing numerous benefits to physical activity, including increased energy, better mood, greater strength, and improved body confidence.
Yes.
Have I missed anything?
I don't think so.
Okay, those are the key motivators for you.
Yes.
Fantastic.  Now we can start exploring what that might look like for you, and what kinds of activities you might enjoy.
That would be great.
Okay.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Um. [sighs] I don't know. I guess I care about the person, and there's a certain comfort in having someone there. So, I'm at war with myself because part of me wants the companionship, and the other part... I'm just not sure what I want to do.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column6: It really helps you get through things.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Mm. Let's see. I'm not really sure. I'm having a hard time with that.

column6: Tell me more about that.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Well, I have to really think about it because...

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Some guilt?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah, maybe some guilt, and I just... [sighs] I go back and forth.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Uh-huh.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Because you want to do the right thing, and that's important to you – helping people.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah, I... thank you. I appreciate you saying that. I feel I am.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: But you've done your duty.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah. It's just hard to... my job is done, and I have to be more assertive and sure of myself.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: So, what have you done to start the process?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Well, I've had conversations, some not so pleasant. I tend to hold things in, and then finally, I was very logical about it. The other day, I wasn't so logical.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: [laughs]

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: You mentioned talking to others, and he has some options for other places to go.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yes. That's good. I mentioned them to him.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Mm-hmm.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Well, I told him within a couple of days. I have future plans, and things are up in the air for me too. I've been here seven years, but I'm not sure what's next.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Mm-hmm, Mm-hmm.

column6: Um.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: And it's kind of scary.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Oh, God, yeah. And it's scary to have an extra burden to carry with you.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: And he's that extra burden.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Yeah, yeah.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay. So, it sounds like you've worked it out for him to be out within a couple of days.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: That's the goal.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay. Well, I have a feeling your plans will prevail. [laughter]

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: I like your way of thinking. I'll tell him that. [laughs]

column6: Well, thanks for talking.

column6: So you're in a lot of pain?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: It's okay, Ruth. I understand the pain inside.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column6: So your mom doesn't understand you, and you don't have a dad around?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style

column6: So you feel like your hands are tied, that you're a burden to your mom. She's a single parent, she works a lot, and you have all these problems in your life. It sounds like you feel you're adding to her burdens.

column6: Yeah.

column6: Because it wouldn't be a burden to her.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Because she has to pay for my food, my uniforms, and our housing.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay. Even by coming here today, Ruth, and talking to me, opening up and telling me you don't want to continue, confiding in me that you hurt yourself and feel all this pain, that's you trying to help yourself. It shows you care. It shows you care about your mom, and you're worried about the burdens on her, even thinking of removing yourself to make her life easier. That shows me how much you care about her. But the solution you have in mind seems...

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: The right one?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: How could it be the right one? Ending your life, hurting yourself, when it's just you and your mom? You just said she's a single parent, she doesn't have a husband, you don't have a dad. It's just the two of you. How could that be the right choice?

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Um, I don't know. I'm not sure I can...

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: You're not sure. You have a lot on your mind right now. You've opened up to me, told me you've been hurting yourself, thinking about killing yourself, not wanting to be here. Short-term, it helps you. You feel like a burden to your mom, that stresses you out, makes you sad. You see how much she struggles. But we also see how much you've been trying to help by going to school. We know your attendance is good, you're trying to keep up your grades. You have a C average, even having an A in math, which was your lowest grade. All of that shows how much effort you've put in, and we see that effort. You've been doing what you can, and it's normal to feel like it's not enough sometimes. That's what we're here for, so you can tell us these things, and we can help you.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Thank you, I feel better.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Thank you, Ruth, for coming today.

column3: motivated towards adopting better life style
column6: Okay.
Thank you for coming in today, Katie. I'm looking forward to getting to know you.  Could you start by sharing a little about yourself and what brings you in today?
Uh, yeah, sure. Um, well, my doctor referred me to see you. Um, he has some concerns about my pregnancy and my baby. So, I'm doing what I'm told.
So you're following through by meeting with me today, and you mentioned he has some concerns. Can you tell me a little more about that?
Uh, yeah, he is concerned about my alcohol intake.
Okay. And I'm wondering if you have any concerns about that.
Uh, no.
No. Okay. So that's not an issue for you. It is an issue for him, but not for you at this point.
Mm-hmm.
Okay.  Could you share a little about your alcohol intake and what your life is like?
Um, okay. Uh, well, I guess I drink a glass of wine at supper every night, and sometimes a bit more to relax with my friends if I go out. Wine has always been a kind of family tradition with supper.
Okay.
Yeah.
So it's part of your culture, and you find alcohol helps you relax a little.

Yeah, and I have friends who drank during pregnancy, and I see articles on Facebook that say there isn't really a clear link between abnormalities and alcohol. I just think it's kind of an old wives' tale. I'm independent and I'm going to do what I want; it's my body.

Okay. So you're not comfortable with someone telling you what kind of alcohol and how much you should consume. It sounds like you've been getting mixed messages. Your doctor says there's no safe amount of alcohol during pregnancy and asked you to see me. You've also been looking into this yourself.
Yeah. I've looked it up to support my argument.
Okay.
Yeah, which is that I'm going to do what I want. So... I'm here anyway.
You know yourself best and want to be in control of your body.  You don't want someone else telling you what's okay.  It seems you're not too concerned right now about your alcohol use.
Nope. Never have been.
Okay. Is that lack of concern based on your past experiences, the messages from friends?
Yep.
And the information you've seen in the media that suggests it's okay to drink alcohol?  So, you're not concerned, and maybe the doctor is exaggerating?
Mm-hmm. I think so.
You think he might be overreacting a bit?
Yeah.
To suggest quitting drinking entirely?
Yeah.
I'm wondering, would you be open to looking at what the current guidelines say about drinking?  Would that be something you'd consider?
Like right now?
Yes.
Uh...
What if I showed you a brochure about it?
Uh, yeah, I guess.
Yeah?
Sure.

If we look at the low-risk alcohol drinking guidelines, it says the safe limit for women is 10 drinks a week, and no more than 2 drinks a day.  This applies to women who are not pregnant. The guidelines also state there is no safe amount of alcohol to drink during pregnancy. Zero alcohol is recommended. What are your thoughts on that?
Well, I've heard these things before, but I don't see the evidence. I don't see the risk.  If someone could prove it to me, or show a direct link...
So, seeing it in writing isn't enough to convince you it might be dangerous to drink during pregnancy?
It's the same thing I've already heard.
So you feel like what the doctor and this brochure are saying is a bit blown out of proportion?
Mm-hmm.
And it sounds like you've found information suggesting alcohol is safe during pregnancy. Tell me about that information.
Um, well, I've looked up different articles.  And, as I said, I know people who haven't had any problems. That's about it.
Mm-hmm. You mentioned articles, and evidence is important to you. Are these recent articles?
I don't have a bibliography or anything.
Mm-hmm.
So I don't know when they were published. Just stuff I found supporting my view.
So the information you found supports your desire to be independent and autonomous, to make your own choices. The information from your doctor and this brochure seems to challenge those values.
Yeah. This brochure just says the same thing I've heard, about the limits and no safe amount during pregnancy. But why not?
Mm-hmm.
What kind of issues would it cause, if any?
Maybe we can set that aside for a moment and come back to it later. We'll look at what the guidelines say about the 'why.' Could we talk about your pregnancy? Was this a planned pregnancy?
Yeah.
Something you were hoping for?
Yep.
Okay. How important is it to you to have a healthy baby and be a good parent?
Um, it's really important. It's a big priority to have a healthy baby and raise him or her well, and be a good parent.
Mm. What does being a good parent look like to you?
Um, being there at home with them, not being absent, taking care of them, feeding them, changing their diaper (which I'm not excited about). The basics.
Hmm. Protecting your baby...
Yeah.
...guiding your baby...
Mm-hmm.
...nurturing that baby is really important to you...
Yeah, of course.
...and raising your baby well?
Yeah.
That really matters to you. I hear you saying protecting your baby is important, but that seems to clash with the information in the brochure.
Mm-hmm.
What do you think about that?
Um, I don't know where these brochures get their information, where's the hard evidence?
You want to see it in black and white.
Yeah.

You want to know it's current and reliable. The information I've shared is based on the latest research since 2011. There's been a lot of research on what's safe for a pregnant woman to consume, including alcohol. This is the evidence we have. Ultimately, you choose what's best for you and your baby. What are your thoughts?

It surprises me that it's based on research from 2011. I must have missed that. If it is current, I want to do what's best for my baby and myself. If I have to quit drinking, I guess I'll make that decision.  But it's a lot to take in today.

Mm-hmm. It sounds like you've been making good decisions about your baby. You've done research, you want to raise your baby well. I can see that's important to you. This information wasn't what you were expecting.
Nope.
What would be helpful next steps, as you think about potentially reducing or stopping alcohol use during your pregnancy?

Um, if I could take a brochure home to show my partner and get their support. That would really help me. And changing our habits, putting the alcohol away. That's probably the best thing I can do today.
Mm-hmm. Those are significant steps. Putting the alcohol away is huge. That's really big.
Yeah.

Thank you for exploring this with me today. Could we continue this conversation and talk about those steps, how it goes with talking to your partner about reducing or stopping drinking, and give you a chance to do more research and review the brochures? Would that work for you?
Yeah, I think that would be a good idea. Maybe you could help me with ways to approach it with my partner, because I think they have the same view I had.
We can definitely cover that next time. Thank you for coming in.
Yeah. Thank you.
Hi Mr. Smith, thanks for coming in.  Let's start by checking in on how your medication is working for you.
Good, I think it's helping.

That's great to hear. I also wanted to discuss your blood pressure, which was a little elevated last time.  Is now a good time to talk about that, or would you prefer to address it at a later appointment?
Well, I'm a bit rushed today, to be honest.  I had a long wait, and I've got a busy afternoon.
I understand completely.  My apologies for the wait; that's certainly not ideal.  It sounds like your time is valuable.
It is.  I'm self-employed, so time off means lost income.

Absolutely.  I appreciate you making the effort to come in.  So, regarding your blood pressure, we can certainly focus on that today.  Would you be open to briefly discussing some lifestyle factors that can contribute to blood pressure, even if we can't go into great depth today?
Okay, a quick chat is fine.  But I really do need to get back to the office soon.
Understood.  So, how do you generally feel about your current lifestyle and its impact on your health?
Well, I know I could probably eat better and exercise more.  It's just… time.  I'm constantly working.

That's a common challenge. Many people find it difficult to balance work and healthy habits. It sounds like you're aware of what you could be doing differently, but the practicalities of fitting it into your schedule are the real hurdle.
Exactly.  Ready meals and grabbing food on the go are my staples.
So, if things were different, if you had more flexibility in your day, it sounds like you'd be more inclined to make healthier choices?
Definitely.  I know what I *should* be doing.
Okay.  So, it sounds like you're motivated to make changes, but the current structure of your work life makes it difficult.  Is that a fair summary?
Yes, that's it in a nutshell.

Thanks for sharing that. Given your time constraints today, how about we schedule a follow-up appointment specifically to explore some strategies for incorporating healthier habits into your busy schedule? We can brainstorm some realistic and manageable steps you could take.
That sounds good.  But please, no more long waits!
Absolutely.  I'll make sure to schedule you for the first appointment of the day to avoid any delays.  We can use that session to really dive into this and find some solutions that work for you.
Okay, great.  I'll check my schedule and call to book something.
Perfect.  And in the meantime, perhaps just give some thought to any small changes you might be able to make, even if they seem minor.  We can discuss those at our next meeting.
Will do. Thanks.
You're welcome.  I look forward to our next conversation.
Hi, Mike. I'm Kathy. I appreciate you coming in today.
Hi, Kathy, nice to meet you.
I understand you'd probably rather be elsewhere, but thank you for being here.
Okay.
I want to check in on how you're doing physically.  Your safety is important, so I'd like to ask a couple of questions about that, if that's alright?
Sure.
I understand you're here because of a speeding ticket. Is that right?
Actually, I got a DUI and was speeding at the time.
Oh, I see.  Are you feeling unwell or sick at all right now?
No, I'm fine.
Good. I just wanted to make sure. When was the last time you had a drink?
The night of the DUI.
Okay.  I understand your lawyer suggested this assessment. Can you tell me what you understand about it?
He said I should come here and tell the truth, but I'm not really sure what it means.
I appreciate your honesty.  Do you have any questions for me about the process?
No, not really.
Your lawyer mentioned your blood alcohol level was 0.28.  That's significantly above the legal limit for driving.
Is that bad?
Yes, it's considered very high.
Okay.
The officer at the scene seemed concerned.
Yeah, he was freaking out a bit.
I understand.  I'd like to ask some questions about your drinking habits. You said the DUI was two weeks ago. What did you drink that night, and how much?
I was at a friend's birthday party downtown. It's not typical for me, but I drank too much and made a bad decision to drive.
Can you tell me more about how much you drank?
I don't really remember. Maybe five or six drinks, I think.
Five or six drinks. What kind of drinks were they?
Vodka and soda.
You mentioned this isn't typical for you. How often do you usually drink?
Normally, one or two drinks, and not very often. There's no real pattern.
So, you wouldn't consider yourself an alcoholic?
No, it was just poor judgment that night.
So, drinking doesn't usually interfere with your daily life?
No, not at all.
When do you think you started drinking regularly?
I don't really drink regularly, so I'm not sure that question applies.
Okay.  Let's talk about your first DUI.  This was your second, correct?
Yes.
It seems like the times you've had more than a couple of drinks, you've gotten into trouble. Is that a fair assessment?
Yeah, pretty much.
It sounds like you've had some bad luck.
Yeah, it seems that way.
Does alcohol always seem to be involved when you have these bad luck" incidents?"
It seems like it.
Can you think of other times when alcohol was involved and things went badly, or was it just these two DUIs?
I don't usually drink to excess.  It's not a regular thing.
Where do you typically drink? At home, socially after work, or at events?
Usually socially.
Have you thought about ways to ensure your safety after drinking?
Yeah, maybe calling a taxi.
That sounds like a good idea. It seems like you've already been considering your options.
Yeah, or I could just stay home if I plan to drink.
That's a responsible approach. You've clearly given this some thought.
Yeah, I don't like getting into trouble.
No one does. When you think about alternatives to driving after drinking, how consistent is that thought? Do you think you'll act on it next time?
I'll never drive drunk again.
What makes this time different?
I don't want to lose my license or my job.
You need your license for work, since you sell cars, right?
Yes, exactly.
You're here today, and I commend you for that.  It shows you're taking this seriously.  Calling a taxi or staying home are good signs you're thinking about safety.
Yeah.
What does staying home look like for you? You mentioned drinking at events.
The Super Bowl is coming up. I might drink then, so I'll probably just have people over instead of going out.
That sounds like a good plan.
Yeah, it's safer.
Have you ever considered not drinking at all?
After my first DUI, I didn't drink for six months. I didn't think I had a problem, so I started again.
Six months is a significant period. What were those six months like?
It was strange. My friends didn't hang out with me as much.
Your friends?
Yeah.
The ones you usually drink with?
Yeah, my social circle.
Why do you think they didn't spend as much time with you?
Probably because I wasn't drinking with them. I don't really know.
Did you talk to them about it?
No, my girlfriend at the time didn't want me to.
So, your girlfriend was important to you?
Yes, at the time.
Why did you break up?
She left when I started drinking again.
After the six months?
Around the same time. We were arguing a lot. I didn't feel like myself. I missed going out with my friends.
You felt isolated?
Yeah. I felt like she was trying to control me.
So, you value your independence?
Yeah.
How long ago was that six-month period of sobriety?
My first DUI was three years ago, and this one was a few weeks ago.
What have been the positive and negative aspects of drinking since then?
I don't really think of it in terms of good or bad. I just drink socially.
Did those friends start spending time with you again?
Yes, after my girlfriend and I broke up.
So, your girlfriend and your friends didn't get along?
She blamed my first DUI on them, saying they encouraged me to drink too much.
What do you think about that?
I think she was right. If they hadn't given me those shots, I would have been okay to drive.
So, you think you would have been fine if they hadn't given you those shots?
Yeah.
You mentioned hitting a mailbox. Was that related to the first DUI?
Yes, I hit a mailbox a couple of blocks from home.
That must have been frightening.
I don't remember much of that night.
Was it a blackout?
I don't know if it was a blackout, I just don't remember it clearly.
After that incident, you stopped drinking for six months, right?
Yes, and we were trying to work things out, but it didn't last.
You felt like she was controlling you?
Yes, I was tired of it.
You felt like you needed your friends, too?
Yes.
You mentioned your friends gave you shots. Did you feel pressured by them?
No, they just shouldn't have given me those last shots. They knew I'd had enough.
They weren't looking out for your best interests?
No.
And you drove after that.
Yeah, it was my choice to take the shots, but I don't remember much.
It's easy to have 20/20 hindsight.
Yeah.
So, after you started drinking again, did you reconnect with the same group of friends?
Yes, they've been my friends
Steve, before we finish today, would you be open to discussing your drinking habits?
Okay, what about it?

You completed a survey for us, which was very helpful. Thank you. I'd like to review a few things. I noticed you indicated drinking two to three times a week, three or four drinks per occasion, and sometimes consuming six or more drinks in a week.
Yes, on weekends.

I'm a little concerned about your drinking level. Excessive drinking can worsen existing problems or cause new health issues. Have you considered the connection between your drinking and the anxiety and insomnia you mentioned?
No, not really. I don't think I drink that much, so I doubt it's causing my anxiety.

It's common to think drinking aids sleep, but it can have a rebound effect. While it might help you fall asleep faster, it can lead to waking up in the middle of the night or early morning and struggling to go back to sleep.
I do wake up around 2:00 AM on nights I drink heavily.

This chart shows that for your age and gender, your drinking exceeds the low-risk level. For men under 65, low-risk is no more than 14 drinks a week and no more than four a day. A drink is defined as 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of spirits. You're actually in the high-risk category.
I didn't realize it was that bad.
That's why this information is helpful. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being 'no desire to change' and 10 being 'strong desire to change,' how ready are you to make changes?
I'm not sure. This is new information. I don't want to put myself at risk, and I consider myself healthy. I'd say a five.
That's a good starting point. What made you choose a five instead of a lower number?
I'm training for a marathon, which is why I'm here. I need to get my sleep back on track. I also don't consider myself a hazardous drinker or an alcoholic. Hence, the five.
I understand. So, your health is important, you're training for a marathon and want to succeed, and you were surprised to be in the high-risk category.
Yes.
Given this, what are you willing to do to change?
I suppose cutting back on my drinking.
What would that look like?
Maybe no more than three or four times a week, and on weekends, no more than five or six beers.
Writing down goals can be helpful.  If you were to set a goal for your drinking, what would it be?
Doing the math, I guess no more than 18 drinks a week.

That's a step in the right direction.  Keep in mind that 18 drinks still exceeds the low-risk category. My recommendation would be to aim for 14 or fewer per week eventually. But this is a good start, and I commend you for your willingness to consider this.
Thanks.
We can discuss your progress at your next appointment next month.
Sure.
Great.
There, um, what brings you in today?

I don't know. I'm just having a little bit of trouble dealing with my criminal history and trying to stay on the right path, but it gets kind of overwhelming. I really want to be a good productive member of society, but I got this background that nobody will overlook. So it kind of makes it like, what do I go back to what I know? I mean, you can only work for $5, $6, $7 an hour for so long, and it's really frustrating. It's causing some anger issues to resurface and some depression to resurface, and I don't want to fall back.
It's really getting in the way of you becoming who you want to be.
Yes, it is.
So what about your criminal record is blocking you from getting where you want to be?
I don't know what about it is.
Your record has a conviction?
Yeah. It has a felony conviction on it.
Okay. Ah, there's the big trouble. Yeah.
Yeah, it is. And it's-- I hadn't anticipated that it would have been-- You know, so at the time, it was just like, 'Okay, cool. I'm not going to jail.'
Mm-hmm.

You know, and, um, now, it's like, okay, so this is more like a life sentence than it was a four-year sentence that they were offering. You know, I mean, I think it would have been bad either way, but, um, I hadn't anticipated that this was going to be this difficult, especially since I went back to school and got a degree and actually want to do some corporate level or professional type of work.
Mm-hmm. So when you put in applications or anything like that, the felony conviction, whether you know it or not, seems to knock you out of the ballpark. You're not even considered as an applicant?

No, I'm not. Um, in situations where I don't know about it, I mean, if I'm not considered because of that, I probably-- Um, you know, that sucks too. Don't get me wrong. I mean, I-I don't- I don't get callbacks a lot because of that issue.
Mm-hmm, mm-hmm.

I'm sure. The ones that really count are, you know, are kind of just, you know, making me so angry and, you know, kind of spilling over into the rest of my life or the ones that I get face to face, especially after a really good interview.
Mm-hmm.
Black and white. It just stops right there. 'I'm sorry. I can't really do much for you. I-- You have to go,' you know, and it's.
So do you- do you, um, put out there about the felony conviction before you even go for the interview?

No. I mean, there's different situations, you know. Sometimes they ask and, you know, I'll say something like, 'We'll discuss at interview.' Uh, sometimes, there are situations where if I probably put that, I don't get a callback and those situations I don't know about. You know, but there are also times where I get an interview through, um, you know, uh, some sort of connection or something, or like a buddy of mine or a family member will send me on an interview. You know, I don't have to fill out an application for that. They just usually, you know, give you the interview. And at the end.
Seems like it's a done deal.
Yeah. It seems like it's a done deal. You just have to go through the motion of having the interview. And then.
Mm-hmm.

When I go through the interview and it goes well, and they're like, 'Okay, well, you know, I think we can do something' and then, 'Here, sign this, sign that,' and the other thing. And it's like, but we just had a great, you know, I mean, I qualify. Like.
Mm-hmm.
And.
So you didn't hurt anybody.
No, I didn't.
You didn't hurt anything, right?
It's really frustrating because.
Yeah.
It's almost like I-I don't want to give up, but it's like, I'm not given any other choice, you know?
Yeah, 'cause you're-you're, especially with going back to school and having done all that footwork and stuff. I mean, you really have something to offer somebody.
I do, yeah.
Yeah. And, um, and at the time the big crisis was actually maybe prison and all the crisis around the arrest and, uh, you know, it's like you're a leper and the leper colony.
Mm-hmm.
Um, have there been any times when you've started the interview with that conversation so that you don't even have to go through the whole thing and then get rejected?
Not that I can think of, no.
Mm-hmm.
I think.
What do you think would happen if you did that?
Probably get booted out right away.
Mm-hmm.
You know. Um.
Would that be, um, what would they be like versus getting through this great interview, knowing you're-you're good for the job and all that kind of stuff, and then they boot you out?
Well, it sucks either way. You know what I mean?
Mm-hmm. It's, uh, I mean the lesser of two evils is that what we're getting at?

Mm-hmm. You know what I mean? If it's going to make things more efficient like as if-if you're what you're trying to say is if that's something that I could do and then if they get past it, then now I know that there's an actual intention by the hiring people to hire.

Right. If that's a deal-breaker and you both know it from the very beginning, I'm wondering if then really the interview is really something else. I mean, whether they get the job would truly be based on the interview and not-not your criminal record.

Yeah, I think as far as maybe efficiency, you know, weeding out the things, not wasting my time, you know, but I had to tell you something, a lot of the people that don't care about that type of thing.
Mm-hmm.
Are not the sort of jobs that I really want to be doing. You know what I mean? Um, I don't know, it's just really frustrating.
Not like you're working for the government or for a bank or, you know, the FBI where those are not things you're applying for. They're jobs where you would wonder why a non-violent felony would even.
Be an issue.
Right.
Right, and then the other thing is anybody that I might tell that to.
Mm-hmm.
That doesn't care.
Mm-hmm.
Are probably not jobs that, you know, are worth going to get the interview.
Mm-hmm, you didn't go to college for that.
Right.
Mm.

Do you know what I mean? If I want to work at a moving company and I tell them off the bat, you know, from the gate, I tell them I have a felony conviction, just so you know before the interview and they don't really mind. I mean, that's great, you know, but at the same time, I don't- I'm not looking to be a mover or.
Mm-hmm.
A burger flipper or something like that. Not that there's anything wrong with it, but I feel like I have a little bit more to offer.
Mm-hmm.
You know, and, um, I don't know, it's a really, it's-it's like being caught between a rock and a hard place.
Mm-hmm. So, what have you looked into about, um, you know, advocacy in that area or expungement or anything like that?
I have done, and my eyes
Hi Liz, thanks for meeting with me today.
Sure.
So, what's something you'd like to change or work towards?
Well, I've been thinking about working out lately. I really want to start working out again. It's been on my mind, I know I need to do it. It's just getting the motivation.
It sounds like you've been giving this a lot of thought, and it's something you genuinely want to do.  It's understandable that motivation can be a challenge.
Mm-hmm. Yeah, it is.
So, if you could wave a magic wand and instantly have the ideal workout routine in place, what would that look like?
Wow, um... I guess I'd be going to the gym maybe three or four times a week, for about an hour each time.
That sounds like a great goal.  What makes that ideal for you?

Well, I know that's what's recommended for seeing results, and I used to do that. But honestly, the biggest hurdle is the time commitment. An hour at the gym turns into two hours with travel, and that's hard to fit in.

So, the time commitment feels like the biggest obstacle right now.  It sounds like you're already aware of what works for you in terms of frequency and duration, but the practicalities of fitting it into your schedule are the real challenge.
Exactly!  It's not that I don't want to, it's just finding the time.
Okay, so let's explore that a bit.  Instead of focusing on the ideal scenario right away, what's a small, realistic step you could take this week towards your goal?
Hmm... maybe I could try going just once this week, for maybe 30 minutes?
That sounds like a great starting point.  It's achievable and allows you to ease back into it. What day and time might work best for that 30-minute session?
Maybe Tuesday evening?

Tuesday evening sounds good.  So, you're thinking a 30-minute workout on Tuesday evening.  How confident are you that you can make that happen on a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is not at all confident and 10 is completely confident?
Probably a 7 or 8.  Things can come up, but I think I can manage it.
That's great! An 7 or 8 shows you're committed. What could help you move that up to a 9 or 10?
Maybe if I pack my gym bag the night before, so I'm ready to go.

That's a fantastic idea.  So, packing your gym bag the night before will help boost your confidence.  So, to recap, you're aiming for a 30-minute workout on Tuesday evening, and you'll pack your gym bag the night before to help you stick to that plan. How does that sound?
Sounds good.
Great.  We can check in next time and see how it went.  Remember, even small steps forward are still progress.
Okay, thanks.
You're welcome, Liz.  See you next time.
Before you go, do you mind if I take a look at the questionnaire you filled out before the visit?
Okay.
Thanks. I want you to know that whenever patients and I talk about alcohol and drugs, my role is to share information and learn from what they want to do, if anything. Does that make sense?
Yeah.
Great. So, you wrote here that you've used alcohol in the last year on at least eight days?
Yeah. Somewhere around eight days. I'm not sure.
Okay. How would you describe your drinking?
Um, I really only drink at parties. I don't drink at home or anything.
Okay. What kind of alcohol do you drink at parties?
Um, liquor, whenever people are mixing, um, vodka, sometimes beer, but I don't like beer very much. Um, the drinks at parties are usually like vodka and orange juice or gin and tonics.
How much do you think you usually drink at a party?
You mean the whole time I'm there?
Yes.
Um, probably four or five drinks.
Okay. You checked the box here that drinking helps you feel relaxed, feel better about yourself or fit in?
Yeah. It makes me feel relaxed.
And you also checked that sometimes you forget things when you drink.
Yeah.
What kind of things do you forget?
Um, I forget how many drinks I've had like when a friend asks me or I forget whose house I'm at.
Sometimes you forget where you're at.
Right.

Here's the part where I share information. The safest level of drinking for teenagers is zero drinks. That's because we know a number of negative things are more likely to happen when adolescents drink. We know alcohol can harm how the brain develops as an adolescent and teens who drink are more likely to hurt themselves by accident. Sexual assault is another thing more likely to happen and so are sexually transmitted diseases. I'm curious, do you think your drinking has anything to do with the possibility of having an STD?
Um, yeah. I was drinking the last time I had sex. Um, the guy had been drinking too, and we didn't use a condom.
Do you remember giving consent when you had sex?
Yeah. We've had sex before and we've used a condom before.
How do you think drinking alcohol affected using a condom this time?
Well, we just didn't stop to put one on. We weren't thinking that way.
Sounds like drinking changes how you think in those moments?
Yeah. I would've definitely told him to put on a condom if I was sober.

There's something else I want to share. When people forget where they are or how many drinks they've had, that's a sign of heavy drinking. And when people keep drinking despite experiencing negative consequences, that can be a sign of what we call alcohol use disorder.
Well, that's not me. I don't need help from anyone.
I'm curious. What do you like about drinking alcohol?
Um, well, it's fun. I like drinking when my friends are drinking too. Um, I laugh more. It's just fun.
Okay. And what about your drinking do you not like?
Um, I don't like forgetting where I'm at sometimes.
Anything else?
I really don't want any STDs.

Right. So, on one hand, you like the feeling of being relaxed and having fun when you're drinking and on the other hand, you don't like forgetting where you are or forgetting how many drinks you've had and you don't like putting yourself at risk for STDs?
Yeah.
So, when you think about what you like and not like about your drinking, where do you want to go from here? What would you like to change about your drinking?
Well, I definitely don't want to drink too much again.
How ready are you to not drink too much? If I asked you to pick a number on a scale of 0 to 10, and 10 being totally ready, what number would you pick?
Um, a nine.
Very ready to stop drinking too much. Why do you think you picked such a high number like nine rather than a lower number like a six or a seven?
Well, I really don't want any STDs and I don't like wondering whether I have one or not.
Okay. What plan could you come up with to make sure you achieve that goal?
Um, well, I want to count my drinks so I don't have more than two and I want to stop drinking once I start feeling drunk.
Great. Who could help you reach this goal?
Well, I have this friend who thinks I drink too much. She would probably be willing to make me promise not to have more than two drinks at a party.
Okay. And how about unprotected sex? It sounds like you don't want to experience that again.
I'm going to talk with him and I'm going to make him promise that we always use a condom and that we don't have sex drunk.

All right. So, you're very motivated to change your drinking and you have a plan to keep from drinking more than two drinks at parties and keep from having unprotected sex. I would like to share how it's working for you. What do you think about coming back in six weeks or so?
Okay.
Great. Thanks for talking with me and I look forward to seeing you again soon.
So, tell me about the exercise.
Well, since we spoke last, I've been to the gym a couple of times.
You have?
I have.
That's fantastic.
Yeah, and actually, my pants feel a little better too. I'm very pleased with it.
So, what else have you noticed other than your pants fitting better?
Um, I do feel better.
Mm-hmm.
My back—
Your... what?
Well, my back doesn't hurt nearly so much.
Wow.

And, um, but it seems like it's still hard. I'd like to go more often, or I guess I'm just need to be a little more patient with myself because it's, um, I'm not— I want to be able to spend more time at the gym, but right now, it's not— Well, I guess I need to build up to it.
Mm-hmm. So, what would help you get to building up to it? Spending more time there.
Um, well, I guess just sticking with it and not getting sidetracked.
Mm-hmm.
Like last week, I didn't get there at all until like Thursday during the week.
Mm-hmm.
So it was a frustrating week for the gym that way.
Mm-hmm.
I was kind of busy with some other things, but, um—
Mm-hmm. But you made it one day—
I got—
Instead of zero days.
Yeah, and actually, I made it again on Saturday too. So.
That's fantastic.
Yeah.
Even with this, you know, pretty hectic schedule going on.

Yeah. It's been a little hectic, you know. And, uh— But, I don't like it too much because there's all these younger guys that can lift a lot more weight than me or they can stay on the treadmill longer, and it's a little discouraging, you know. 'Cause I don't know if you've noticed, I'm not buff, and they are. And it's a little discouraging to think how much work it's going to take to get, you know, kind of back towards that.
So you'd like to get buff?

No, but, um, when I'm not at the gym, and I am my normal rational self, I realize that I'm, you know, way past the age where I would really even want to do that, let alone want to spend the time it takes. But then while I'm at the gym, and I see the buff young guys, you know, lifting a lot of weight and all that stuff, then, you know, the urge to be buff comes up in me.
So, but for right now, it sounds like just having the pants fit better—
Yeah.
Sounds really like it's making you feel good about yourself, and—
It is.
What other positive things have you noticed about the exercise?

Well, I noticed— Well, I still need to work on my diet a lot. I haven't— I'd like to say that by working out at the gym, I have modified my diet, but I haven't very much. I've gotten a little bit better with that, but I'd like to do a lot more.
In what way have you gotten a little bit better?

Um, a little bit less junk food. Um, like at times, when I feel like, 'Oh, I think I'll just go have a candy bar,' or some worthless thing like that, I'll actually have second thoughts before I do it.
So you're at the second thought part. And what do you think might take you over to actually doing it if you wanted to?
Well, I think when I really start seeing some results at the gym, it's kind of— I think the way it works in my mind is if I've worked out really hard and I've— say I've lost a pound that week—
Mm-hmm.

You know, and then as I'm looking at that double or triple fudge four-decker ice cream sundae thing, you know, that somebody is eating, I would say, 'Wow, that would be about two hours on the treadmill.' Then that would probably— the— that would—
Oh, okay. The payoff just wouldn't be worth those two hours of treadmill versus that double fudge brownie thingy.
Right, decadent— Why do they put the word decadent in food?
'Cause it is decadent, it's lovely.
Okay.
Yeah, yummy, so—

Okay. But it seems to be going so far so good. I guess, you know, I can, you know, um, I'm— I'm pretty pleased with how it's going on. Um, I'm really glad we talked that last time 'cause it was the impetus to get me to go the first time in a long, long time.
Okay, so I've prescribed an antibiotic for Aiden's ear infection.  It seems he's had quite a few of these in the past year.
Yeah.
That must be tough on both of you.  It sounds stressful.
It really is. He gets so upset.
I understand.  One of the main risk factors for frequent ear infections in children is exposure to smoke. Do you smoke?
Yes, I do. But I try really hard not to smoke around him.

I appreciate that.  It's great that you're aware of the risks.  Since Aiden is still getting these infections, it suggests he's being exposed to smoke somehow. Can you tell me more about your smoking habits and how you manage it around him?
I try my best. I never smoke in the car, and when he's home, I always go outside. I know it's bad for him, and I don't want him around it.

It sounds like you're really trying to protect him, and I commend you for that.  It's also understandable that quitting smoking can be incredibly challenging. Many people struggle with it.  It's important to understand that even smoking outside, while a good step, can still expose him to secondhand smoke through residue on clothing, hair, and in the environment.  This is sometimes called 'thirdhand smoke'.
I didn't realize that. I thought going outside was enough.

It's a common misconception.  It's great that you're already motivated to protect Aiden.  Quitting smoking is the most effective way to eliminate this risk.  It would also have significant benefits for your own health.  Have you considered quitting before?
I've thought about it, but it's really hard. I don't know how.

I hear you. Quitting is definitely a process, and it's understandable to feel overwhelmed. Many people find it helpful to have support and a plan.  We can work together to explore some strategies that might work for you.  There are many resources available, including nicotine replacement therapies like patches, gum, and lozenges, as well as medications that can help reduce cravings.  We can also discuss counseling and support groups.  Would you be open to exploring some of these options?
I guess. I'm just so busy. I don't know if I have time for all of that.

I understand that time is a precious commodity. However, consider this: How much time do you spend dealing with Aiden's ear infections?  The doctor's visits, the sleepless nights, his discomfort… Quitting smoking could potentially reduce these episodes, freeing up time and energy in the long run.  Also, think about how much time you spend on smoking itself.  Quitting could actually give you more time.
That's a good point. I hadn't thought of it that way.

It’s about finding what works for you.  We can start small.  Perhaps we could schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss this further and create a personalized plan.  No pressure, just a chance to explore some options.  How does that sound?
Okay. I think I could do that.

Great.  In the meantime, perhaps you could start thinking about what you find most challenging about the idea of quitting.  Knowing your triggers and what makes it difficult can help us tailor a plan that addresses your specific needs.  We’re in this together.  It’s a journey, and I’m here to support you every step of the way.
Okay. Thank you.

Well, I want to thank you for coming in today to see me. Um, I do understand from talking with your counselor that you've got quite a bit on your plate, you've got a lot going on. Can you tell me a little bit about that?

Well, um, I have a two-year-old son, and then I work full time as a server at a restaurant, and then recently, I also started going back to night class, so you know, just the combination of all that, you know. I-I've just been feeling really stressed lately.
Yeah, I could see that. Um, may I ask, are you also a single mom?
Yeah.

So you've got a lot of stressors right now. You're a single mom raising a two-year-old, you're working full time, and you're going back to school. What do you think would be the most helpful for us to focus on today?
Well, I-I told the counselor that I think childcare is probably my-my biggest issue right now.
Okay. Can you tell me a little bit about that?

Yeah. Um, well, my mom normally watches my son, but lately, it's kind of becoming a problem. You know, she like will back out at the last second, and so I've had to call in at work a couple of times. I've had to miss class a few times. So i-it's just stressful worrying about, you know, whether I'll be able to do those things or not.
Okay. So I'm hearing you say that the situation with your mom's not ideal. You actually miss class sometime and had to lose some work shifts as well, and that's problematic.
Yeah, exactly.
Okay. Um, outside your mom, is there anyone else that can help with childcare?

Um, well, I have a sister, but I don't really trust her to watch my son, and I don't really know that many people that-- the only thing I can think of, I have this one neighbor who stepped in and helped one time when my mom backed out. She-she actually has, uh, a three-year-old daughter, so you know, kind of worked out.
Okay.
Um, I don't really know her that well, but I mean, she seems nice and I-I think she did a pretty good job that night.
Hmm. So what I hear you saying is this neighbor was supportive when you really needed her to be.
Yeah.
Stepped in last minute. Um, when you picked up your son, you didn't have any concerns and he seemed happy?
Yeah.
Okay. Let's pursue that neighbor a little bit. Um, people like that, I like to think of as natural resources, but I know for a lot of people, the major problem with, uh, childcare is affordability.
Yeah.
Have you given any thought to, if you'll be able to afford to pay someone on a regular basis to watch your son?
I-- you know, I mean, maybe a little bit, but I don't really make that much money to be able to afford something like daycare or, you know, like full time babysitting.
Yeah, I can understand that. Um, what are some of your natural skills?
Well, I mean, I-I like cooking. I'm-I'm actually in school for culinary arts.

Oh, I bet you're a really good cook then. Um, what would you think about a plan where you worked out an arrangement with this neighbor, where in exchange for her watching your son, you would prepare dinner for her and her, um, daughter?
Mm-hmm.
Um, you know, you could maybe swap a meal for child care. What do you think of a idea like that?
Hmm. That's, that's interesting. I-I never really thought of something like that, but, yeah, it might work.
Okay. Okay, I'm glad you think so. Um, so, other than this neighbor, or is there anyone else that could help you?
Hmm. No, I-- you know, there-there just aren't that many people I trust right now with my son.
Okay, I can respect that. You-you really have to go with kind of your gut and follow your own intuition on that. Um, what about the baby's father, is he of any help?
[chuckles] No, no, not at all. He, he really hasn't been in the picture since my son was born.

Okay, fine. You know what? We've got one really good lead with the neighbor. I think if you would follow up in pursuing that, you might find some relief and resolve some of your childcare issues. Um, how many days a week are you in school?
It's-it's three nights right now, so I have class on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday nights.
Okay. Um, so what would it look like if you had a plan where both your neighbor and your mom were helping you out?
Um, well, you know, if my neighbor could even just take over one day of watching my son, I think that would help my mom quite a bit.
Okay. So what I'm hearing you say is that, if you could just reduce the amount of time that you're needing your mom, she might be more supportive, more onboard?
I mean, I think so, yeah.
All right. Um, so what do you think would be your next steps in working out a plan between your neighbor and your mom?

Mom, you know, just, I guess talking to my neighbor and seeing if she's even interested in this idea, and if she is, you know, telling my mom about it and, you know, hopefully, that will make her feel a little better and maybe a little bit more reliable.
Okay. Sounds like you got a good plan to follow up on there. All right. Um, now you mentioned that your son is two. When will he turn three?
Just a couple months from now. He's almost three.
Okay. Well, in that I-- in that case, I've got another idea for you. Um, what about, um, maybe when he turns three, you could enroll him in Head Start? Are you familiar with that program?
I've heard of it, but I don't know that much.

Okay. Head Start is a very affordable, very high-quality preschool program. Um, it was really created for parents and families, just like yours, folks who have a lower income and fewer resources, but Head Start really prepares your child both socially and intellectually for going to school. Um, and you know, by the time he turns three, you may find that that routine is something that's better for him to get used to before he starts kindergarten. Uh, would you like some more information on local Head Start sites?
Yeah, I mean, it sounds like it would be really good for my son and, you know, it would help me out in terms of childcare for sure.

Okay. Well, good. Um, all right. It sounds like you've got a good plan there going forward. Um, now I did see from the nurse practitioner's notes, you're also working on reducing your smoking and your drinking. How's that going?

[chuckles] Well, you know, I-I've been working on it a couple of weeks now, and honestly, it's been a lot harder than I expected. Um, trying to break my routine in the evenings, especially has-has been hard, but, um, you know, a couple of nights I have reached my goal in terms of, you know, number of cigarettes I'm going to smoke and number of drinks. So, I mean, I've done okay some days, but others, not so much.

Okay. So what I hear you say is that it was a bigger challenge than you expected, yeah, but you're working on it. You're-you're still committed to it. So yeah, that's really to be commended.
