Yeah, yeah. I definitely have, so I-I try to never smoke around him, and if I do smoke at home, I always go out to the balcony to smoke.
Oh, okay, good. You know, I can tell you really have your son's best interest at heart here. You know, just from our conversation today, I can tell you're a really good mom
Okay, hard part's over. So the good news is no cavities.
Oh, great.
Yes, always happy to hear that. I do have some concerns though because I'm seeing some irritation in your mouth in the palate that's called nicotinic stomatitis.
That sounds bad.
Yeah, it is. It's some damage to the roof of your mouth that happens from tobacco smoking and so I'm wondering if you can tell me a little bit about how tobacco fits in your life right now.

Tobacco. Well, I don't smoke cigarettes. I've never smoked cigarettes. I do go out with my friends. Um, you know, we go out to bars and, you know, we'll have a few drinks and smoke some of those little cigarillo-type things. I mean I wouldn't even think of them as cigars and they're certainly not cigarettes. Um, and I mean I'll have one or two of those in an evening with, uh, with my friends but certainly not 20 or 30 of them a day like you would with cigarettes and that's the only thing that could possibly have anything to do with tobacco.

So you've made a decision in your life not to smoke cigarettes, that's something you didn't want to do. It sounds like you're kinda concerned about the health effects of cigarettes. But you have been smoking the little cigarillos at least one or two every time you go out.

But that's- that's just like a- a social thing. That's something that my friends and I do. We-- We-- It's not habit or something that I have to have and, you know, talking about one or two when we go out for an evening. Not packs of them.
Yeah, so you're not-- You're not like those chain smokers, you're not smoking packs and packs a day.
Oh, no. No.
The amount you smoke is so miniscule you can't even imagine that it would cause any harm and yet here it is damaging the roof of your mouth.

Well, we've-- you have a point there. Mm, now that you mention it, um, I have started having one or two at work, you know, when we have break since I have a couple of friends at work that smoke and so every time we have a break, you know, we all go out to the- the break place outside, um, and so I- now I go with them and I have one of these Swisher Sweets. Um, I like the peach flavor they're so cute. But that's really only pretty recently.
Uh-huh. So smoking has kind of become a big part of your social life now. When you go out, you're smoking, and even during breaks at work, you're smoking.
Well, yeah, yeah. You know now that you say it like that it's true. Um, I am smoking on a daily basis.
So aside from that social aspect, what are the things you like about it?

Well, it's relaxing and it's just nice to be with people, um. Um, and you know, when, you know, I like to go to Las Vegas, and so when we go to Vegas, it's really fun to go to the cigar bars, is kind of sophisticated and fun and so, you know, it's mostly a social thing.
Okay.
I wouldn't say I was a chain smoker.
Okay. How about the other side? Have you noticed any not-so-good things about the smoking?
Well, I was going to ask you about, um, whitening my teeth because I've noticed that they have more stains on them than a few years ago, and so I imagine that has something to do with the smoking.
Yeah. So we're noticing some pretty negative effects in terms of your oral health with the smoking. Are there any other things that you're concerned about?

Um. Well, there's the expense, you know. With the economy and all, um, I- I have to be careful about my money and so, um, there is the extra expense of if I'm buying more of them than I used to. So the-the money aspect is also a concern.
Mm-hmm. So there's your oral health, there's the financial aspect, and then earlier you brought up some concerns about smoking cigarettes and how that can be harmful for you.
Oh, yeah.
Were you aware of the fact that smoking these little cigarillos, the Swisher Sweets, can have some of the same negative health effects?
Oh, absolutely not. I mean I thought of it more as a- a fun thing to do with my friends, certainly not a smoking habit or anything that would be harmful.
Mm-hmm. So it's kind of surprising to you that something you've been doing and you've been doing more and more of it is actually pretty bad for you.
Oh, yes. I checked the box on your form when you asked if I use tobacco, I checked 'No,' because I never thought of myself as a smoker.
Mm-hmm. What do you kind of make of that now that you realize that you're actually a tobacco user and that you might actually be causing some pretty serious health effects.

I'm really concerned, I mean, I don't want to, um, develop cancer, lung cancer, or any of the awful things that happen from smoking, and, you know, really, until this conversation, I never really thought of myself as a smoker at all.
Mm-hmm.
-I'm very concerned.

Well, the good news is in terms of the nicotinic stomatitis, at the point in which you stop smoking, you can actually reverse all the negative effects that occurred and you might also know that you can stop the progression of any other diseases that had started, just by quitting smoking.
Really?
Yeah. Is that something you'd be interested in?
Oh, I would. I really would because, like I said, I'm a brand new smoker. I didn't know I was a smoker until I came to see you.

Mm-hmm. Well, if you think about it on a scale of 1 to 10 where 1 is really don't think you could do it at all and 10 is really confident that you could quit if you tried, where do you think you fall?
Oh, I think I will probably be in seven or eight. I'm-I'm pretty confident that I could stop doing this.
Okay, what made you choose seven or eight as opposed to a-a five?

Because it's not a part of my daily life. I don't have to have, uh, a smoke when I get up in the morning. I don't smoke 20 or 30 of them a day, so it's not that much exposure and I-I feel pretty confident that I could stop.

Mm-hmm. So, it sounds like just to kind of summarize, you've noticed some negative effects of the smoking, you have some concerns about health effects that could occur, there's the financial aspect, and yet you feel pretty confident that you could quit if you tried. So, where do you think we should go from here?

Um, I'd really like some more information about quitting. I mean, I've heard there's some-some new medications, there are some new things that can be done to help people make quitting more comfortable and I-I really wanna quit.
Okay, well, I'd be happy to talk to you more about that and give you some tips and advice and give you some suggestions about where you can get some support with quitting.
That'd be wonderful. Thank you.
I really appreciate you talking to me about this today.
Thank you.
Hi, are you Katie?
Yeah.

Hi Katie, my name is Beth. I'm a nurse here.  I understand you filled out a health questionnaire while waiting to see Mrs. Smith, and it mentioned your marijuana use. Would you be comfortable talking with me about that for a few minutes?
Uh, sure. What's this about?
It's just a chance to explore how marijuana fits into your life.  No worries, this is completely confidential and not about getting you in trouble.  We just want to understand your perspective.
Okay.
I noticed you mentioned using marijuana regularly. Can you tell me a little more about how often and in what situations you use it?
Well, you know, they just decriminalized it, so it's not a big deal.  A couple times a week, just to relax.
So, it sounds like marijuana helps you relax, especially given you're a student here on an academic scholarship and on the debate team, which sounds like a lot of pressure.
Yeah. I mean, I'm the first in my family to go to college, so it's a lot.
That's a huge accomplishment, and it's understandable that you might feel some pressure navigating college life. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot.
I've always been kind of anxious, and pot just helps calm my nerves.
It sounds like anxiety is something you've experienced for a while, and marijuana has become a way to manage that.  Tell me more about what you find helpful about it.
Well, some of the other kids here seem to have it all together, and when I use pot with them, I feel like I fit in a little better.
So, it's also connected to feeling a sense of belonging and connection with your peers?
Yeah, I guess.
It sounds like fitting in is important to you, and you're hoping marijuana helps with that. How's that working for you so far?
I'm not sure it is.
That's interesting.  It sounds like there might be a disconnect between hoping it helps you fit in and how it actually makes you feel. What are some of the downsides you've noticed, if any?
Well, I get nervous I'll get caught. My parents would be really upset.
So, the worry about getting caught and your parents' reaction adds to your stress, rather than taking it away. Is that fair to say?
Yeah.
Are there any other downsides you've noticed?
Well, it's expensive, and I usually end up bumming it off my roommate, which is kind of embarrassing.

So, it also brings up feelings about your financial situation. It sounds like marijuana use has both some benefits and some challenges for you. It helps you relax, but it also causes stress related to fitting in, getting caught, and finances.  How do you feel about all of that?
When you put it that way, it doesn't sound so great.
It sounds like you're starting to see the bigger picture. Katie, you mentioned earlier that you've always dealt with anxiety. Have you ever considered talking to a counselor about that?
No. We don't really do that in my family.
I understand. Sometimes there can be stigma around counseling.  What are your thoughts about it?
It's just not something we do.  And it costs money, which we don't have.

I hear you.  Many students experience anxiety, especially in college, and counseling can be really helpful in developing coping skills.  Here at the college, we have free counseling services available to all students.  And it's completely confidential, so we wouldn't share anything with your parents unless there was a serious concern about your safety, like if you were thinking about harming yourself.
I would never do that.
I understand.  I just want you to know the limits of confidentiality.  Would you be open to learning more about our counseling services?
I don't know.
No pressure at all.  I just wanted to make sure you're aware of the resources available to you.  Would you be comfortable if I walked you over to the counseling center so you know where it is?
Okay, sure.
Great.  It's just down this hall.  We can stop by and I can introduce you to one of the counselors if you'd like, or you can just take a look around.
Okay.

Chris, I wanted to talk with you. As Athletic Director, I keep tabs on players to ensure everyone performs their best. I heard about a party this weekend and understand you were there. I'd like to discuss how partying and alcohol fit into your life right now.
Could I confide something that's been bothering me? Before the party, my parents, knowing I'm an honor student, kept me away from social life.
Mm-hmm.
About a month ago, friends invited me to a party, using my constant studying as leverage. I convinced my parents I'd sleep over at a friend's, which is when I started drinking.
Mm-hmm.

It was a unique experience. It was fun at the time, so I kept doing it. This past weekend, instead of studying for an exam, I asked my mom to go to another party. She suspected what I was doing and asked me to promise no alcohol or drugs, and that she'd pick me up by midnight. I was surprised, as that's when parties usually start, but I agreed. I was speechless and felt terrible for betraying her trust.
So, you're an honors student, a star athlete, and have done everything you've been told. Last month, you started getting more involved in the party scene.
Right.
It was fun initially, but now you're noticing consequences.
Yes. I've been more lethargic and apathetic towards schoolwork.
Mm-hmm.
I sit in class with my mind elsewhere, especially on weekends, when I'd rather find ways to get alcohol with friends.
It's changed your focus. What do you like about drinking?
I'm generally reserved, except in sports or social settings. I'm self-conscious.  Drinking relaxes me, and I can talk and engage with others more easily.
So, it helps you loosen up and feel more relaxed.
Exactly.
You've noticed negative aspects: your mom's upset, decreased focus, struggling in school...
Kind of.
Anything else?
My friend groups have changed. Some aren't into that scene.

I'm in one group, and I met people in another who invited me to that first party. Since then, I've been with them more, but I'm neglecting my other friends.
So, there's tension with your friends.
A little. Not all are into the party scene.
Given these changes affecting friendships, studies, and your relationship with your mom, what's your next step?
I should stop. I'm realistic; these situations happen.
Mm-hmm.
I shouldn't take it too far, like blacking out or getting sick. That's not worth it. I need to rebuild trust with my mom. It seems small to others, but it's big for me.
Your mom is important to you.
Of course.
Her opinion of you matters.
Exactly.
How important is it to adjust your drinking or quit?
Very important, to regain my mom's trust.
Okay.
And to improve my schoolwork and athletics.
Okay.
There's a future in that.
How confident are you that you can change your drinking, cut down, or quit?
Pretty confident.
On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being not at all and 10 being completely, what number?
Probably 8 or 9.
Okay.
It can't be 10; nothing is. But I'm determined.
Why 8 or 9, not 6 or 7?
I'm determined because I hate how I felt after betraying my mom. I hate the feeling of vomiting.
Mm-hmm.
It's unpleasant and something I don't want. Even if I drink, I don't want to get to that point. It's not worth it.
What's a realistic goal for you?
To prioritize studies and regain my mom's trust.
Mm-hmm.
Then focus on studies. In my leisure time, I can party with friends, but partying doesn't mean drinking. One drink won't ruin my life, but I'd prefer not to.
So, your goal is no alcohol, or at most, one drink at parties?
Exactly. To participate socially, but not excessively.

Chris, I appreciate you talking about this. It's been on your mind. I care about you as a student and athlete and want what's best. You have a good plan: no alcohol, or a maximum of one drink. It sounds like it will work.
Thank you for listening. It means a lot.
My pleasure. It's my job. I'll get ready for practice.
Hi, Sandra. Thanks for coming in. I know your time is precious, especially with your daughter in the hospital, so I appreciate you making time to talk.
Hi. Well, I came because of my daughter. I know I should quit, but it's hard. I enjoy smoking, and with everything going on, it feels like too much.

I understand. It sounds like you're juggling a lot right now, and quitting smoking feels like another burden.  It's completely understandable that it's not at the top of your list. Tell me, what made you decide to come in at all, even with everything else happening?
I feel like a terrible role model for my kids. My daughter's turning 12, and some of her friends are already trying smoking. I don't want her to think it's okay because of me.
So, you're really concerned about the influence your smoking might have on your daughter, especially at this age when she's starting to be more aware of these things.
Exactly. I started smoking young, and I definitely don't want that for her.
It sounds like you're torn. You want to be a good role model, but quitting feels overwhelming.  Let's explore that a bit. What are some of the things you enjoy about smoking?
It's relaxing. It helps with stress.  At work, we all go out for smoke breaks together, it's a social thing. I'd feel left out if I didn't smoke.
So, smoking is a way to relax, connect with colleagues, and manage stress. What else do you like about it?
I like having a cigarette after a meal. It's like a signal that I'm done eating. It helps me control my weight sometimes, too. I might have a cigarette instead of a snack.
So, it also helps with appetite control. Anything else?
Hmm, I guess I just enjoy it. It's a habit. I know it's not good for me, but I'm so used to it. I don't really think about quitting much.
Okay, so let me see if I understand. You enjoy the relaxation, the social connection at work, it helps manage stress and appetite, and it's a long-standing habit.  Have I captured everything?
Yeah, that's pretty much it.
Now, let's think about the other side. What are some of the things you don't like about smoking?
I worry about my kids. I feel guilty.  I don't want my daughter to start, especially since some of her friends already are.
Can you tell me about a specific time when you felt that guilt or concern about your daughter seeing you smoke?
Just this morning, I was outside having a cigarette, and I looked up, and she was watching me from the window.
That must have been difficult.  Seeing her watch you like that, knowing how you feel about her smoking, how did that make you feel?
Terrible. I want to be a good parent, and I know smoking isn't part of that.
It sounds like being a good parent is really important to you. And yet, smoking is also something you enjoy and rely on. How do you reconcile those two things?
I don't.  It's a constant struggle. I know it's wrong, but it's hard to imagine life without it.
So, it's not that you don't *want* to quit, it's more that you're not sure *how* to make that happen, or how to make it a priority with everything else going on.
Exactly.
Okay.  I understand.  We're about out of time for today, but I'd like to continue this conversation next week if you're open to it.  Would that work for you?
Sure, I guess so.

Great. Between now and then, I'd like you to try something.  Think about the top three reasons you might consider quitting.  Just jot them down.  And also, reflect on the good things about smoking and the not-so-good things, like we talked about today.  It doesn't have to be anything formal, just some thoughts. Would you be willing to do that?
Okay, I'll try.
Perfect. Here's a booklet with some information that might be helpful. Thanks for coming in, Sandra. I'll see you next week.
Thank you.

Dylan, thanks for coming in today. I understand from the university incident report that you were stopped on stadium road last Friday, cited for driving under the influence, and subsequently taken to detox.  The report also indicates you're 20 years old.  Can you confirm the accuracy of this report, and tell me a bit about what happened that evening?

Yeah, that's pretty much right. It was last week, and yeah, I was drunk. I drove over to a friend's place to watch the Vikings game. We had a few beers, and well, the Vikings weren't doing so great, so we ended up drinking more than we planned.  Then, at the end of the night, I couldn't get a ride home, so I drove.
So, if I understand correctly, you drank more than you intended because the Vikings were losing, and when your friend couldn't give you a ride, you decided to drive yourself home. Is that accurate?
Yeah, that's exactly what happened. I mean, I'm a normal college student. I like to drink with my friends. It wasn't even a big party or anything.  Just a few of us, and I still got caught.

I hear you. It sounds like you were just trying to have a good time watching the game with friends, and you probably didn't fully consider the potential consequences of underage drinking, especially since it was a small gathering and you tried to find a ride home.  It's understandable that you feel frustrated.
Exactly. I did try to be responsible. I even tried calling my friend for a ride. But it didn't work out, and now I'm in trouble anyway.
Dylan, you've told me what brought you here.  What do you see as the real problem?

Well, I wouldn't say I have a drinking problem. I think I have more of a getting *caught* problem.  I mean, my other friends drink just as much, and they never get caught.  It feels like I was just unlucky.
It sounds like you're attributing this situation to bad luck.  If you continue to believe that, and don't make any changes to your behavior, what do you think might happen down the road?
I guess...more trouble with the police and the school.  And I really don't have the time or money for that.
How important is it to you to avoid future problems with the police and the school?

Really important.  Going to detox was awful. I don't ever want to go through that again.  And my dad said if I get suspended, I have to go work on my uncle's farm in Iowa. That would be a social disaster.  Plus, my parents already took my car away after the DUI.
So, what would you be willing to do to avoid detox again and getting suspended?
I guess... the obvious thing is to not drink so much. And try to avoid situations where I'm more likely to get into trouble.
On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the most confident, how confident are you that you can stick to that plan?
Probably around a six. Maybe a little over halfway.
What steps could you take to move that six to a seven or an eight?

I guess... a big part of it is where I drink.  Like, if I only drink at my apartment, I'm not risking driving.  Or, if I go to a party, maybe wait until I'm 21. And maybe find other things to do besides drinking.  This town has got to have more going on than just that.
How might your life be better if you're successful in making these changes?

Well, I wouldn't be hungover all the time. I could actually make it to my 8 AM classes.  Even when I do go now, I just end up sleeping through them and missing everything.  If I could re-prioritize what's important, I think I could do better in school. I had a 3.5 GPA in high school, so I know I'm capable of it.
College is about choices.  Tell me about the values that are important to you, and how those values connect with your decisions about drinking.

Education is really important to me, and my family too. My parents are always talking about it. I really want to be an international journalist.  So, if I can re-prioritize and not drink so much, I won't disappoint my parents, and I'll have a better chance of getting a good education.
Thanks for sharing that, Dylan.  So, the university's decision is that you'll be placed on disciplinary probation and you'll need to attend an alcohol education seminar. The seminar fee is $150.
Okay. When is the seminar?

Dylan, the Minnesota State Mankato security report indicates you were stopped on stadium road last Friday, cited for driving under the influence, and transported to detox.  The report also lists your age as 20. Is this report accurate? Can you tell me about what happened that night?
Yeah, it's pretty much all true.
Okay, I understand. It sounds like a difficult situation.  Can you tell me a bit more about what led up to the incident?
Well, I was at a party...
Okay. So, it sounds like you were at a party, and then you were driving. Is that right?
Yeah.
And how much had you had to drink that night?
I don't know, a few beers maybe?
A few. Okay. So, thinking back to that night, how do you feel about the choices you made?
Not good. I messed up.
It sounds like you're feeling some regret.  Is that fair to say?
Yeah, definitely. I could have hurt someone.
That's a very real concern, and it shows you're taking this seriously.  It's good that you recognize the potential consequences.  What are your thoughts about drinking and driving in general?
It's stupid. I know that. I just didn't think...
It sounds like you know the risks, but maybe in the moment, it was hard to make the best decision. Is that something you've struggled with before – making good decisions about alcohol?
Sometimes. I mean, everyone drinks at parties.

It's true that drinking is common, especially in social situations. But everyone's different, and everyone's body reacts differently to alcohol. What have you noticed about how alcohol affects you specifically?
I get… loud.  And I make bad choices.

Loud and making bad choices.  So, it sounds like you have some awareness of how alcohol changes your behavior.  That’s a really important insight. What do you think might be helpful for you going forward to avoid situations like this?
I guess… not drink so much? Or not drive after drinking at all.
Those sound like some really good starting points.  So, if you were in a similar situation again, what could you do differently?
I could… call a cab. Or a friend.
That's a great idea. Having a plan is really important. It sounds like you're already thinking about some positive changes. What feels most important to you about making these changes?
Just… not screwing up my life. And not hurting anyone.
Those are powerful motivators. It sounds like you have a strong sense of responsibility.  What do you think might get in the way of making these changes?
My friends. They'll think I'm lame.

That's understandable. It can be tough when your friends are doing something different. But it also sounds like you're starting to think about what's important for *you*.  What do you think is more important – fitting in, or staying safe and avoiding these kinds of situations?
Staying safe, I guess.
It sounds like you're really starting to connect with why these changes are important for you.  What's one small step you could take this week to move in the direction of those changes?
Maybe… talk to a friend who doesn't drink much.
That's a great idea.  Connecting with someone supportive could be really helpful.  We can also talk more about resources and strategies in our next session. How does that sound?
Okay.
Molly, thanks for coming in to talk with me today.
You're welcome.
I understand from your mom that you've been having some difficulties with other kids at school, some bullying and things like that. That must be tough.
Yeah. I've missed two days of school already because of it.
Missing that much school is significant.  It sounds like things are escalating.
And even when I'm out, rumors start.  Like last time, I was supposedly in the principal's office all day with security guards, which wasn't true at all.
It's frustrating when people spread untrue stories.
It's been happening since fifth or sixth grade. I get blamed for everything.
Why do you think that is? What kind of things do they blame you for?
I think it's because I tend to engage. Like if someone tells me something, I don't just let it go. I want to talk about it, and I think some kids see me as an easy target.
So, tell me more about this 'engaging.' Can you give me an example?

If someone says, 'I heard something about you,' I'll ask, 'Oh really? What is it?' and I just keep it going.  Or if someone says they want to beat me up, I might say, 'Okay, then hit me.' I don't walk away.
And what usually happens when you don't walk away?
It usually escalates.  If I just stopped it, maybe they wouldn't know what to say. But if I keep talking, it builds up, and then we both get in trouble and sent to the principal's office.
So, what's it like for you after you've been in the principal's office?
I usually tell myself I should just let it go next time.
Mm-hmm.
But if someone says something about me, it makes me mad.  I try to stop myself, but sometimes I still say things. I'm trying to get better, though.
You mentioned trying to get better. Tell me about a time recently when you handled a situation differently.
There was this one time someone was talking to me, and I just said, 'Wow, this is really lame. I'm just going to leave.' And I did.
That's great. How did that feel?
I felt proud of myself.
You should be. What helped you do that?

I thought about how my mom gets mad when I don't let things go. She tells me to leave it be, but I don't always listen. So I tried to think about her feelings and what would happen if I just walked away. They stopped talking to me, and I didn't get in trouble.
It's impressive that you can consider your mom's perspective like that.
Yeah.
That's a real strength. So, this time you thought about your mom, you walked away, you felt proud, and nothing bad happened. Is that right?
Yeah.
Does it usually work that way?
Yeah. They stopped talking to me.  The funny thing was, these were eighth graders who don't even go to my school. I don't even know how they started talking to me. It was weird.
So, when someone told you that you're an easy target...
They don't really say that to me directly. I just think that's what it is because that's what I've heard from my mom, and because I keep engaging with them.
Okay, so they know how to get a reaction from you.
Yeah.
And then things escalate, and you get in trouble.
Yeah. It happens a lot.
So, you know that 'channeling your mom' helps. What other ideas do you have about what you could do?

I was thinking that if something happens at school during class, I could ask to use the restroom just to get away and think about how to handle it.  Like in gym class, there was this girl I'd had trouble with before. We were playing pickleball, and I just told my gym teacher quietly that I couldn't be near her and asked to move to a different court.  He let me switch.
That was a really good decision.
The girl was annoyed, though.
But it was smart of you to recognize that something bad might happen if you had to play with her.
Yeah. I probably would have smacked her or something.
You knew that about yourself.
Yeah.
So you know which kids tend to push your buttons.
Yeah, there are a few.
That's okay. The important thing is for you to be happy and safe.
Yeah.
So, it sounds like you've got some good strategies already.  It's tough, though. Kids can be mean.
Yeah.
I'm wondering if you'd like to meet again to talk more about this. You've got some good ideas, and I'm also open to you bringing a friend along if that would be helpful.
Yeah, there's one friend who might want to talk about some stuff. She doesn't have a lot of support at home.
Okay. I want this session to be primarily for you, Molly, but I'm also happy to talk with your friend. It sounds like she could use someone to listen.
Yeah.
We can explore some other ways to help you deal with this, because it sounds like some kids are being really unfair to you.
Mm-hmm.
So, would you be willing to come back and talk some more?
Okay.
Great. I also want to tell you that I think you're doing a great job handling a really difficult situation. High school is tough.
Yeah.
It is. I think things can get better.  I'm glad you're involved in swimming and other activities.  Those kinds of things can connect you with good people.
Yeah.
Okay, is there anything else you want to talk about today?
No.
Okay. Thanks, Molly.
Hello, it's good to see you again. What brings you in today?
I'm concerned about my drinking. I think I'm drinking too much, and I'd like to talk to someone about it and get some help.
So, it sounds like you feel your drinking has become a problem for you.
Yes, it's gotten worse over the past six months.
What makes you say it's gotten worse?
Well, I used to drink like most people, but I broke up with my boyfriend about a year ago.  Six months ago, I started going out again to meet people.
Okay.
And I've gotten into this habit of going out every Friday and Saturday, drinking a lot to try to meet guys.
I see.
And lately, I've been drinking more on weeknights, which I never used to do.
So, you've noticed an increase in your drinking over the past six months, particularly since you started going out again to meet someone.
Yes. I'm not comfortable talking to guys normally. Drinking helps.
So, it sounds like drinking helps calm your nerves when you're trying to meet potential partners.
Yes, definitely.
Potential partners as in men?
Yes.
Okay.
I mean, I guess most people drink when they go out.
That's common.
But I've been drinking more and more, and it's not even working. I'm not meeting anyone, and I just end up with a massive hangover all weekend.

That's frustrating. It sounds like on the one hand, drinking helps you feel more comfortable talking to men, but on the other hand, it's not actually helping you meet anyone, and it's leading to hangovers.
Exactly. I might talk to someone, but I'm usually too drunk. My friends drive me home, and the night is a blur.
So, what would you like to do about this?
I want to stop. I'm drinking more and more, even on weekdays, and I don't want to do that.
Okay.
I'm not eating properly anymore. I'm eating less or just getting takeout food. I'm not exercising like I used to, either. I want to cut back on my drinking.
So, it sounds like you really want to stop drinking, especially on weekdays.
Yes, I do.
Because you've noticed it's negatively impacting your eating and exercise habits.
Yes. I don't want to stop altogether, though.
I understand. It sounds like drinking has some benefits for you, like the social aspect of going out with friends.
Yes, and all my friends drink. I wouldn't have a social life if I didn't drink at all. I don't feel like I'm an alcoholic.

So, you enjoy the social aspect of going out with friends, and you don't want to give that up completely. It sounds like you want to find a balance where you're not experiencing negative consequences.
Yes, it's just gotten a bit out of control.
Have you tried to cut back on your drinking in the past?
No, this hasn't happened before.
So, this is the first time you've experienced this.
Yes. Before, I was in a relationship for six years. My friends weren't drinking as much then. It's all new.
Okay. It's good that you've identified what's happening and that you've noticed the pattern with your drinking.
Mm-hmm.
On a scale of 0 to 100, where 100 is extremely important and 0 is not important at all, how important is it for you to cut back on your drinking?
I'd say 80. That's why I'm here.
80 is quite high. What makes it an 80 rather than a 50?
It just got to a point where it felt like too much.  No one else is drinking as much as I am during the week. I need to do something about it now.
So, you have a strong sense of needing to make a change.
Yes. I'm worried it will get worse.
So, over the last six months, you've noticed this pattern, it's had negative impacts on your lifestyle, and you're ready to make a change.
Yes.
What do you think the next step is?
That's why I'm here. I think cutting back on weekdays is what I really need to do.
Okay.
And then maybe try to plan things out a bit more on weekends so it doesn't get out of hand.
So, you're thinking about keeping weekdays alcohol-free?
Yes, exactly.
How does that sound as a first step?
Good. That's definitely what I want to do. I'm out of routine with exercise and everything. I need to get back into things.
You sound motivated to make a change.
Yes, talking about it makes me realize I need to do something.
That's excellent.
Thanks for coming in. Tell me what's been happening since we last spoke.
Well, I, um, I did get an interview for a job.
That's great!
Yeah, but I wasn't able to go, um, because of my kids. I didn't have anyone to watch them. So, I had to cancel the interview. It's too bad because it was a job that would have been good.
You sound disappointed.
Well, yeah, because I didn't really have a choice. I have to make sure my kids are taken care of first. I'm worried this is going to keep happening.
It's going to keep happening that you have to turn down opportunities?
Yeah.
Tell me, on a scale from one to 10, how important is it for you to get a job?
About a 10. I'm the only one supporting my kids, and what I'm getting from welfare is not enough. I really need a job soon.
You have to provide for your children.
Mm-hmm.
On a scale from one to 10, how confident are you that you could get a job?
Right now, about a three. Even if I get an interview and find childcare, my resume isn't impressive. It has employment gaps, and I'm not as educated as other applicants. I don't feel employable.
So, the childcare issue has been getting in the way, and finding something that works would be helpful. You're also feeling not so great about your resume and experience.
Yeah. It's so limited, and I've been out of the workforce. Even when I was working, it's not stuff that I feel can lead to the job I want now.
What is it that you want?
Something steady where I can be home every night with my kids. I'd like something where I'm making good money and I don't have to worry about money all the time.
If you had consistent work, it would change your life in a lot of ways.
Yeah. It would be huge.
It would provide the income you need, and you wouldn't worry so much.
Yeah. It'd be nice to just know what I'm doing and have my routine.
Every day you know where you're going.
Yeah.
What would it take to get you to a five in confidence, to feel more confident about getting work?
Being able to make the interviews would be the priority.
Okay.
Having childcare, having someone I trust that I can call when I know I have an interview.
You definitely need to go to an interview to get the job. Having reliable childcare would definitely help.
Yeah.
What else would get you to a five?
I wish I had more experience or more education. Everyone seems to have a college education, and I don't have that on my resume.
Okay.
I get asked about education and training, and as soon as I am, I feel like I'm not good enough since I don't have it.
If you had something on your resume about education or training, maybe a certificate in a field you're interested in, you would feel proud.
Yeah. Something I could talk about in the interview. Even a certification where I could confidently talk about it.
Do you have any ideas what fields you might be interested in?
I don't really know. I need a job now, so I'm not sure.
What's going to be fastest?
Right. It's almost more important than what I'm interested in. I'm not going back to school for four years right now.
If you were going to do something, you'd want something quick, like a short certificate.
Yeah, something that would get me immediate skills for some kind of job now, even if it's not my long-term goal. Just get me into something, and then I can focus on other things.
A short-term thing to transition into something else.
Yeah, exactly.
That would be steady and pay well?
Mm-hmm.
Allow you to afford everything you need?
Yeah. Even those jobs don't feel accessible. It seems like maybe if I were better on the computer...
Getting some computer skills would help?
Yeah. I think so because I don't have anything on my resume about technology.

So, getting a job is really important right now. You need the money and to take care of your children. You have some ideas about getting to interviews, and feeling more confident about your skills. Reliable childcare is very important.
Yeah.
As well as maybe a certificate or classes in computers?
Yeah, that would be great.
What would you like to do next?
Find childcare resources. That seems to be the priority.
That's a priority.
Because I can't even do an interview without that. And then, getting into some kind of short training program.
Yeah.
Like maybe a weekend program.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit frustrated with the cycle of losing and regaining weight.  It's completely understandable to feel that way.  Many people experience similar challenges.

Yeah, it's just so discouraging. I feel like I'm constantly fighting a losing battle.  Work is crazy busy, and with the kids, I barely have time for myself, let alone trying to cook healthy meals or exercise.

It sounds like you have a lot on your plate.  It's commendable that you're even thinking about your health amidst everything else.  It's not about being perfect, but about finding small, sustainable changes that can fit into your life.
That's what I keep hearing, but I honestly don't know where to start.  Everything feels overwhelming.

Totally.  So, instead of trying to overhaul everything at once, how about we explore just one small area where you might be willing to make a change?  Something that feels manageable, even with your busy schedule.
Hmm... I guess I could maybe try to be a little more active. I used to enjoy walking, but I haven't done it regularly in ages.

Walking is fantastic!  It's accessible, and you can adjust the intensity and duration to fit your needs.  No need for a gym membership or special equipment.  Even short bursts of walking can be beneficial.
Yeah, I suppose I could try walking during my lunch break at work.  There's a park nearby.

That's a great idea!  Even 15-20 minutes a few times a week can make a difference.  It's not about doing hours of intense exercise, but about incorporating movement into your day in a way that feels doable.
Okay, I can try that.  But what about food?  That's where I really struggle.

We can definitely talk about nutrition, but let's focus on the walking for now.  Making one change at a time can be more effective than trying to tackle everything at once.  Once you've established a walking routine, we can explore some small, manageable adjustments to your diet.
That sounds much less daunting.  So, just the walking for now?
Exactly.  Focus on finding a rhythm with the walking, and we'll check in next week to see how it's going.  We can then brainstorm some ideas for healthy eating that fit your lifestyle.
Okay, I think I can do that.  Thanks.
You're welcome!  Remember, this is a journey, not a race.  Be patient with yourself, and celebrate the small victories along the way.
Welcome. My name is Mark, and I work here at Green Prescriptions.
Thank you.
I know a little about you from the referral letter from your doctor.
From my GP?
Yes, from your GP. But before we get to anything, I'd like to ask you a little about what led you to come here today and get an idea of what's been going on for you.
What's led me to come here?
Yes.
My GP.
And what did he have to say?
Well, I had my checkup, and it revealed that apparently, I might have type 2 diabetes. That's what he says.
Right.
I think I feel perfectly well. I understand people with diabetes are a little plumper than I am.
Mm-hmm.
But that's really why I'm here. I'm almost on his command.
Right, so he gave you a directive?
Well, he did. He says he's going to put me on some sort of program if it gets worse.
Mm-hmm.
But as I say, I feel absolutely fine now.
So it came as a bit of a surprise, you feeling okay.
Yeah.
You go for this checkup with the doctor, and he says, 'You have type 2 diabetes.'
Mm, I was very surprised.
Mm. Came out of the blue for you?
Yes, I think it did.
Mm.
Mm.
And you said you don't fit that type 2 diabetes image, that you've had this idea-
I-
of being overweight with it.
That's what I understand.
Mm.
You know, and I'm not overweight.
Mm.
I sort of look after myself to a limited extent in that way. But I'm a busy person, I suppose I burn off the calories.
Mm.
I don't know, really.
Mm.
My lifestyle-
Hmm. So it doesn't quite fit in your head, type 2 diabetes and-
No.
your lifestyle?
No, not at all.
Comes as a big surprise. What was your reaction when he told you that?
Well, I thought he must be joking, to be honest.
Mm.
I thought, you know, why would you-- Look around you.
Mm, mm.
I just felt that-- I mean, I don't think he was wasting my time because why would he do that?
Yeah, yeah.
Right?
He's got a lot to do.
Absolutely right.
Mm.
He's got a job to do. And obviously, the tests have come through, and I have these signs of diabetes 2.
Right.
Right? I just think that-- Well, I just don't feel like it, Mark.
Mm.
Um-
So how do you feel in your head-
I feel absolutely fine.
-and what the tests say kind of don't match up.
Yeah. Well, physically, I feel absolutely fine.
Mm.
I'm-- I didn't see anything wrong with me at all.
Hmm.
I mean, I get around, I sleep pretty well-
Hmm-hmm.
I sort of, you know-
Hmm.
I'm-I'm compos mentis. So I don't-
Yeah. What's the problem? Mm.
What is the problem?
And how did this happen is probably what you're also thinking. Well, how did this--?
Well, uh, yes. I mean-
Mm.
-I must admit, I haven't done too much research. I've been a bit busy.
Okay.
Um, but he was saying something about, I don't know, family or whatever. I don't know.
Yeah.
And I don't know if it's hereditary.
Mm.
I think he said something about it being hereditary.
So he mentioned it might be a family thing, and so you-
Yeah.
maybe got it from your parents or something of the sort.
Yeah, it could be-
Mm.
-because my mother mentioned-
Mm.
-that my father had diabetes-
Right.
-diabetes 2. And if I think about it, his brother-

-I haven't seen him for years.

But he might well have it because he is-

-a pretty big guy. You know-
Right.
He's pretty big.
So he fits the picture-
Well, yes, the stereotype-
-when you think about what he-- Yeah, he's stereotypical.
Yeah, I guess.
A little bit bigger, perhaps doesn't look after himself that well, and he fits that picture.
Well, yeah. I mean, as far as I know, I hadn't seen him for-
Yeah.
-I don't know how many years.
Mm. So you have this knowledge that there's some family history of diabetes in the past?
Apparently so. Yes, apparently so.
The doctor mentioned that as being a factor.
Mm, I mean, is it hereditary?
That's certainly true. Yes. We know that people who've had it in the past, there is a hereditary or genetic factor involved.
A genetic factor. So, does that mean that if you have a history of this in your family-
Mm.
-if it's a gene-- you are more likely than not to get it?
Correct. Yeah.
Also, it's-
But it's not inevitable.
Right. Okay.
Because the genes or the hereditary factor is not the only factor that causes it. So there are other factors that come into play.
I'm sure you're going to tell me what they are.
Well, you've mentioned some things you know, one being hereditary. What else do you know or have you heard? You say you haven't had much time to research.
To be frank, Mark, I honestly don't know. I mean, I honestly don't know what causes it because I've never had any reason to think about it. It came upon me from the GP and it took me back.
Yeah.
The hereditary thing I thought, well, maybe that's the explanation.
That makes sense.
And why go any further, it's there?
Yeah.
Can't help it.
Yeah.
They lived pretty long lives, they did, all right.
They managed with it.
Relatively went into their 70s.
Okay. Would it be helpful if you knew a little more about the factors involved in type 2 diabetes?
Well.
If that would help.
If there's something you think that-- Yes. Yes, of course.
Well, I'll share what I know from working with others and some of my experiences.
Okay.

And see what you make of it. See if it fits with where you're at. We know there's a strong family or hereditary factor. It tends to happen later in life, not when you're a teenager. So it's a later onset. It takes time to develop. The main aspect is insulin. Have you heard of it?
Well, I'm here because my mom wants me to be here.
Mm-hmm.
I don't really wanna be here, but it-it-- whatever.
Got it.
Um, she-she found my stash-
Uh-huh.
-and she freaked out, and she's going crazy over it. Um, I don't know why she was going through my stuff in the first place, but whatever, so, now I'm here.
Mm-hmm.
Um, I've been hanging out with a new cool crowd of people that I really like.
Mm-hmm.
And that's basically it.

Yeah. So you've got this new group of friends and, um, you actually kind of like where you're at with things right now. And your mom was going through your stuff and found your stash, and it's just turned into this.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah, basically.
Yeah.
Mm-hmm.
And, uh, sounds like you're pretty upset with your mom for doing that?
I am.
Yeah.
I mean, it's my stuff, I don't know why she's-
Right. It's like your private space and, you know, it's-- that's-- it's your stuff.
I-I don't go- I don't go through her stuff. I don't go through her purse. I don't-
Yeah. So why should she go through yours?
Right.
Yeah. Yeah.
Okay, I've finished the exam. I have some good news and some not-so-good news. Looks like you don't have any cavities, so that's the good news.
That's great.

However, I'm a bit concerned about something I'm noticing in your mouth. If you look up here, at the roof of your mouth, I'm noticing some irritation that's often associated with tobacco use. You mentioned on your form that you don't use tobacco, so I'm wondering what might be contributing to this.
I don't smoke cigarettes.

Okay. Well, as I said, there's some irritation, particularly on the roof of your mouth. It's a bit discolored and there are some small red spots. You probably haven't noticed, as we don't often look at the roof of our mouths, but this could be damaging the tissue and potentially cause some oral health problems. It's sometimes called nicotinic stomatitis. We typically see this in patients who use tobacco. So, perhaps you're not smoking cigarettes, but are you using a pipe or cigars, or is there anything else that could be contributing to this?
Well, the only thing is... I've never smoked cigarettes, but when I go out with friends, we sometimes go to lounges.
Mm-hmm.
And, you know, sometimes there are people who offer us these little cigars, like Swisher Sweets. They come in different flavors. That's the only time I ever really use anything with tobacco in it.

Okay, so it sounds like you might be referring to flavored mini cigars. It's a common misconception that because they're flavored, they're not as harmful.  Did you know they still carry similar risks?
Really?  They're just small, flavored cigars.
They are still cigars, and they still contain tobacco.  They carry similar risks to cigarettes, including the potential for oral cancer and other health issues.
Well, I only use them when I'm out socializing. It's not like I smoke regularly.

I understand. It's good that it's not a daily habit, but even occasional use can still cause problems.  I can see some changes in your mouth that suggest some damage is occurring. Have you considered quitting altogether?
Well, I didn't really think I had started a habit.
What do you mean?
I didn't really think of it as anything more than just something I do socially, like having a drink with friends.
So, what are your thoughts about quitting?
Maybe.
I understand it's something to think about.  Given what we've discussed about the potential risks, what makes you hesitate about quitting completely?
Well, it's just something I do to relax when I'm out, and it's not very often. I could probably cut back.

Cutting back is a good thought, and it can be a helpful first step. However, complete cessation is the most effective way to reverse the changes in your mouth and eliminate the risks associated with tobacco use.  What are your thoughts about that?

Well, I'm not sure they are really cigars. And I feel it's my choice what I do, and I'll think about cutting back, but I'm not ready to quit completely right now. I'm also not completely convinced about the risks you're describing.

I understand your perspective. It's important to have all the information to make informed choices. The changes I'm seeing in your mouth are consistent with what we see with tobacco use, regardless of the form.  It can affect your teeth and overall oral health.  It's a decision you're making about your health, and even occasional use can pose risks.  What would help you feel more confident about the information I'm sharing?
I'm not sure.

That's okay. I'm here to support you in any way I can.  Perhaps we could discuss some resources that provide more information about the risks of tobacco use, even occasional use.  Would that be something you'd be open to?
Maybe.

Okay.  I appreciate you considering this.  I'll check in with you at your next visit to see how you're doing and if you have any further questions or concerns.  In the meantime, is there anything else you'd like to discuss today?
No, I think that's all.
Okay.  Thanks for coming in today.
The baby was up all night and I'm exhausted.
That sounds incredibly tough.  Lack of sleep can really take a toll.
Yes. She was up every three hours to eat, I don't understand it.

It's completely understandable to feel that way.  Caring for a newborn is demanding, and the sleep deprivation can be overwhelming.  It's common for babies at this age to still be feeding frequently throughout the night.
Yes. My mom told me that I started sleeping through the night when I was a month old, Lilly is six weeks.

It sounds like you're comparing Lilly's sleep patterns to your own as a baby. It's important to remember that every baby is different, and what was true for one baby isn't necessarily true for another.  Developmental milestones, including sleep patterns, vary widely.
Well, what is normal for a baby this age?

That's a great question.  At six weeks, it's very common for babies to still be waking up frequently throughout the night to feed.  Their little stomachs are small, and breast milk and formula are digested quickly.  Also, their sleep cycles are different from adults.  They spend less time in deep sleep and more time in lighter sleep, which makes them more prone to waking.  While some babies might start sleeping longer stretches earlier, it's also perfectly normal for them to still be waking every few hours at this stage.  There's a wide range of what's considered 'normal'.
So, it's not unusual that she's still waking up every three hours?

Absolutely not.  It's very typical.  Many parents experience similar challenges.  It's understandable to feel frustrated when you're exhausted, but it's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and Lilly's sleep patterns are likely to change and evolve as she gets older.
Okay.  I guess I was just hoping for more sleep by now.
It's perfectly natural to hope for more sleep.  Sleep deprivation is incredibly challenging.  What are some things you've tried so far to manage the nighttime feedings and get some rest yourself?
Well, I'm breastfeeding, so my husband can't really help at night.  And I've tried putting her down in her crib when she's drowsy, but she usually wakes right back up.

It sounds like you're doing your best to manage the situation. Breastfeeding is wonderful for both you and Lilly, but it can be more demanding in terms of nighttime feedings, especially in the early weeks.  Have you considered talking to a lactation consultant about strategies for managing nighttime feedings and maximizing rest? They might have some helpful suggestions tailored to your situation.
No, I haven't. I didn't think of that.

It could be a valuable resource.  They can offer support and guidance on breastfeeding techniques, optimizing feeding schedules, and even discuss strategies for partners to be more involved, even if they aren't breastfeeding directly.  They can also validate your experience and help you feel more confident in your approach.
That sounds helpful. I think I will look into that.

That's a great idea.  Remember, taking care of yourself is just as important as taking care of Lilly.  Prioritizing your well-being, even with limited sleep, can make a big difference in how you're able to cope with the demands of parenthood.  We can also talk more about other strategies for managing sleep deprivation and finding support if you'd like.
Yes, that would be great.

Hello, Kaylie. I'm Lori, the pharmacist here at Bulldog Pharmacy. I see that you have a new prescription for cholesterol statin 20 called in by Dr. Ferris today. I wondered if you had a minute to talk to me. I just want to make sure that you know how best to take it, and if you have any questions.
Sure. I'm just getting a few groceries.
Okay. What did the doctor tell you cholesterol statin is for?
Well, he told me that I had a blood test for cholesterol, and that I should start taking this.

He's right. This medicine is designed to help lower your cholesterol, and that means that it will help lower your risk of having a heart attack or a stroke. How did your doctor tell you to take this medicine?
He didn't really tell me. He just phoned it in.
Okay. Well, you're going to take one tablet of cholesterol statin 20 one time a day by mouth, and you can take that with or without food. When do you normally take your medications?
Well, I take all of my other medications right before I go to bed. So I guess I could take it then.

Okay. That's perfect because cholesterol statin works best if it's taken at night, though you can take it any time of the day. And you should take it every single day. It's important to keep that up. Where do you store your medications?
I store my medications, uh, in my nightstand, right by my bed.
All right. Do you have any children in your home?
No.

Okay. Well, then that sounds like a perfect location for you. Medicines keep best if they're stored away from light and heat and moisture. What did the doctor tell you to expect in terms of side effects?
He didn't mention anything about that.

All right. Well, this medication is pretty well tolerated, which means it doesn't have very many side effects. But you might experience some mild muscle aches and pains. If they seem really severe to you, then you should call Dr. Ferris and talk to him about that. Also this medicine can interact with a lot of other medications, and even over the counter things. So check with the doctor or myself before you start anything new. And lastly, grapefruit juice can interact with cholesterol statin 20. So if you use grapefruit juice every day, I probably would switch to a different juice while you're on this medication.
Just so I know we're on the same page, can you repeat back to me how you'll take this medicine?

Sure. I'm just gonna take one tablet right before I go to bed with my other medications. And I guess I will switched to orange juice. And if I notice any muscle pain that is severe, I'll call Dr. Ferris right away.
Great, Kaylie. I know we went over a lot today. What other questions do you have for me?
Uh, I think you answered all my questions. Thank you.

Fantastic. All right. Well, here's your prescription. I even put it on auto fill for you so that it will be filled for you every- at the same time every month. And if you have any other questions later, our phone number is right here on the bottle, and you can call me at any time. Thanks so much. Have a great day.
Good morning. It's really nice that you've come to see me to talk about stopping smoking.
Good morning.
What brings you in today? What are you hoping to achieve?
Well, I'd like some medication if you can offer me some.
Absolutely, we can discuss medication options.  What else are you hoping to gain from our sessions?
Just whatever else you can do to help me become smoke-free.
Okay. Can you tell me more about why you want to quit smoking?
Well, these days I'm finding that I'm smoking 20 to 30 a day, and I'm getting sick of it.  I've seen my friends stop smoking, and it feels like I'm the only one left.
It sounds like you're feeling some pressure to quit, especially when you're around your friends.
Especially the other night at the restaurant. It was a bit embarrassing being the only one walking outside to smoke.
So, feeling a little uncomfortable and self-conscious is one of the reasons you want to quit?
Yes.
Are there any other reasons?
It's expensive these days.
How much are you spending a week, roughly?
About £7 a day.
So, about £50 a week?
Yes.
So, we have the cost, feeling like the odd one out, and not liking the smell. Those seem like three good reasons to consider quitting.
Yes.
Do you feel like those reasons are strong enough to motivate you to quit?
Yes.
Great. Have you thought about when you'd like to quit?
What do you suggest?
It often works best to pick a time when you're not under too much other stress.
Okay.
What do you enjoy most about smoking?  What are the main reasons you smoke?
It's just something to do. When I'm bored, I smoke. Or sometimes when I go out, but as I said, I'm often the only one outside smoking.
Okay. What do you think you'll miss the most about it?
It helps me with stress.
What kind of stress?
Just when I take a break at work. I need a break away from it all, just to shut off. The cigarette helps me calm down.
So, it's a way to de-stress and take a break.
Yes.
What's your favorite cigarette of the day?
Definitely the one at the end of the evening.
The one that helps you unwind and transition to your personal time.
Yes.
After you set a quit date, what do you think you might do at the end of the workday, when you'd normally have that cigarette?
I guess I'll just get some fresh air, but without a cigarette. I'll try to give myself regular breaks, maybe.
It sounds like you're already thinking about alternative strategies.
It's going to be tough.
Have you tried to quit before?
I managed a couple of weeks once.
What led you to start smoking again?
It was stress from an argument with my partner.
So, a stressful situation triggered you to start again.
Yes.

Let me summarize. You want to quit because of the cost, feeling left out, and the smell. You smoke mainly to relax and de-stress, especially at the end of the day.  You'd like to quit, and you want to choose a time when you're under less stress.  Is that a fair summary?
Yes.
When do you think might be a good time to set your quit date?
I have a party this weekend. Maybe Monday morning after that.

So, Monday morning after the party. That's next week. Okay. We often recommend medication to help people quit.  It can increase your chances of success and help manage cravings.  Have you considered any medication options?
Yes. I'm thinking about the patches.
Okay. You've seen the patches before?
Yes.

We can discuss how to use them.  The course usually lasts 10 to 12 weeks, and we recommend completing the whole course for the best chance of success. You mentioned that the end of the workday is a particularly challenging time.  Sometimes using two different types of nicotine replacement can be helpful.  For example, you could use a patch for a steady dose of nicotine and then have something else available for when cravings get strong.  What does a craving feel like for you?
I just get irritable.

That's a common nicotine withdrawal symptom.  The patch can help with that baseline irritability, and then we can talk about a second product you can use when those breakthrough cravings hit, especially in the first week.
Okay.
So, you're happy with Monday as your quit date?
Yes, absolutely.
Would you like to schedule a follow-up appointment?
Yes, definitely.
Would it be alright if I gave you a call if you don't make it to the appointment?
Yes, that would be great.

Hello, Mr. Green. It's good to see you again.  Last week we reviewed your results, and you have impaired glucose tolerance, slightly elevated blood pressure, and cholesterol.  Today, we'll discuss lifestyle changes that can improve your health. How have you been?
Well, I suppose you're going to tell me it's all my fault and I have to give up everything I enjoy.
Not at all. You're in charge of your health.  My role is to support you in making informed decisions.
The doctor said I might need medication long-term.
That sounds concerning. How do you feel about that?
I feel fine, but the doctor said it could be beneficial.

There are many things you can do to improve your health, often working in conjunction with medication. Today, we can explore options like diet, exercise, and weight management. Where would you like to begin?
Okay, what should I do first?
It's entirely up to you.  Where do *you* think you should start?
What do *you* think?
I can offer suggestions, but you already have a good understanding of what's beneficial.  What comes to mind for you?
You'll probably say stop smoking, lose weight, and exercise more, right?

Those are all excellent points.  Quitting smoking would have a significant positive impact, and weight loss would help with blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes risk. What are your thoughts on those?
I'd love to lose weight, but it's hard to give up the things I enjoy.
It's understandable that change is difficult. Where do you see yourself in terms of making these changes?
I want to be there for my children and grandchildren, and be a good example. I don't want to be a burden.
So, your family is a strong motivator for you?
Yes. I want to be healthy for them.
Where do you think you could start?
I've been thinking about it. I could cut back on my drinking. That contributes to my weight and blood pressure, doesn't it?
Absolutely, that's a great starting point.
Actually, I think I'll try to cut it out completely. My wife says I drink too much on weekends.
That sounds like a positive step, and it's great that you have support.
And I suppose I could cut out the snacks at work.
What could you replace them with to avoid getting hungry?
I'll have soup at lunchtime. A big bowl of soup is better than the snacks I usually have.
That's a fantastic idea. Vegetable soup can count towards your daily servings of fruits and vegetables. What else have you considered?
I've already stopped adding salt to my food. The doctor said it would help my blood pressure.
That's excellent!  Reducing salt intake also benefits bone health by helping retain calcium.
I didn't know that! I'll tell my wife. She uses a lot of salt, and her mother had osteoporosis.

That's a great way to support her too. You've made a wonderful start, Mr. Green. You're clearly motivated and have a good plan. You're reducing alcohol, cutting back on snacks, and have already reduced salt.  Next time, we can discuss smoking and exercise further, when you're ready. How do you feel about your progress so far?
I feel good about cutting back on snacks and alcohol. I'm taking it one step at a time. Hopefully, my next check-up will show improvement.
That's a great attitude.  Shall we schedule our next appointment for the same time next week?
Yes, that works for me.
Excellent. I look forward to seeing you then.
Thanks. You too.
Thanks for coming in today. I guess you've sat in that seat with lots of people like me in the past.
Mm.

Yeah. And you have some ideas about that and some experiences about that. So today I want to talk about that and I'm really interested to know what you've been thinking about in terms of what you may want to change in your life because we're going to be working together for a while here.
Right. Neat. What have I changed, what am I—
What you've been thinking about over the last little while about getting your life back on track. Because I noticed you've—
I've been thinking about how easy it would be to deal again.
Yeah.
I mean, I've been thinking about how I could actually set myself up the right way doing it the wrong way.
Sure. So what I'm picking up is that's a life that you know a lot about.
Mm.

And you can make lots of money and set yourself up well. What's the other side, because I guess when I talk to guys like yourself who have done time, often they're thinking about actually, maybe life can be different. So I'm wondering where you're at with the kind of thinking about—
Well, at the end of that last week inside, I had that kind of, okay, what's next buzz? And, you know, it just doesn't work out here.
Okay.
I don't have—I don't know what that is.
Sure. So life on the outside is pretty different than the kind of—
Yes.
—the expectation of life on the inside something?
Yeah, it's worse.
Yeah?
Yeah.
So tell me how you've been managing. Because I don't know if you've been back dealing? How have you been managing to—
I haven't yet, I mean—
Okay.
—the offer's there.
Yeah?
Um, I don't know why I haven't said that I will yet but I mean—
Tell me—
—it's there.
It's there and—and—and you've a lot of contacts?
Yeah.
You've been in the system, so lots of contacts. So this isn't a new challenge for you.
No.
So what stopped you over the last—How long have you been out now?
How long have I been out?
Yeah.
Three weeks, one day.
Three weeks, isn't it?
Three weeks, one day.
So what's been there? What's it about that you haven't done in three weeks one day?
I don't know.
22 days you've actually made a decision not to—to pick up your old life and continue on.

Um, I—I—you know, I kind of told myself not to, you know, just before I left. And then I'm just kind of with it and I don't quite know why. I don't know, if, uh, there's no real reason why I haven't yet. It's just that I don't—I just don't think it'll work the way I always dream it will you know, I see myself up like, whatever, if I do that again, the next leg is a long one. A real long one.
Okay.
And I—I can't go back there. There's no way I'm going back there.
Right. So the one hand you've—you—you could set yourself up and—and take the risk, but on the other hand, you know, that actually it might not last?
No, never lasts.
Never lasts. Mm. You seem like a bit of a crossroads to me.
Yep. I've been in crossroads for 12 years.
Mm. But there've been times when those crossroads would be more sort of focused than other times.
Yeah. And—
Yeah. And it sounds like maybe like—
—sort of opposite, yeah.
Yeah.
You know, we're in the middle, you know, and it's actually at the moment, I guess.
Yeah.
But I don't know. You know, that's quite clear that no idea.
Okay. Okay. So—
Do you have an idea?
No. Well, I've—I've got lots of ideas, but I'm really interested to hearing your ideas kind of first though because you know, and there might be some things that we can work on.
Mm.

But I guess what I'm really interested in is—is you've made a commitment 22 days, drug-free. Haven't gone back into that lifestyle. What's keeping you, 'cause you're at the crossroads, you kind of just pause there at the moment. I'm not sure about this other bit over here. What keeping you in that place?
Fiona?
Yeah?
Yeah.
Tell me about Fiona?
She's told me that it's over if I do it. You know, I mean, she—What tell you about, Fiona I mean she's been with me. She's the one who stayed through all the stuff. And I owe her—
Okay.
something.

12 years.
12 years. Okay. So she's stood by you then for the time, but this time she said, it happens again I'm out of here?
Yeah. She's actually got the black and white line down now.
Okay. And it sounds like you're listening to that black and white line.
It's pretty she—you know, she could be pretty full-on.
Yeah, yeah.
Yeah, so it's hard to ignore that line.
Yeah.
I mean. And it comes with a whole lot of different rules, and you know, she's never been quite like she is now.
Okay. So something's changed in your relationship between you, yeah?
Yeah. I think she has. I don't think I have.
Okay. So what's Fiona want from you?
She just wants me. I mean, she just wants someone to be there. Me. She—she remembers me and she wants—she wants him.
She wants him. So which him does she want, Daryl?
The one that, you know—
Does she want the—did she want the—the—the—the him that she fell in love with and saw great things in?
Yeah, that's the one.
Or does she want the—the—the—the him that's—that keeps on getting into trouble?
No, no. No one would want him. I don't want him. He's a right? She wants the one that she fell in love with.
Okay.
Yeah.

If I had the answer to that, I wouldn't need to be sitting here.

And I mean, I honest—I don't know, man. I don't know. I—I wish I knew somewhere I could start that, you know, could give it to her, but I—I can't. I—I don't know.
All right. Well, let's—let's just play with this idea a little bit, Daryl. So what did Fiona fall in love with? What were the qualities of Daryl that she said, This is him"?"
